Sec. 1. - Town incorporated. 
    Upon the petition of Harvey Elmer and others, praying for a division of the Town of East Windsor, and that all that part of said town lying south of a line in said petition described, should be incorporated into a new town: 
    RESOLVED BY THIS ASSEMBLY. That all that part of the Town of East Windsor lying south of a line connecting at the mouth of the Scantic River running thence S. 84;deg;9;min; E. 470 chains 75 links to Ellington town line, with all the inhabitants residing therein, be and the same is hereby incorporated into a separate town, by the name of SOUTH WINDSOR; and the inhabitants aforesaid and their successors, forever, residing within said limits shall have and enjoy all the powers, privileges and immunities which are enjoyed by other towns in this state, with the privilege of sending one representative to the general assembly of this state. And said new town shall pay its proportion (according to the list of 1844) of all debts, charges, expenses, suits, petitions and claims already due or which may exist against said Town of East Windsor, or for which said town may be hereafter made liable by force of any claim now existing. And the poor of said Town of East Windsor who were born within the limits hereby incorporated and have not gained a settlement elsewhere in this state than in said Town of East Windsor, by residence or otherwise within said limits, shall be deemed inhabitants of said Town of South Windsor, and shall be maintained, accordingly, whether said poor are now maintained by said Town of East Windsor or not; and said Town of East Windsor shall be liable to maintain all such poor of said East Windsor as are or may be absent therefrom: PROVIDED such persons at the time of departure belonging to that part of the Town of East Windsor incorporated into the Town of South Windsor. All the property belonging to the Town of East Windsor shall belong to the Town of East Windsor and said new Town of South Windsor, in proportion to their respective lists, according to the grand list of 1844, saving and excepting the public records and other property appertaining to the town clerk's office, which shall be and remain the property of the Town of East Windsor. And the town deposit fund shall belong to said towns in proportion to the number of their respective inhabitants. ALWAYS PROVIDED, that if after the organization of said Town of South Windsor, the selectmen of the aforesaid town do not agree in the division of the paupers or funds and property belonging to said towns on or before the 15th day of March, A.D. 1846, the selectmen of either town may apply to Amos M. Collins, Francis Fellows and Gurdon Robins, of Hartford, who, or either two of them, are hereby authorized and empowered to divide said paupers and funds and property in manner and form aforesaid; which division shall be final and conclusive, first notifying the selectmen aforesaid of the time and place when the same shall be made. The burden of keeping and maintaining the ferry across the Connecticut river in said East Windsor, at the mouth of the Scantic, shall belong to the new Town of South Windsor - which town shall hereafter keep and maintain the same for public accommodation as the same has been heretofore kept. The collectors of state and town taxes in the Town of East Windsor are hereby authorized to collect their respective taxes already laid, due, and in their respective rate-books contained, in the same manner as though this resolve had not passed. 
    The first town meeting of said new Town of South Windsor shall be held at the meeting house of the first society on the first Monday of August, A.D. 1845; and Theodore Elmer, and in case of his failure, Ebenezer Pinney, shall be moderator thereof, and shall warn said meeting by setting up a notification of the same on the signposts of said town, and such other places as either of said persons may deem proper, at least six days before said meeting. Said towns shall have all the powers at said first meeting incident to other towns in this state and full right to act accordingly; and the officers elected at such first meeting shall hold their offices until others are chosen and sworn in their stead. 
Editor's note- The preceding act, adopted in 1845, is taken from the "Resolves and Private Laws of the State of Connecticut, Volume IV, 1836 through 1857," page 1278. Such acts were, at the time, not assigned a chapter or bill number. 
Sec. 2. - Clarification and expansion of the power of the town relating to its sewerage system and to exempt town from certain provisions of C.G.S. § 7-253. 
(a)  The town of South Windsor may provide for the payment of the whole or any portion of the cost of its sewerage system, any extension or enlargement thereof, and any additional sewerage system hereafter acquired or constructed, by assessment, service charge, connection charge or such other method of payment as is deemed fair and equitable against the owners or real estate especially benefited thereby, whether or not such real estate abuts upon such work or improvement, and may provide that payment under such method or methods be made at such time or times as the growth and development of the various areas of said town warrant, or as connections to or extensions of the sewerage system are sought, and may enforce or collect such assessments, taxes or other charge either as a personal liability of the owner or as a lien on the lands benefited. 
(b)  The town of South Windsor may apply any charges, assessments or other payments assessed pursuant to section 1 [subsection (a)] of this act or C.G.S. § 7-249 against land or owners of land benefiting from the existing sewerage system to assure that such land or owners thereof shall bear a fair proportionate share of the cost of the sewerage system. 
(c)  Wherever a sewer is laid out through or adjacent to undeveloped lands or in a highway abutting such lands, and assessments are made with respect thereto by the town of South Windsor, and whenever the South Windsor sewer commission determines that at the time of completion of such sewer there would not be immediate benefits accruing to such lands and that such benefits will not accrue until there is a major change in conditions, of accessibility, in zoning restrictions, in use or in other conditions, said commission may defer collections and assessments of benefits subject to any equitable interest rates thereon which commission may assess, for such time as the rate of growth and development of the area warrants. 
(d)  If the sewer authority of the town of South Windsor provides for the payment of any assessment made pursuant to this act or C.G.S. § 7-249 in substantially equal annual installments, such installments of any assessment may be due at a time determined by said town notwithstanding the provisions of C.G.S. § 7-253 to the contrary. 
(e)  Any power granted by the provisions of this act shall be in addition to, and not in derogation of, any power granted to municipalities under any provision of the general statutes. 
(Sp. Act No. 260, 1969, §§ 1-5) 
Sec. 3. - Recovery for laying of water mains. 
(a)  At any time after water main pipelines are laid in the town of South Windsor, said town may apportion and assess the whole or any portion of the cost thereof upon the land owners who, at any time, elect to connect to such water main pipelines. 
(b)  Any assessment levied under subsection (a) not paid within thirty days after the due date shall be subject to interest from such due date at the interest rate and in the manner provided by the general statutes for delinquent property taxes. Each addition of interest shall be collectible as a part of such assessment. Any such unpaid assessment shall constitute a lien upon the real estate against which such assessment was levied from the date it became delinquent. Each such lien may be continued, released and recorded in the manner provided by the general statutes for continuing, recording and releasing property tax liens. Each such lien shall take precedence over all other liens and encumbrances except taxes and may be foreclosed in the same manner as a lien for property taxes. Said town may designate the tax collector or any other person as collector of such assessments and such collector may collect such assessment in accordance with the provisions of the general statutes for the collection of property taxes. The town may recover any such charges in a civil action against any person liable therefor. 
(Sp. Act No. 388, 1959) 
Sec. 4. - Bond issue for water mains. 
    The town of South Windsor may issue bonds, in the manner and subject to the limitations provided by C.G.S. ch. 109, for the purpose of the construction or extension of water mains of a private water company servicing said town, such mains to be the property of such company. 
(Sp. Act. No. 347, 1959)

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - Designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances, Town of South Windsor, Connecticut," and may be so cited. 
Sec. 1-2. - Rules of construction and definitions. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    Charter. The term "charter" shall mean the charter approved by the voters of the Town of South Windsor on November 8, 1977, and any subsequent amendments or revisions thereof. 
    Code, this Code. The terms "Code" or "this Code" shall refer to the Code of Ordinances, Town of South Windsor, Connecticut, as designated in section 1-1. 
    Council. The term "council" or "the council" shall mean the town council of the Town of South Windsor. 
    County. The term "the county" or "this county" shall mean the County of Hartford, in the State of Connecticut. 
    Gender. The use of any gender shall include the other gender. 
    C.G.S. The abbreviation "C.G.S." shall mean the General Statutes of Connecticut, Revision of 1958, as amended. 
    Joint authority. All words giving a joint authority to three or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. 
    Keeper and proprietor. The terms "keeper" and "proprietor" shall mean and include persons, firms, associations, corporations, clubs, copartnerships and joint venturers, whether acting by themselves or through a servant, agent or employee. 
    Number. The use of the singular shall include the plural, and the use of the plural shall include the singular. 
    Officers, employees, departments, boards, commissions, or agencies. Whenever the title of an officer, employee, department, board, commission or agency is given, it shall be construed to refer to an officer, employee, department, board, commission or agency of the Town of South Windsor. 
    Or, and. "Or" may be read "and," and "and" may be read "or" if the sense requires it. 
    Owner. The term "owner" applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person; another. The terms "person" and "another" may extend and be applied to communities, companies, corporations, public or private, societies and associations. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" shall include every species of property except real property as herein defined. 
    Property. The term "property" shall include real and personal property. 
    Public place. The term "public place" shall include any and all streets, highways and boulevards, alleys or other publicly owned or controlled ways and any and all publicly owned or controlled parks, squares, spaces, grounds and buildings. 
    Real property. The term "real property" shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Shall, may. "Shall" is mandatory; "may" is permissive. 
    Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" shall mean the paved portion of a street between the street right-of-way and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    State. The term "the state" or "this state" shall mean the State of Connecticut. 
    State law, general law or general statutes. The terms "state law, general law or general statutes" shall refer to the Connecticut General Statutes, as amended. 
    Street. The word "street" shall include streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public ways in the town; and may include private ways over which the town exercises jurisdiction. 
    Tenant, occupant. The term "tenant" or "occupant" applied to a building or land, shall include any person holding a written or oral lease of, or who occupies, the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Town. The term "town," "this town" or "the town" when used herein shall mean the Town of South Windsor, in the County of Hartford, State of Connecticut. 
    In the construction of this Code of Ordinances, except as otherwise provided in this Code of Ordinances, words and phrases shall be construed according to the common usage of the language and according to the general statutes; technical words and phrases, and such as have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law, shall be construed and understood accordingly. 
State Law reference- Rules of construction of terms used in the General Statutes, C.G.S. § 1-1. 
Sec. 1-3. - History notes, editor's notes, state law references and cross references. 
    The history notes appearing in parentheses after each section and the editor's notes and state law reference and cross reference notes throughout the Code are for the benefit of the user of the Code and shall not be considered as part of the text of the Code. 
Sec. 1-4. - Catchlines and headings. 
    The catchlines of the several sections and subsections of this Code, printed in boldface or italic type, and the chapter, article and division headings are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section, subsection, chapter, article or division and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles or a substantive portion of any such section, subsection, chapter, article or division, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, subsections, chapters, articles or divisions, including the catchlines or headings, are amended or reenacted. 
Sec. 1-5. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following: 
(1)  Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the town, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the town or any evidence of the town's indebtedness; 
(2)  Any appropriation ordinance or resolution or any ordinance or resolution providing for the levy of taxes or for an annual budget; 
(3)  Any ordinance annexing territory to the town or excluding territory as a part of the town; 
(4)  Any ordinance or resolution granting any franchise, permit or other right; 
(5)  Any ordinance accepting, dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening or vacating any street or public way in the town; 
(6)  Any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the town; 
(7)  Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor; 
(8)  Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the town; 
(9)  Any ordinance or code or parts thereof adopted by reference in this Code and not included herein; 
(10)  Any ordinance approving, authorizing or otherwise relating to any contract, obligation, agreement, lease, deed or other instrument; 
(11)  Any ordinance adopting a preliminary plan or development plan; 
(12)  Any temporary or special ordinance; 
and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length herein. 
Sec. 1-6. - Code does not affect prior offenses, rights, etc. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing, before the effective date of this Code. 
Sec. 1-7. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
    All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code of Ordinances that amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code of Ordinances may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein. In the case of repealed chapters, articles, divisions, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. 
    All ordinances that amend or repeal any provision of this Code shall set forth in full the sections or subsections to be amended or repealed. 
Sec. 1-8. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  When an ordinance repealing another is afterwards repealed, the first shall not be revived without express words to that effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment, penalty or forfeiture incurred before the repeal takes effect, or any suit, or prosecution, or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed, or for the recovery of a penalty or forfeiture incurred under the ordinance repealed. 
(c)  The passage or repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any action then pending. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C.G.S. § 1-1(s)-(u). 
Sec. 1-9. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    If any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court, such invalidity or unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining provisions of this Code. 
Sec. 1-10. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions any part of this Code of Ordinances or any ordinance of the town or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever with intent that any provision of this Code or other ordinance of the town shall be misrepresented or with intent to commit a fraud thereby. 
Sec. 1-11. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by town personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the town council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the council or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete; and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code that have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into the unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ to _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
Sec. 1-12. - General penalty. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code or any other ordinance of the town, or rule or regulation promulgated by any officer thereof under authority vested in him by law or ordinance, any act is prohibited or is declared to be unlawful or an offense, or the doing of any act is required, or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided, the violation of such ordinance, rule or regulation shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $99.00. Each day any such violation shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  The imposition of any punishment hereunder shall not prevent the enforced abatement of any unlawful condition by the town. 
State Law reference- Penalty limitation, C.G.S. § 7-148(c)(10)(A). 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Civil emergencies, ch. 26; courts, ch. 30; elections, ch. 34; law enforcement, ch. 62; library, ch. 66; planning, ch. 78; taxation, ch. 90; utilities, ch. 98. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Town seal. 
    The seal, of which an imprint is on file as part of the minutes of the June 2, 1969, meeting of the town council, is hereby adopted as the official seal of the town for use whenever and wherever the official seal of the town is necessary or appropriate. 
(Code 1978, § 2-100) 
State Law reference- Town seal, C.G.S. § 7-101. 
Sec. 2-2. - Reproduction of town seal. 
    Reproduction of the town seal in any manner whatsoever shall be made and used only under the direction and with the approval of the town, provided the town clerk may approve other reproduction of the seal for nonprofit purposes which in the clerk's judgment is of an educational or civic nature. 
(Code 1978, § 2-200) 
Sec. 2-3. - Interlocal agreements. 
    Any powers granted to any town board, agency, authority, district, committee or commission by any town ordinance or any powers of any town board, agency, authority, district, committee or commission derived from any town ordinance notwithstanding, no elected or appointed town board, agency, authority, district, committee or commission, except the board of education, shall enter into any contract or agreement with any other municipality, any borough, city, local government unit, local agency or authority, or district as defined in C.G.S. §§ 7-324, 7-330, 7-333 or 7-334, or any board, agency, authority, committee, commission or district of such municipality, borough, city, local governmental unit, agency or authority or district as so defined without the approval of the town council. 
(Code 1978, § 2-3000) 
Sec. 2-4. - Tax stabilization fund program. 
(a)  Title. This section shall be known and may be cited as the Town of South Windsor Tax Stabilization Fund (TSF) program. 
(b)  Purpose of fund. The town's general tax revenues are sensitive to economic conditions as well as actions taken by state and federal government. Unanticipated revenue shortfalls during a fiscal year are usually addressed through reductions to services or increased taxes. The TSF program is established for sound financial management and fiscal accountability and enforces spending discipline by setting aside monies collected from revenues received during good economic conditions for use during years with lower growth or declining revenue. The TSF program may also reduce town borrowing costs due to stronger bond ratings. The purpose of the tax stabilization fund is to set aside revenue during years of strong growth in a fund which does not lapse at the end of the municipal fiscal year, which monies would then be available when revenue is stagnant or in decline and may be expended to prevent large tax increases and protect against the reduction of services in future years. 
(c)  Establishment of TSF. There is hereby established a fund pursuant to C.G.S. § 7-148(K), which fund shall not lapse at the end of the municipal fiscal year. Said fund shall be known as the South Windsor Tax Stabilization Fund (TSF). 
(d)  Fund balance. The town's annual budget shall include allocations to the TSF in amounts adequate to meet its purposes as follows: allocations into the fund will come from any surplus over $1,000,000.00 in the general fund annually. The town council may also appropriate up to ten percent of the amount of tax revenue generated in the first full year of new residential and/or commercial construction and/or revenue generated by the expiration of tax abatement and/or tax fixing agreements resulting in increased personal property and/or real property taxes. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein, the aggregate balance in the TSF shall be a minimum of $500,000.00 but in no event shall it exceed a maximum of $3,000,000.00. 
(e)  Fund expenditures. The TSF shall not be reduced or used for purposes other than those specifically provided for in subsection (b) above, purpose of fund . During the development of the annual budget, the town council may authorize a transfer from the TSF to the general fund. This transfer will be shown as a revenue line in general fund budgeted revenue consistent to the extent possible with use of fund balance entries. The minimum annual transfer amount shall be $50,000.00 and the maximum annual transfer shall be $500,000.00 in any one fiscal year. 
(f)  Management of fund and termination. The TSF shall be administered by the town treasurer pursuant to Charter section 205. The TSF shall only be terminated by an affirmative vote of six members of the town council. 
(Ord. No. 222, 2-20-18) 
Secs. 2-5-2-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Civil preparedness director, § 26-36 et seq.; justices of the peace, § 30-1; elections, ch. 34; police department, § 62-31 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-36. - Town and board of education medical insurance program. 
(a)  Title. This section shall be known and may be cited as the "Town of South Windsor and South Windsor Board of Education Medical Insurance Program." 
(b)  Establishment of self-insurance funds. There is hereby established a fund under this program. It shall be known as "Town of South Windsor and South Windsor Board of Education Medical Insurance Fund" (hereinafter referred to as "fund" or "SWMIF"). 
(c)  Purpose of fund. The SWMIF shall be used for the purchase of insurance and services, payment of administrative costs and the accumulation of reserves for future costs in areas relating to the health needs of town and board of education employees and their dependents. 
(d)  Fund protection. Based on the recommendation of the town's consultants, the town manager and the superintendent of schools, the town's annual budget shall include allocations to the SWMIF in amounts adequate to meet its purposes. The fund shall not be reduced or used for purposes other than those specifically provided for in subsection (c), purpose of fund. This fund may be liquidated only by an affirmative vote by six members of the South Windsor Town Council to discontinue the self-insurance program described in subsection (b), establishment of self-insurance funds; provided, however, that the fund shall remain in effect until such time as all claims required to be paid under the town's and the board's contractual obligations have been satisfied. The SWMIF may be liquidated only following consultation with the board of education and upon 18 months' prior notice to the board, which notice may be waived by the board by affirmative vote of six board members. A decision by the board of education to withdraw from the fund shall also be preceded by 18 months' prior notice to the town, which notice may be waived by the town by affirmative vote of six members of the South Windsor Town Council. 
(e)  Management of fund. The SWMIF shall be administered by the town manager, or his or her designee, and by the superintendent of schools, or his or her designee, subject only to limitations imposed under the Town Charter relating to the town treasurer and the town attorney. 
(Ord. No. 171, §§ 1-5, 3-21-05) 
Sec. 2-37. - Retired employee health care benefits trust fund. 
(a)  Establishment of trust fund. In accordance with C.G.S. § 7-450(a), the town shall establish a trust fund ("trust") to hold and invest all contributions and assets of the town's retiree health care plan ("plan"). The town shall have the authority to amend or terminate the trust. 
(b)  Purpose of trust fund. The trust shall be for the purpose of funding current and future postemployment health care benefits for eligible retired employees in accordance with the plan. The trust may also be for the purpose of funding any other postemployment health and life plans as the town may establish. 
(c)  Powers and duties of trustee. The finance director shall serve as the trustee ("trustee") of the trust. The trustee shall have such powers and duties as set forth in the terms of the trust, including, but not limited to, investing the assets of the trust and making payments or other disbursements in accordance with the plan and terms of the trust. 
(d)  Administration of retiree health care plan. The town manager shall serve as the plan administrator of the plan and shall have such powers and duties as set forth in the plan and the trust with respect to the administration of the plan, including, but not limited to, providing all proper instructions and directions to the trustee regarding disbursements from the trust. 
(Ord. No. 184, 6-15-09) 
Secs. 2-38-2-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SOCIAL SECURITY 

Sec. 2-56. - Application for membership. 
    The town shall apply for membership and to participate in the old age and survivors insurance system under title II of the Social Security Act as amended, in accordance with C.G.S. § 7-452 et seq. for all its employees with the exception of the employees excluded by C.G.S. § 7-454 et seq. 
(Code 1978, § 7-100) 
Sec. 2-57. - Execution of agreements to effectuate coverage. 
    The town manager shall execute on behalf of and in the name of the town any and all agreements with the state employees retirement commission for the purpose specified in section 2-56 in accordance with and subject to the provisions of C.G.S. § 7-452 et seq. and subject to the regulations promulgated by the state employees retirement commission pursuant to C.G.S. § 7-452 et seq. 
(Code 1978, § 7-100) 
Sec. 2-58. - Deduction from wages authorized. 
    The town treasurer shall be authorized and directed to deduct from wages of employees participating in the old age and survivors insurance system as required by C.G.S. § 7-453 and to forward the amount thereof together with the contribution of the town to the state employees retirement commission in manner and form prescribed by the regulations. 
(Code 1978, § 7-100) 
Secs. 2-59-2-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PENSION PLAN[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Pension committee, § 2-141 et seq. 

Sec. 2-81. - Plan anniversary date. 
    Effective January 1, 1983, the pension system as funded through group annuity contract by the Aetna Life Insurance Company shall have a plan anniversary date of January 1 and each subsequent year. 
(Code 1978, § 7-201; Ord. No. 106, 2-14-83) 
Sec. 2-82. - Method of funding. 
    Effective January 1, 1983, the method of funding under the group annuity contract shall be changed from deferred annuity to immediate participating guarantee (I.P.G.) and pension investment contract (P.I.C.). 
(Code 1978, § 7-201; Ord. No. 106, 2-14-83) 
Sec. 2-83. - Qualification of members. 
    Effective January 1, 1983, an employee shall be eligible to become a member of the pension plan on the first day of the month following the anniversary date of employment providing the following requirements are met: 
(1)  He is a full-time employee of the town and is not covered under the state teachers' retirement system; elected officials are not eligible for membership, with the exception of the town clerk; 
(2)  He works at least 35 hours a week and at least ten months a year; 
(3)  He has completed at least one year of continuous service; 
(4)  He has reached age 21; and 
(5)  He was hired before age 50, if a policeman, or before age 55, in any other case. 
(Code 1978, § 7-201; Ord. No. 106, 2-14-83) 
Sec. 2-84. - Basic benefits; future service retirement annuity. 
    The yearly amount of retirement credited for each year of service during the period commencing December 1, 1968, and ending November 30, 1971, will equal 11/4 percent of the first $4,800.00 of the employee's earnings plus 21/2 percent of the employee's earnings in excess of $4,800.00. The yearly amount of retirement credited for each year of service after December 1, 1971, will equal 11/2 percent of the first $4,800.00 of the employee's earnings plus 21/2 percent of the employee's earnings in excess of $4,800.00. 
(Code 1978, § 7-201) 
Sec. 2-85. - Interest. 
    Effective January 1, 1976, in computing the employee's death benefit and cash termination benefit, interest shall be credited at the rate of five percent compounded annually, from January 1, 1976, on previous contributions and accumulated interest and from the end of the contract year in which subsequent employee contributions are made. 
(Code 1978, § 7-201) 
Sec. 2-86. - Vesting. 
    Effective January 1, 1976, an employee whose service with the town is terminated will retain full vested rights to the retirement annuity previously purchased for him attributable to his own contributions. He will retain a vested right to a percentage of the retirement annuity previously purchased for him attributable to town contributions in accordance with the following schedule: 
VESTING SCHEDULE 
Years of Service Vested Percentage Less than 10   0 10  50 11  60 12  70 13  80 14  90 15 or more 100  
(Code 1978, § 7-201) 
Secs. 2-87-2-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS, COMMITTEES, AGENCIES, AUTHORITIES AND COUNCILS[4] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Civil preparedness agency, § 26-66 et seq.; civil emergency advisory council, § 26-101 et seq.; flood and erosion control board, § 46-31 et seq.; historic district commission, § 54-33; human relations commission, § 58-31 et seq.; library board of directors, § 66-36 et seq.; parks and recreation commission, § 74-31 et seq.; traffic authority, § 94-36 et seq.; water pollution control authority, § 98-31 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-121-2-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PENSION COMMITTEE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Pension plan, § 2-81 et seq. 

Sec. 2-141. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Retirement plans means the retirement plans of the town employees currently in existence for town employees, excluding those who participate in the state teachers' retirement system. 
(Ord. No. 149, § 1, 5-19-98) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-142. - Created; membership. 
    There shall be a pension committee composed of nine members. The pension committee shall be comprised of the town manager, finance director, the mayor, two members of the town council appointed by the town council, two town employees appointed by the town manager, and two committee members representing the town board of education. 
(Ord. No. 149, § 3, 5-19-98) 
Sec. 2-143. - Appointments; compensation. 
(a)  The pension committee members appointed by the town council shall be appointed for two-year terms, except that the terms shall expire concurrent with their term of office or when they leave their council position. The town council may also appoint two alternates from the town council, board of education, board of fire commissioners or the board of police commissioners. These members may only act in the absence of the regular member from the town council. 
(b)  All vacancies that may occur on the pension committee shall be filled by the town council, except for vacancies of committee members representing the town board of education, which vacancies shall be filled by the board of education. 
(c)  The members of the pension committee shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 149, § 4, 5-19-98) 
Sec. 2-144. - Administration. 
(a)  The management of the investment and funding of the town's retirement plans, including the volunteer fire department's pension plan, is hereby vested in the pension committee. 
(b)  The pension committee may make rules and regulations for the investment and funding of the retirement plans, which are not inconsistent with the terms and provisions of the plans. The pension committee may construe the plans and its construction thereof, and its actions taken in good faith with respect to investment and funding will be final and conclusive. It may correct any defects or supply any omission or reconcile any inconsistencies in such manner and to such extent as it shall deem expedient to carry the same into effect. The committee shall be the sole and final judge of such expediency. The pension committee shall supervise and control the investment and funding of the retirement plans in accordance with the terms of the plans to accomplish this purpose. 
(c)  The pension committee shall be responsible for keeping records of investments, which shall be subject to audit. Employees may examine records pertaining directly to them. 
(d)  The finance director, upon approval of the pension committee, shall be responsible for all withdrawals of fund moneys and seeing that the management of the accounts is carried out in accordance with the direction of the pension committee. 
(Ord. No. 149, § 5, 5-19-98) 
Sec. 2-145. - Outside assistance. 
    The pension committee may employ such actuarial, legal or clerical consultant services as it deems necessary for the proper operation of the pension plans or pension fund, within the limits of such appropriations as may be made by the town council. 
(Ord. No. 149, § 6, 5-19-98) 
Sec. 2-146. - Investments. 
    The pension committee shall manage and control the retirement plan funds and be responsible for investments of the principal and income of such funds. The committee may appoint an investment advisor/consultant to assist in the investing or reinvesting of any or all available funds and/or may invest or reinvest any and/or all available funds with an appropriate investment agency. 
(Ord. No. 149, § 7, 5-19-98) 
Sec. 2-147. - Hold harmless. 
    No member of the committee shall be responsible or liable for any negligent act, or failure to act, of the committee or its members when operating within their role or jurisdiction of said committee. This provision shall not apply to any act of fraud or intentional act of malfeasance. 
(Ord. No. 149, § 8, 5-19-98) 
Sec. 2-148. - Reports. 
    The pension committee shall report to the town council every two years on the financial condition of the retirement plans based upon an actuarial report. The report shall include other recommendations or facts that may be of value to the members of the plan and to the town council. The pension committee shall also submit a report annually to the town council. 
(Ord. No. 149, § 9, 5-19-98) 
Sec. 2-149. - Annual budget. 
    The pension committee shall submit annually to the town manager a budget for preparation of the town's annual budget and an amount for any payments to the retirement plans during the coming year, along with a schedule of estimated expenses necessary for the administration of the retirement plans. The budget shall be submitted in accordance with the town Charter section on the preparation of the annual budget. 
(Ord. No. 149, § 10, 5-19-98) 
Sec. 2-150. - Amendments to plans. 
    The retirement plans may be amended from time to time in accordance with any respective collective bargaining agreement and as adopted by the town council, following a referral to the pension committee for its recommendations. 
(Ord. No. 149, § 2, 5-19-98) 
Secs. 2-151-2-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PUBLIC BUILDING COMMISSION[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Charter reference- Appointment of commission, § 502. 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86. 

Sec. 2-171. - Established. 
    A public building commission is established for the town. 
(Code 1978, § 2-300) 
Sec. 2-172. - Powers and duties. 
    The powers and duties of the public building commission shall be as prescribed in this section. The commission shall: 
(1)  Appoint its own chairman and secretary, and establish its own rules and regulations for the conduct of its meetings. 
(2)  Be generally responsible for the planning and construction of such public buildings as may be specifically authorized by the voters in town meeting. 
(3)  Study sites and building locations for such public buildings as may be proposed by other branches of the town government and shall, in cooperation with the town planning and zoning commission, recommend appropriate sites to the council. 
(4)  As deemed necessary, recommend to the council appropriations for each building project, in whole or in part, for action by the council and shall be bound by the appropriations so made. 
(5)  At its discretion, select an architect for each building project and shall select either directly or indirectly such other professional services as may be required. Any such contract with such architect or other professional service shall be executed by the town manager on behalf of the town. 
(6)  Have prepared preliminary and final building construction plans as needed for each project, and shall obtain the approval of such plans by other town, state and federal boards or commissions where required by law or good practice. Approval by the town government body that will administer the building after its completion shall be required in each instance. 
(7)  Seek competitive bids for construction of each project and shall make contract awards in accordance with its best judgment for the benefit of the town within the limitation of each related appropriation. 
(8)  Arrange for adequate supervision of each project during construction through the use of the services of the architect or by other suitable means. 
(9)  For each project that may benefit by payments to the town from state or federal funds, make applications for such benefits; or, in those cases where another branch of the town government is by law selected to make such application, recommend such action to the appropriate branch. 
(10)  Upon completion of each building project, turn the project over to the cognizant town government body and shall notify such body and the council of such acts in writing. 
(11)  Subsequent to completion of each project, render to the council, in writing, a report on the project and an accounting of the expenditures made under the related appropriation. 
(Code 1978, § 2-301) 
Secs. 2-173-2-195. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Planning, ch. 78. 
State Law reference- Joint commission authorized, C.G.S. § 8-4a. 

Sec. 2-196. - Zoning and planning commission law adopted. 
    The provisions of C.G.S. § 8-1 et seq., relating to zoning, and the provisions of C.G.S. § 8-18 et seq., relating to planning commissions, are adopted by the town. 
(Code 1978, § 2-401) 
Sec. 2-197. - Duties and title. 
    The planning and zoning commission established as provided in Charter section 204 shall have all the powers and duties of both a planning and zoning commission provided in C.G.S. §§ 8-1 et seq. and 8-18 et seq. 
(Code 1978, § 2-402) 
Sec. 2-198. - Chairman, secretary. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall appoint a secretary, whose term of office, compensation and duties shall be prescribed by the commission. During the month of October, the commission shall elect one of its members to be chairman, who shall hold office for a period of one year, or until his successor is appointed. 
(Code 1978, § 2-403) 
Sec. 2-199. - Disqualification of members. 
    No insurance agent or broker, or real estate agent or broker, shall be eligible to become or to remain a member of the planning and zoning commission. If any member shall, during the term of his office, engage in the business of acting as an insurance or real estate agent or broker, he shall resign from the commission forthwith; and if he fails to resign, he shall be removed by a majority vote of the other members of the commission if they find after a public hearing before them that he has violated the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1978, § 2-404) 
Secs. 2-200-2-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - INSURANCE CONTROL COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-221. - Established. 
    An insurance control commission is established consisting of the town manager, who shall be the chairman; the mayor or his designate from among the council; one councilman, who shall be appointed by the council; the chairman of the board of education or his designate; and the town attorney. The commission shall appoint not less than one advisor who shall be thoroughly familiar with coverage offered by fire, extended coverage and casualty insurance policies and not less than one advisor who shall be thoroughly familiar with health and accident and life insurance group plans, which advisors shall have no vote in the proceedings of the commission. The commission shall place all insurance and bonds written on behalf of the town and shall provide for the manner in which commissions accruing on those policies shall be divided. No person receiving commission, salary or other remuneration for the writing or placing of insurance policies and/or bonds shall be a member of the commission. 
(Code 1978, § 2-500) 
Secs. 2-222-2-245. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - CONSERVATION COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-246. - Established; membership, duties. 
(a)  A conservation commission is established for the development, conservation, supervision and regulation of natural resources, including water resources, within the territorial limits of the town. 
(b)  All appointments made to the conservation commission shall be made by the town manager, and all members and alternate members may be removed by the town manager for cause, and the town manager may fill any vacancy if one should occur. 
(c)  The members of the Inland-Wetlands Agency, appointed pursuant to section 305 of the Charter, may be the members of the conservation commission who are appointed under this division. 
(d)  All terms of members and alternates on the conservation commission shall be four years in length. The terms of all members of the conservation commission shall be coterminous with those of the Inland-Wetlands Agency. 
(e)  The conservation commission shall appoint its own chairman and secretary and establish its own rules and regulations for the conduct of its business. 
(f)  The conservation commission shall have the powers and duties provided by the general statutes. 
(Code 1978, § 2-901; Ord. No. 98, § 1, 5-7-79; Ord. No. 99, § 2-901, 2-4-80) 
Secs. 2-247-2-270. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - CAPITAL REGION PLANNING AGENCY[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Planning, ch. 78. 

Sec. 2-271. - Town representation. 
(a)  The town adopts C.G.S. §§ 8-31a-8-37a and joins the Capital Region Planning Agency as defined by the state development commission. 
(b)  During the month of November following every municipal election, the town planning and zoning commission shall appoint one of its members as a representative to the capital region planning commission, for a term of two years. This appointment shall be submitted to the town council for its approval. If the town council fails to approve the appointment, the town planning and zoning commission shall submit the name of another of its members for approval and shall continue to do so until an appointee is designated who meets the council's approval. 
(Code 1978, §§ 2-1001, 2-1301) 
DIVISION 8. - REGIONAL COUNCIL OF GOVERNMENTS 

Sec. 2-272. - Law adopted. 
    The town adopts C.G.S. §§ 4-124i-4-124p, providing for the formation of a regional council of governments within a planning region as defined or redefined by the secretary of the state office of policy and management, and joins such regional council of governments when and as such council is duly established in accordance with state law, upon their adoption by not less than 60 percent of all municipalities within such planning region. The adoption of such sections of the general statutes is intended to include the provisions of any special act of the 1973 General Assembly respecting additional representation for the core city within the capital region on a regional council of governments, and a nonvoting advisory regional forum thereunder, consistent with proposed bylaws of such regional council of governments dated January 25, 1973, and endorsed by the existing regional council of governments on May 3, 1971. 
(Code 1978, § 2-1300) 
Sec. 2-273. - Representatives. 
(a)  The mayor shall be the principal representative to the regional council of governments. 
(b)  During the month of November following every municipal election, the council shall appoint one of its members as an alternative representative to serve in the event of the mayor's absence. 
(Code 1978, § 2-1301) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C.G.S. § 4-124k. 
Secs. 2-274-2-295. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - HOUSING AUTHORITY 

Sec. 2-296. - Declaration of need. 
    The town council, after investigation, hereby finds and declares that there is a shortage of safe, sanitary dwelling accommodations in the town available to families of low income at rentals they can afford, and that there is a need for a housing authority in the town. 
(Code 1978, § 2-1501) 
Sec. 2-297. - Creation and powers. 
    The town council creates a town housing authority, which authority shall have all the powers invested in such authority by the statutes and shall be composed of five commissioners to be appointed by the town council as provided in C.G.S. § 8-41. 
(Code 1978, § 2-1502) 
Secs. 2-298-2-320. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-321. - Intent. 
    It is the intent of this division to promote the economic welfare of the town.

    Appointments of members of the economic development commission and alternate members shall be made for terms of four years. Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term and in the same manner as the original appointment. The commission shall elect from its own members a chairman and a vice-chairman every two years.

DIVISION 11. - MASS TRANSIT AND HIGHWAY ADVISORY COMMISSION[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 94. 

Sec. 2-346. - Established; composition; terms; vacancies; qualifications. 
(a)  A mass transit and highway advisory commission is established, consisting of nine electors of the town to be appointed by this division and the town council. 
(b)  In the month of December, in odd-numbered years, successors to the members whose terms are then expiring shall be appointed to serve for four years or until their successors are appointed, whichever is later. All vacancies shall be filled by the town council. 
(c)  No more than five members shall be members of the same political party. 
(Code 1978, § 2-1901; Ord. No. 96, 5-7-79) 
Sec. 2-347. - Organization. 
    The mass transit and highway advisory commission shall select its own chairman and secretary and establish its own rules and procedures for the conduct of its business. 
(Code 1978, § 2-1902; Ord. No. 96, 5-7-79) 
Sec. 2-348. - Duties. 
    The mass transit and highway advisory commission shall: 
(1)  Study the needs of the town in the area of mass transportation and present to the council plans and programs for the development of a comprehensive, balanced mass transit policy. 
(2)  Investigate, analyze and advise the council on proposals made by federal, state, regional, local or private agencies in the area of mass transportation. 
(3)  Recommend to the council those actions necessary for proper participation by the town in federal, state, regional, local or private programs designed to improve the mass transportation capabilities of the town. 
(4)  Coordinate all town activities relating to mass transportation. 
(5)  Monitor conditions that might effect changes in traffic patterns or traffic flow in the town and investigate and propose changes or additions to streets and highways to accommodate these changes and report its findings and recommendations to the town council, the town planning and zoning commission, and the town traffic authority. 
(6)  Investigate, analyze and advise the town council and town traffic authority in matters of traffic safety. 
(Code 1978, § 2-1903; Ord. No. 96, 5-7-79) 
Secs. 2-349-2-370. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 12. - DRUG AND ALCOHOL ABUSE PREVENTION COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-371. - Establishment; membership. 
(a)  There is established a drug and alcohol abuse prevention commission consisting of the chief of police or his designee, the chairman of the board of education or his designee, the town's youth coordinator, the town's social services director, the town's public health director, a representative of the town's public health association, and five citizens of the town appointed by the council. The citizens appointed by the council shall serve for a term of two years. At the expiration of their term and biennially thereafter, successors to the members whose terms are then expiring shall be appointed by the council to serve for a term of two years. 
(b)  All vacancies shall be filled by the town council. 
(Ord. No. 97, § 2-3006, 5-7-79) 
Sec. 2-372. - Organization. 
    The commission shall select its own chairman, vice-chairman and secretary and establish its own rules and procedures for the conduct of its business. 
(Ord. No. 97, § 2-3007, 5-7-79) 
Sec. 2-373. - Duties. 
    The commission shall investigate, study and analyze the problems of drug and alcohol abuse in the town, including the cause and effect thereof; develop recommendations and programs to solve and prevent these problems, and advise the town council in regard thereto. 
(Ord. No. 97, § 2-3008, 5-7-79) 
Secs. 2-374-2-395. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 13. - AGRICULTURAL LAND PRESERVATION ADVISORY COMMISSION[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Cross reference- Planning, ch. 78. 

Sec. 2-396. - Establishment and composition. 
(a)  An agricultural land preservation advisory commission is established consisting of 12 members to be appointed by the town council as follows: 
(1)  Four residents of the town who are either farmers or are otherwise associated with the agriculture industry. 
(2)  A representative from the Hartford County Soil & Water Conservation District who is a resident of the town. 
(3)  A member or alternate of the South Windsor Inland-Wetlands Agency/Conservation Commission. 
(4)  A representative from the South Windsor Land Trust. 
(5)  A resident of the town, preferably with experience in or knowledge of real estate transactions or investments. 
(6)  A resident of the town employed by or associated with a banking or other financial institution. 
(7)  Three persons, at large, who are residents of the town. 
(b)  The members of the commission shall be appointed for a term of three years. All members shall hold office until their successors are appointed. 
(Ord. No. 141, § 1, 2-3-97) 
Sec. 2-397. - Organization. 
(a)  The agricultural land preservation advisory commission shall elect, annually, its own chairman and secretary and a vice-chairman, who shall act in the place of the chairman in the event of the chairman's absence or incapacity. However, the chairman, vice-chairman and secretary shall continue to hold such offices until their successors are elected. 
(b)  The commission shall establish its own rules and procedures for the conduct of its business. Otherwise, it shall follow Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised, where applicable and not in conflict with its own adopted rules and procedures. 
(c)  The commission shall establish a schedule of regular meetings. Special meetings may be called at any time by the chairman or upon written request of any seven members. Seven members shall constitute a quorum. 
(Ord. No. 141, § 2, 2-3-97) 
Sec. 2-398. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the agricultural land preservation advisory commission shall be to act in an advisory capacity to the town council by establishing farmland preservation priorities for the town and conveying these priorities to the town council with specific recommendations as to what the town council, town agencies and/or the town government administration can or should do to maintain and promote a viable agriculture industry within the town in accordance with such priorities. 
(Ord. No. 141, § 3, 2-3-97) 
Sec. 2-399. - Duties. 
    The duties of the agricultural land preservation advisory commission shall be as follows: 
(1)  Inventory and develop information and maps that show active and inactive farmland, prime and important farmland and farms in relation to zoning, inland wetlands, drainage basins, surface water and groundwater, flood hazard areas, aquifers and recharge areas, and any other environmentally or resource sensitive areas. 
(2)  Conduct surveys to gather information from farmers and others in the agriculture industry concerning attitudes, conditions and opinions about the future of farming and related activities and what actions would be required to maintain or enhance agriculture within the town. 
(3)  Promote the use of local agriculture products through displays, fairs or any other method deemed appropriate by the commission. 
(4)  Sponsor an agriculture day or days to educate local citizens concerning the multiple benefits of a local agriculture industry and encourage the participation in such events by schools, farmers and community organizations. 
(5)  If the town at any time establishes an agricultural land preservation fund pursuant to C.G.S. § 7-131q, act as an advisor to the town council regarding that fund. 
(6)  Keep records of its meetings and its activities and submit an annual report to the town council. 
(7)  Appoint advisors to assist it in the fulfillment of its duties as it deems appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 141, § 4, 2-3-97) 
Secs. 2-400-2-420. - Reserved.

DIVISION 15. - PATRIOTIC COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-446. - Establishment and composition. 
    A patriotic commission is hereby established consisting of ten members and two alternates, all of whom shall be residents of the Town of South Windsor, to be appointed by the town council as follows: 
(1)  The initial nine members of the commission were appointed for a term of three years except that initially three of the members were appointed for a two-year term and three members were appointed for a one-year term. All subsequent appointments shall be for a term of three years. 
(2)  During the month of October 1998, the town council appointed two alternates to the patriotic commission, one for a term of four years, and another for a term of three years. As each of these terms expires, the town council shall appoint each alternate for three-year terms. 
(3)  During the month of July 2011, the town council appointed one additional member to the patriotic commission for a three-year term. 
(4)  Effective as of January 31, 2012, the term of each person who is a member of the commission on that date shall be extended to December 31st of the year in which the member's term would otherwise expire, and all subsequent appointments shall expire on December 31st of the applicable year. All members, however, shall hold office until their successors are appointed. 
(Ord. No. 118, § 1, 6-1-87; Ord. No. 152, § 1, 9-22-98; Ord. No. 192, § 1, 7-18-11; Ord. No. 193, § 1, 1-17-12)

(a)  The commission shall elect, annually, its own chairperson and secretary and a vice-chairperson who shall act in the place of the chairperson in the event of the chairperson's absence or incapacity. However, the chairperson, vice-chairperson and secretary shall continue to hold such offices until their successors are elected. 
(b)  The commission shall establish its own rules and procedures for the conduct of its business. Otherwise, it shall follow Robert's Rules of Order, where applicable, and not in conflict with its own adopted rules and procedures. 
(c)  The commission shall establish a schedule of regular meetings. Special meetings may be called at any time by the chairperson or upon written request of any five members. Five members shall constitute a quorum. 
(Ord. No. 118, § 2, 6-1-87; Ord. No. 152, § 2, 9-22-98; Ord. No. 192, § 2, 7-18-11; Ord. No. 193, § 2, 1-17-12) 
Sec. 2-448. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the commission shall be to recognize, accommodate and foster pride and patriotism among the citizens of South Windsor in our nation, our state and our town and to demonstrate evidence thereof through the development and conduct of programs and activities as hereinafter described. 
(Ord. No. 118, § 3, 6-1-87; Ord. No. 152, § 3, 9-22-98; Ord. No. 192, § 3, 7-18-11; Ord. No. 193, § 3, 1-17-12) 
Sec. 2-449. - Duties. 
    The duties of the commission shall be to study and develop plans for programs and activities related to national and state holidays and town celebrations, including the commemoration and/or honoring of the nation, state and/or town, the history and culture thereof, military and other units and citizens and/or officials thereof, and to make recommendations for same to the town council and upon approval by the town council to plan, arrange, supervise and conduct such programs and activities. The commission may appoint advisers to assist it in the fulfillment of its duties and purpose as it deems appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 118, § 4, 6-1-87; Ord. No. 152, § 4, 9-22-98; Ord. No. 192, § 4, 7-18-11; Ord. No. 193, § 4, 1-17-12)

ARTICLE IV. - CODE OF ETHICS 

Sec. 2-481. - Establishment; purpose. 
    The proper operation of the town government requires that public officers, officials and employees serve in the public interest; that governmental decisions and policies be made in the proper channels of the governmental structure; that public office not be used for personal gain; and that the public has confidence in the integrity of its government. The purpose of this article is to set forth standards of ethical conduct, to develop and maintain a tradition of responsible and effective public service, and to provide for actions to be taken in the event of violation of this article. In recognition of these goals, there is hereby established for the town a code of ethics as stated in this article. 
(Ord. No. 124, § 14-101, 11-6-89) 
Sec. 2-482. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Agency means all departments, boards, commissions, committees of the town and the town council as more specifically referred to in section 1001 of the Charter. 
    Close relative or business associate means a relationship between an individual, in his official capacity, and a particular relative or business associate of that individual that is such that it would tend to influence improperly that individual's judgment, in his official capacity, on a particular issue or item. 
    Conflict of interest means the taking part or participation of an official or employee of the town in any action in such individual's official capacity that involves either a situation wherein such individual has a financial interest or the situation involves a close relative or business associate. 
    Employee means any person receiving a salary or wages from the town for services rendered, whether full-time or part-time. 
    Financial interest means any interest in the outcome of the exercise of a person's official capacity from which that person expects to or does derive economic gain in excess of the economic gain that is expected to be or is derived by the members of the public generally. Such person shall further be deemed to have a financial interest if any close relative or business associate of such person or if any company in which such person holds greater than a five percent interest is the beneficiary of economic gain in excess of that derived by the public generally as encompassed in the previous sentence. 
    Official means any person holding elective or appointive office in the government of the town, except justices of the peace, and shall include the town treasurer, the town attorney, the town clerk, and members and alternate members, if any, of the town council, the board of education, the town planning and zoning commission, the zoning board of appeals, the board of library directors, the housing authority, committees appointed to oversee the construction or improvement of town facilities, or any board, commission or agency that exercises legislative or judicial functions or financial authority. 
(Ord. No. 124, § 14-102, 11-6-89) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-483. - Standard of service. 
    All officers, officials and employees of the town shall adhere to the rules and regulations of performance and work established as the standards for their positions by the appropriate authority. 
(Ord. No. 124, § 14-103, 11-6-89) 
Sec. 2-484. - Use of public property by town personnel restricted. 
    No official or employee shall use or permit the use of town funds, services, property, equipment or materials except as provided by the laws of the state or the duly established and published ordinances, rules or regulations of the town. No official or employee shall grant any consideration or advantage to any person beyond that which is available to every other person. 
(Ord. No. 124, § 14-104, 11-6-89) 
Sec. 2-485. - Conflict of interest prohibited. 
    No officer, official or employee of the town shall intentionally or with reckless disregard for the particular situation in question engage in an official town capacity in any manner that would create or result in a conflict of interest. The existence of a conflict of interest shall be determined on a case-by-case basis. The person making such determination shall be bound to apply the general standards of reasonableness (as such standards are customarily applied by the courts of the state) to the relevant facts in each particular case as they relate to the criteria set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 124, § 14-105, 11-6-89) 
Sec. 2-486. - Financial interest restricted. 
    No member of the town council or any other officer or employee of the town shall be financially interested, directly or indirectly, either as principal, surety, officer, partner or otherwise, except as a minority stockholder or except as a director in a corporation, in any contract with sales to, purchases from or compensable services made with or rendered with the town. The provisions of this section shall not apply to any contract awarded to the lowest responsible bidder after public advertisement. 
(Ord. No. 124, § 14-106, 11-6-89) 
Sec. 2-487. - Confidential information. 
(a)  Except as may be required by law, no officer, official or employee of the town shall disclose any confidential information concerning the property, government business or affairs of the town, and neither shall he use such confidential information to advance the private financial interest of himself or a close relative or business associate of his, for personal gain, political reasons and/or the economic detriment of the town. 
(b)  No official or employee shall disclose or use any confidential information obtained in an official capacity for the purpose of advancing the financial or personal interest of himself or others. 
(Ord. No. 124, § 14-107, 11-6-89) 
Sec. 2-488. - Acceptance of gifts, gratuities and favors restricted. 
    No officer, official or employee shall accept or solicit for personal gain any improper favor, service or thing of value which may tend to influence him improperly in the discharge of his official duties. 
(Ord. No. 124, § 14-108, 11-6-89) 
Sec. 2-489. - Appearance on behalf of private interests. 
    No officer, official or employee shall render or agree to render for compensation any service to any person or party other than the town, in connection with any cause, proceeding, application or other matter before any town agency on which he is serving or has served within one year prior to the date of any such appearance. This does not prohibit any town official or employee from appearing before any board or commission on such person's own behalf or as official spokesman for an organization of which he is a member, provided such appearance does not violate C.G.S. §§ 8-11 and 8-21 or any other provision of this Code of Ordinances. (C.G.S. §§ 8-11 and 8-21 prohibit any town planning and zoning commission or zoning board of appeals member from appearing before either the town planning and zoning commission or the zoning board of appeals on his own behalf.) 
(Ord. No. 124, § 14-109, 11-6-89) 
Sec. 2-490. - Disclosure of interests required. 
    Disclosure of interests shall be as required by section 1001 of the Charter. 
(Ord. No. 124, § 14-110, 11-6-89) 
Sec. 2-491. - Committee. 
(a)  Established. The council shall appoint a committee of the council to be known as the committee on ethics, which shall consist of three members of the council no more than two of whom shall be members of the same political party. 
(b)  Powers and duties. 
(1)  The committee on ethics established by subsection (a) of this section shall have the power and duty of enforcing this article and section 1001 of the Charter. The committee shall adopt and promulgate reasonable rules and regulations for the administration of this article, which shall be available to any elector of the town upon request to the committee. The committee shall render advisory opinions to the council, to any agency of the town, to any officers or official and employees pursuant to written request or upon its own initiative. Subject to the requirements of The Freedom of Information Act, the committee may, in its discretion, make public opinions it believes will be in the public interest; but no such opinion shall be made public until deletions as may be necessary have been made to prevent disclosure of the identity of the officer, official or employee involved. 
(2)  When an officer, official or employee has doubt as to the applicability of a provision of this article and/or section 1001 of the Charter to any specific situation, he may apply to the committee for an advisory opinion as provided for in subsection (b)(1) of this section and shall be guided thereby. He shall have an opportunity to present his interpretation of the facts at issue and the applicable provision or provisions of this article and/or section 1001 of the Charter, as requested by him, before such advisory opinion is made. 
(Ord. No. 124, § 14-111, 14-112, 11-6-89) 
Sec. 2-492. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  In the event of an alleged violation of section 1001 of the Charter or an alleged violation of any provision of this article by any elected or appointed town officer or official, any member of any town board, agency or commission, or any employee of the town, whether full-time, part-time, permanent or temporary, with the exception of persons holding positions in the classified service as defined in the Charter, with the exception of members of and employees and appointees of the board of education, and with the exception of department heads and the collector of revenue who, under provisions of the Charter, may be appointed and removed by the town manager, full written specifications of the alleged violation shall be sworn to by the person making such charges and duly submitted to the personnel appeals board. Such board shall determine if there exists a prima facie and bona fide alleged violation. If such board adopts a resolution that there exists a prima facie and bona fide alleged violation, the person so charged shall be served with a written notice from the council of the intention of the council to remove such person, containing a clear statement and specifications of the alleged violation and grounds for such removal and of the time and place, not less than ten days after the service of such notice, at which such person shall be given an opportunity to be heard at a hearing thereon by the council. Service shall be made by a county deputy sheriff or a town constable by in-person service or by leaving the notice at the usual place of abode of such person. The deputy sheriff or constable shall endorse on a copy of such notice the time, place and manner of service of notice and file a copy with the council clerk. The service of notice may also be made by depositing such notice in the mail, postage prepaid, certified, return receipt requested, addressee only, to the last known address of such person. At such hearing, which shall be public or private at the option of such person, such person may be represented by counsel, who may cross examine witnesses; and witnesses whose testimony shall be pertinent to the charge shall be subpoenaed by the council at the request of the person charged. Testimony shall be under oath, the hearing shall be recorded on tape, and an official transcript made of the hearing by the council clerk. From the service of notice until final action by the council, the person charged shall be ineligible to perform the duties of his office, position or employment but shall continue to receive his salary or wages pending such final action. Upon completion of the hearing, the council may, by an affirmative vote of at least 80 percent of those eligible to vote, but in no event by less than an affirmative vote of five members of the council, vote either to remove the person charged or censure the person charged. The council shall only vote to censure such person, in lieu of removal, if the council also finds, in accordance with this section, the existence of circumstances that mitigate against the removal of the person charged. From a decision of the council to remove the person charged an appeal shall lie to the superior court for the judicial district of Hartford/New Britain at Hartford, which appeal shall be taken within 30 days of the notification to the person removed of such removal by the council, which notification shall be in the same manner as that provided for notification of the intention to remove such person. 
(b)  If the council votes not to remove or censure such person, or if the council does not vote to remove or censure such person within 14 days of the completion of the hearing, which hearing may be recessed or continued to another date and time no more than seven days from initial hearing, such person shall be reinstated in his original position. 
(Ord. No. 124, § 14-113, 11-6-89) 
Secs. 2-493-2-525. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FINANCE[13] 

Footnotes:
