Chapter 70 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Construction activity, ch. 14, art. III; courts, ch. 30; natural gas waste and oil waste, ch. 50, art. XII; law enforcement, ch. 62; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86; traffic and vehicles, ch. 94. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 70-1-70-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 70-31-70-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LOITERING 

Sec. 70-51. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    To loiter means standing around, moving slowly about, spending time idly, sauntering, delaying, lingering or lagging behind. 
(Code 1978, § 6-700(1)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 70-52. - In public areas. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter on the streets, sidewalks, crosswalks, walks in public parks or any other public area so as to impede and interfere with the use of the street, sidewalk, crosswalk, walk in a public park or other public area by any other person. Any policeman may order any person violating this section to cease and desist from interfering with the right of any other person to use the streets, sidewalks, crosswalks, walks in public parks or any other public area. 
(Code 1978, § 6-700(2)) 
Sec. 70-53. - On school grounds. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter on the grounds or within any building of a school within the town as to in any way impede, interfere with or interrupt the operation of any school or class within such school. Any person in charge of such school or his designee may order any person or persons violating this subsection to immediately quit the premises. 
(Code 1978, § 6-700(3)) 
Sec. 70-54. - On private property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter on private property within the town without lawful business thereon or if ordered to quit the property by the owner thereof or his agent. 
(Code 1978, § 6-700(4)) 
Sec. 70-55. - Penalties. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this article or who ignores or refuses to obey any order given under this article shall be fined not more than $25.00 or imprisoned not more than ten days, or both. 
(Code 1978, § 6-700(5); Ord. No. 94, 10-16-78) 
Secs. 70-56-70-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - AGGRESSIVE OR HAZARDOUS PANHANDLING 

Sec. 70-71. - Definitions. 
    A person acts "recklessly" with respect to a result or to a circumstance described by section 70-57 when the person is aware of and consciously disregards a substantial and unjustifiable risk that such result will occur or that such circumstance exists. The risk must be of such nature and degree that disregarding it constitutes a gross deviation from the standard of conduct that a reasonable person would observe in the situation. 
(Ord. No. 208, 2-16-16, eff. 2-26-16) 
Sec. 70-72. - Unlawful aggressive or hazardous activity. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in one or more of the following activities: 
(a)  Recklessly approaching, speaking to, or following a person in a manner which would cause a reasonable person to fear bodily harm. 
(b)  Recklessly approaching, speaking to, or following a person in a manner which would cause a reasonable person to fear the commission of a criminal act upon such person's property. 
(c)  Touching another person without that person's consent. 
(d)  Recklessly blocking or interfering with the safe passage of a person or vehicle in a way likely to cause bodily harm or property damage. 
(e)  Directing abusive or profane language toward any person. 
(f)  Standing on any roadway or roadway median, including the areas immediately adjacent thereto, previously designated by the town, through its legal traffic authority, as a place where standing is hazardous to the safe travel of persons or traffic. Prior to enforcing the provisions of this subsection (f), a police officer shall first notify the person that the town has designated such roadway or roadway median as a place where standing is hazardous to the safe travel of persons or traffic, and the police officer shall give such person an opportunity to leave the roadway or roadway median. 
(Ord. No. 208, 2-16-16, eff. 2-26-16) 
Sec. 70-73. - Hazardous roadways or roadway medians. 
    The Town of South Windsor, through its legal traffic authority, may designate roadways or roadway medians, including the areas immediately adjacent to said roadway or median, as a place where the presence of pedestrians is hazardous to the safe travel of persons or traffic. The chief of police, acting as the town's legal traffic authority, shall designate roadways or roadway medians, including the areas immediately adjacent to said roadway or median, as to which pedestrian use should be restricted in the interest of public safety. Upon designation of such roadway or median, the chief of police shall submit the same to the town clerk and to the clerk of town council, and said designations shall be posted at the town hall and on the town website. Posting of the same shall be deemed as sufficient notice to the public of said designations. 
(Ord. No. 208, 2-16-16, eff. 2-26-16) 
Sec. 70-74. - Penalties and appeal. 
    A person who violates any provision of section 70-57 shall be fined not more than $90.00, or imprisoned for not more than one day, or both. A person who has been issued a notice of violation may demand a hearing as to the roadway or median designation which was the subject of the violation, if within 15 days after receipt of the issuance of the notice of violation, the individual makes a written demand for a hearing by mailing the demand to the chief of police by certified mail, return receipt requested. The hearing shall be conducted by a board consisting of the chief of police or his/her designee, the town manager or his/her designee, and the director of planning or his/her designee. A hearing, if any, shall be conducted on or before the 30th day after the date of the mailing, publication or service of the notice of violation. The failure of the individual to request a hearing shall constitute a waiver of the right thereto. A decision of the board shall be deemed to have been served on the date a copy thereof has been mailed to the owner by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the address set forth in the notice of violation or to any other address requested by the owner in writing. At the hearing, the individual may contest the propriety of the designation of the roadway or roadway median at issue, including the areas immediately adjacent to said roadway or median, as a place where the presence of pedestrians is hazardous to the safe travel of persons or traffic, the board shall consider the individual's arguments and shall thereafter render its written decision by a majority of those present and voting having applied the criteria set forth in this division. The individual's remedies as to the notice of violation shall be those available to the individual through the superior court. 
(Ord. No. 208, 2-16-16, eff. 2-26-16) 
Secs. 70-75-70-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MINORS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 70-91-70-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CIGARETTE SALES 

Sec. 70-111. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cigarette vending machine means a machine or mechanical device used or intended to be used for purpose of automatically merchandising packaged cigarettes, the operation of which is governed or controlled by the insertion of coins or tokens. 
(Ord. No. 114, § 1, 1-5-87) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 70-112. - Sale restricted. 
    No person shall sell cigarettes or tobacco in any form to any person under 18 years of age. 
(Ord. No. 114, § 2, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 70-113. - Vending machines; notice. 
    Any person who permits cigarette vending machines on his premises shall post or cause to be posted a notice on the machines, of a size not less than three inches by five inches, in the following form: 
By ordinance of the Town of South Windsor, cigarette sales to persons under 18 years of age are prohibited. 
Such persons shall place the notice on cigarette vending machines in a conspicuous place, provided the notice shall not obstruct other notices on the machines or cover the tax stamps on cigarette packages, which must remain visible in accordance with state law. 
(Ord. No. 114, § 3, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 70-114. - Enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the town manager or his designee to enforce the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 114, § 4, 1-5-87) 
Sec. 70-115. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who sells, gives or delivers to any minor under 18 years of age tobacco, unless the minor is delivering or accepting delivery in his capacity as an employee, in any form shall be fined not less than $200.00 for the first offense, $350.00 for a second offense within an 18-month period and not more than $500.00 for each subsequent offense within an 18-month period. 
(b)  Any person less than 18 years of age who purchases or misrepresents his age to purchase tobacco in any form shall be fined not more than $50.00 for the first offense and not less than $50.00 nor more than $100.00 for each subsequent offense. 
(Ord. No. 114, § 5, 1-5-87) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, C.G.S. § 53-344. 
Secs. 70-116-70-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - NUCLEAR CONTROL ZONE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, ch. 50. 

Sec. 70-151. - Findings. 
    This article is necessary for the following reasons: 
(1)  The people of the town have become increasingly aware of the economic consequences of the use of radioactive materials and the disposal of radioactive wastes. 
(2)  The people of the town are well aware of the adverse economic consequences of the actual or potential use, storage and disposal of radioactive materials, including radioactive waste, due to this town's experience during a previous low-level radioactive waste siting process. 
(3)  The people of the town are concerned that the use, storage or disposal of radioactive materials, including radioactive waste, within the town may prove to be a significant detriment to the economic development of the community and an adverse factor on property values within the town. 
(4)  The people of the town are concerned that the disposal and cleanup of radioactive materials, including radioactive waste, could become a significant economic burden to the town. 
(Ord. No. 134, 6-22-95) 
Sec. 70-152. - Establishment. 
    The town is established as a nuclear control zone wherein there shall be no nuclear reactors, experimental or commercial, nor any nuclear fuel reprocessing plants of any kind constructed or operating within the town. 
(Ord. No. 134, 6-22-95) 
Sec. 70-153. - Prohibition on radioactive materials and radioactive waste. 
    No radioactive materials, including but not limited to radioactive wastes, of any kind shall be stored, held, incinerated, treated, processed or disposed of either on a temporary or permanent basis within the boundaries of the town except as provided in section 70-156. 
(Ord. No. 134, 6-22-95) 
Sec. 70-154. - Prohibition on nuclear warheads. 
    No nuclear warheads shall be positioned or manufactured within the town. 
(Ord. No. 134, 6-22-95) 
Sec. 70-155. - Document to be prepared certifying compliance with article. 
    The building department will be responsible for preparing a document certified by industrial/commercial companies seeking a building permit that they conform to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 134, 6-22-95) 
Sec. 70-156. - Exclusions. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to: 
(1)  Limit or prohibit the use of radioactive material in medicine. 
(2)  Regulate the use of radioactive smoke detectors and light-emitting watches or clocks. 
(3)  Prohibit industrial radiography and tracer processes. 
(4)  Prohibit the transmission of electrical energy through the town produced by nuclear energy. 
(5)  Prohibit direct activities of the federal government, or its statutorily created agencies, or its employees. 
(6)  Prohibit in any way the possession or dissemination of any written materials or other expressions of speech protected by the First Amendment of the United States Constitution. 
(7)  Prohibit temporary storage of waste by any medical provider, business entity or research facility located within the town, which waste is a by-product of that entity's business, or research activities, or medical activities in the town, and which waste has not been produced in violation of this article or any other ordinance, regulation or law of the town, the state or the United States. 
(8)  Prohibit the use of radioactive material by any business entity, research facility or medical provider in conducting activities that were engaged in by that business entity, research facility or medical provider as of June 22, 1995. 
(Ord. No. 134, 6-22-95) 
Sec. 70-157. - Penalties. 
    Any person who violates the provisions of this article shall be assessed a civil penalty of not more than $100.00 per day for each day such violation continues. Each violation of this article shall constitute a separate offense. All such civil penalties shall be deposited in the general fund of the town. 
(Ord. No. 134, 6-22-95) 
Secs. 70-158-70-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - WEAPONS 

Sec. 70-191. - Discharge of firearms and other dangerous devices. 
(a)  No person shall discharge a firearm or dangerous device, out-of-doors, within a distance of 500 feet of a dwelling unless such discharge is with the permission of the owners or occupants of all dwellings within 500 feet. 
(b)  No person shall aim and discharge, out-of-doors, a firearm or dangerous device in the direction of a person, building, vehicle or domestic animal within the range of the firearm he is discharging. 
(c)  For the purpose of this section, a dangerous device shall be any air rifle, BB gun, slingshot, crossbow, bow and arrow, or any other device capable of projecting an object with sufficient force so as to cause injury to person or domestic animals or to cause damage to property. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to any person who shall discharge any firearm or dangerous device in reasonable defense of his person or property or in the performance of any legal duty. 
(e)  Any person who shall violate the provisions of this section shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-12. 
(Code 1978, § 5-501) 
Secs. 70-192-70-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - INLAND-WETLANDS AND WATERCOURSES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Inland-wetlands agency, §§ 2-421, 2-422 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 70-201-70-220. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITATION PROCEDURES AND FINES FOR VIOLATIONS 

Sec. 70-221. - Issuing authority. 
    The wetlands agent (wetlands enforcement officer), after making reasonable attempts to resolve or remedy violations of the inland wetlands and watercourses regulations of the Town of South Windsor, is authorized to issue citations for violations of the inland wetlands and watercourses regulations of the Town of South Windsor, to the extent and in the manner provided by this division. Any such citation may be served either by hand delivery or by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the person named in such citation. If the person named in a citation sent by certified mail refuses to accept such mail, the citation may be sent by regular United States mail. The wetlands agent shall file and retain an original or certified copy of the citation. 
(Ord. No. 168, § 1, 3-3-03) 
Sec. 70-222. - Fines. 
    The fine for the first such citation issued to any person with respect to any specific parcel of land shall be $250.00. The fine for the second citation issued to any person with respect to any specific parcel of land shall be $500.00. Subsequent citations issued to any person with respect to any specific parcel of land shall be $1,000.00 for each such citation. All fines shall be made payable to the treasurer of the Town of South Windsor. 
(Ord. No. 168, § 2, 3-3-03) 
Sec. 70-223. - Period an uncontested payment of fine. 
    Any person receiving such a citation shall be allowed a period of 30 days from his or her receipt of the citation to make an uncontested payment of the fine specified in the citation to the treasurer. If the citation has been sent by regular mail pursuant to the provisions of section 70-221 of this division, the day of the receipt of the citation shall be deemed to be three business days after the day of mailing of the citation. 
(Ord. No. 168, § 3, 3-3-03) 
Sec. 70-224. - Notification if fine not timely paid. 
    If a person who has been issued a citation does not make uncontested payment of the fine specified in the citation to the treasurer within the time allowed under section 70-223 of this division, the wetlands agent shall send a notice to the person cited, informing such person: 
(1)  Of the allegations against him or her, the amount of the fines, and the imposition of the administrative fee set forth in section 70-225; 
(2)  That the person cited may contest liability before a hearing officer appointed by the town manager, as provided in section 70-229 of this division, by delivering, in person or by mail, within ten days of the date of the notice, a written demand for a hearing; 
(3)  That if the person cited does not demand such a hearing, an assessment and judgment shall be entered against him or her; and 
(4)  That such judgment may issue without further notice. 
(Ord. No. 168, § 4, 3-3-03) 
Sec. 70-225. - Admission of liability. 
    If the person who is sent notice pursuant to section 70-224 of this division wishes to admit liability for any alleged violation, he or she may, without requesting a hearing, pay the full amount of the fine, together with an additional administrative fee, either in person or by mail, to the wetlands agent. Said administrative fee shall be established by resolution of the inland wetlands agency, with input from the town manager, and amended from time to time as determined by the inland wetlands agency. All fines and fees shall be made payable to the treasurer of the Town of South Windsor. Such payment shall be inadmissible in any proceeding, civil or criminal, to establish the conduct of such person or other person making the payment. Any person who does not deliver or mail written demand for a hearing within ten days of the date of the notice described in section 70-224 of this division shall be deemed to have admitted liability, and the wetlands agent shall certify to the hearing officer that such person has failed to respond. The hearing officer shall thereupon enter and assess the fines and fees provided for by this division and shall follow the procedures set forth in section 70-228 of this division. 
(Ord. No. 168, § 5, 3-3-03) 
Sec. 70-226. - Request for hearing. 
    Any person who requests a hearing shall be given written notice of the date, time and place for the hearing. Such hearing shall be held not less than 15 days nor more than 30 days from the date of the mailing of notice, provided the hearing officer shall grant upon good cause shown any reasonable request by any interested party for postponement or continuance. The presence of the wetlands agent shall be required at the hearing if requested by the person who was issued the citation. A person wishing to contest liability shall appear at the hearing and may present evidence in his or her behalf. The wetlands agent may present evidence on behalf of the municipality. If the person who received the citation fails to appear, the hearing officer may enter an assessment by default against him or her upon a finding of proper notice and liability under the applicable provisions of the inland wetlands and watercourses regulations. The hearing officer may accept written information by mail from the person who received the citation and may determine thereby that the appearance of such person is unnecessary. The hearing officer shall conduct the hearing in the order and form and with such methods of proof as he or she deems fair and appropriate. The rules regarding the admissibility of evidence shall not be strictly applied, but all testimony shall be given under oath or affirmation. The hearing officer shall announce his or her decision at the end of the hearing. If the hearing officer determines that the person who received the citation is not liable, the hearing officer shall dismiss the matter and enter that determination in writing accordingly. If the hearing officer determines that the person who received the citation is liable for the violation, the hearing officer shall forthwith enter and assess the fines against such person as provided by this division, including an additional hearing fee. Said hearing fee shall be established by resolution of the inland wetlands agency, with input from the town manager, and amended from time to time as determined by the inland wetlands agency. 
(Ord. No. 168, § 6, 3-3-03) 
Sec. 70-227. - Compliance. 
    The payment of the assessed fines does not absolve the person from the obligation of complying with the terms of the violation order. 
(Ord. No. 168, § 7, 3-3-03) 
Sec. 70-228. - Notice of assessment. 
    If such assessment is not paid on the date of its entry, the hearing officer shall send by first class mail a notice of the assessment to the person found liable and shall file, not less than thirty days nor more than 12 months after such mailing, a certified copy of the notice of assessment with the clerk of the superior court for geographical area no. 19 in Rockville, together with an entry fee of $8.00 or such other amount as may be required by state law. Further proceedings may then be held pursuant to the applicable provisions of the Connecticut General Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 168, § 8, 3-3-03) 
Sec. 70-229. - Conducting of hearing. 
    The town manager, with input from the town council, shall appoint one or more citation hearing officers to conduct the hearings provided by this division. Neither the wetlands agent, the building inspector, nor any other employee of the Town of South Windsor may be appointed as a hearing officer pursuant to this division. The rate of compensation of the hearing officer, administrative fees, and hearing fees shall be determined by resolution of the inland wetlands agency, with input from the town manager, and may be reviewed and adjusted on an annual basis. 
(Ord. No. 168, § 9, 3-3-03) 
Sec. 70-230. - Issuance of citation. 
    No citation shall be issued pursuant to this division unless: 
(1)  The wetlands agent has provided notice of the violation to the person who would have received the citation; 
(2)  The notice specifies a reasonable time for the violation to be corrected; and 
(3)  The violation is not corrected within the time required. 
The hearing officer shall not uphold the issuance of any citation if he or she determines that the time proved for the violation to be corrected was unreasonable under all of the circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 168, § 10, 3-3-03) 
Chapter 74 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Public pools, ch. 50, art. XI; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 74-1-74-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions, committees, agencies, authorities and councils, § 2-121 et seq. 

Sec. 74-31. - Established; terms. 
    A park and recreation commission is established consisting of ten electors of the town, all of whom shall be appointed by the town council for four-year terms after the initial appointees. 
(Code 1978, § 2-701; Ord. No. 105, 2-14-83; Ord. No. 194, 3-5-12; Ord. No. 200, 3-3-14; Ord. No. 200, Corr., 3-3-14, eff. 3-13-14; Ord. No. 202, 6-9-14) 
Sec. 74-32. - Duties. 
(a)  The park and recreation commission shall, either on its own initiative or in response to specific requests from the town council or the recreation director, make reports or recommendations to the council or the recreation director concerning the initiation, development, maintenance or administration of recreational programs for the town, and the acquisition, development, use and maintenance of public parks, playgrounds, swimming pools or other recreational facilities. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, all recreation related proposals involving the acquisition and/or development of public parks, playgrounds, swimming pools or other recreational facilities shall be referred directly to the park and recreation commission for its review and comment. The commission shall within 60 days thereafter, make its recommendations to the town council in the form of a written advisory report. No formal action shall be taken on the proposed unless and until the town council has received the park and recreation commission's advisory report or the 60 days for commission action has expired, whichever is sooner. 
(Code 1978, § 2-702; Ord. No. 200, 3-3-14; Ord. No. 200, Corr., 3-3-14, eff. 3-13-14) 
Secs. 74-33-74-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONDUCT IN PUBLIC PARKS 

Sec. 74-66. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Director means a person immediately in charge of any park area and its activities, and to whom all park attendants of such area are responsible. 
    Park means a park, reservation, playground, beach, recreation center or any other area in the town, owned or used by the town, and devoted to active or passive recreation. 
    Vehicle means any wheeled conveyance, whether motor powered, animal drawn, or self propelled. The term shall include any trailer in tow of any size, kind or description. Exception is made for baby carriages, wheelchairs, bicycles and vehicles in the service of the town. 
(Code 1978, § 5-601) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 74-67. - Prohibited behavior. 
    No person in a park shall: 
(1)  Mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with, or displace or remove any building, bridges, tables, benches, fireplaces, railings, paving or paving material, water lines or other public utilities or parts or appurtenances thereof, signs, notices or placards whether temporary or permanent, monuments, stakes, posts or other boundary markers, or other structures or equipment, facilities or park property or appurtenances whatsoever, either real or personal. 
(2)  Dig or remove any soil, rock, stones, trees, shrubs or plants; down timber or other wood or materials; or make any excavation by tool, equipment, blasting, or other means or agency. 
(3)  Construct or erect any building or structure of whatever kind, whether permanent or temporary in character, without written permission of the director. 
(4)  Damage, cut, carve, transplant or remove any tree or plant or injure the bark or pick the flowers or seeds of any tree or plant. 
(5)  Climb any tree or walk, stand or sit upon monuments, fountains, railing, fences or upon any other property not designated or customarily used for such purposes. 
(6)  Tie or hitch a horse or other animal to any tree or plant. 
(7)  Hunt, molest, harm, frighten, kill, trap, chase, tease, shoot or throw missiles at any animal or bird. 
(8)  Bring or allow any dog onto park property unless the same is kept in a harness or on a leash, cord, or chain that is a maximum of seven feet in length and of sufficient strength to enable the dog to be under the control of its owner/keeper at all times, who shall maintain control of such dog at all times; or allow any dog to dig up, mutilate, deface or destroy such property, or to bother other users thereof. The owners and/or keepers of all dogs, except dogs guiding the blind or guiding other physically disabled persons, on park property are required to remove defecation therefrom immediately from the property and dispose of same so as not to harm or disturb any property or person. 
(9)  Possess or consume alcoholic beverages at any time; however, nothing in this subsection shall be construed to prohibit the sale, possession or consumption of beer and ale during a special event conducted under a temporary conditional permit issued by the planning and zoning commission pursuant to section 3.17.1 of the zoning regulations and provided further that all necessary permits have been obtained from the state liquor commission; however, the provisions of this subsection (1) shall not apply to the sale, possession or consumption of alcoholic beverages of any kind at the Rotary Pavilion of the Nevers Park provided a permit for same has been obtained from the town manager or his designee pursuant to the regulations for obtaining same promulgated by the town manager, and all applicable regulations of the state department of liquor control have been fulfilled. 
(10)  Appear at any place in a state of nudity, which shall mean devoid of an opaque covering over any one of the following parts of the human anatomy: the genitals, pubic hair, buttocks, natal cleft, perineum, anal region, pubic hair region, or any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola thereof. 
(11)  Build or attempt to build a fire except in such areas and under such regulations as may be designated by the director. No person shall drop, throw or otherwise scatter lighted matches, burning cigarettes or cigars, tobacco paper or other flammable material within any park area or on any highway, road or street abutting or contiguous thereto. 
(12)  Enter an area posted as closed to the public, nor shall any person use or abet the use of any area in violation of posted notices. 
(13)  Gamble or participate in or abet in any game of chance; however, nothing in this subsection shall be construed to prohibit games of chance that award noncash prizes and that are conducted as part of a special event being operated pursuant to a temporary and conditional permit issued by the planning and zoning commission under the provisions of section 3.17.1 of the zoning regulations. 
(14)  Go onto the ice on any of the waters except such areas as are designated as skating fields, and provided a safety signal is displayed. 
(15)  Sleep or protractedly lounge on the seats, benches or other areas, or engage in loud, boisterous, threatening, or obscene, as such term is defined under C.G.S. § 53a-193, language, or any language reasonably calculated to provoke an immediate, violent response from any percipient, or engage in any disorderly conduct or behavior tending to a breach of the public peace. 
(16)  Fail to produce and exhibit any permit from the director he claims to have upon request of any authorized person who shall desire to inspect the same for the purpose of enforcing compliance with any ordinance or rule. 
(17)  Disturb or interfere unreasonably with any person or party occupying any area, or participating in any activity, under the authority of a permit. 
(Code 1978, §§ 5-602, 5-606; Ord. No. 116, 3-16-87; Ord. No. 119, § 5-602, 6-22-87; Ord. No. 154, § 1(3), 2-1-99) 
Sec. 74-68. - Sanitation. 
    No person in a park shall: 
(1)  Throw, discharge or otherwise place or cause to be placed in the waters of any fountain, pond, lake, stream or other body of water in or adjacent to any park or any tributary, stream, storm sewer or drain flowing into such waters, any substance, matter or thing, liquid or solid, that will or may result in the pollution of those waters. 
(2)  Have brought in or dump, deposit or leave any bottles, broken glass, ashes, paper boxes, cans, dirt, rubbish, waste, garbage or refuse, or other trash. No such refuse or trash shall be placed in any waters in or contiguous to any park, or left anywhere on the grounds thereof, but shall be placed in the proper receptacles where these are provided; where receptacles are not so provided, all such rubbish or waste shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere. 
(Code 1978, § 5-603) 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation generally, ch. 50; solid waste, ch. 82; utilities, ch. 98. 
Sec. 74-69. - Traffic. 
    No person in a park shall: 
(1)  Fail to comply with all applicable provisions of the state motor vehicles traffic laws in regard to equipment and operation of vehicles together with such regulations as are contained in this article and other ordinances. 
(2)  Fail to obey all traffic officers and park employees, such persons being hereby authorized and instructed to direct traffic whenever and wherever needed in the parks and on the highways, streets or roads immediately adjacent thereto in accordance with the provisions of this article and such supplementary regulations as may be issued subsequently by the director. 
(3)  Fail to observe carefully all traffic signs indicating speed, direction, caution, stopping or parking, and all others posted for proper control and to safeguard life and property. 
(4)  Ride or drive a vehicle at a rate of speed exceeding ten miles per hour except upon such roads as the traffic authority may designate, by posted signs, for speedier travel. 
(5)  Drive any vehicle on any area except the paved park roads or parking areas, or such other areas as may on occasion be specifically designated as temporary parking areas by the director. 
(6)  Park a vehicle in other than an established or designated parking area, and such use shall be in accordance with the posted directions thereat and with the instructions of any attendant who may be present. 
(7)  Leave a bicycle lying on the ground or paving, or set against trees, or in any place or position where other persons may trip over or be injured by them. 
(Code 1978, § 5-604) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 94. 
Sec. 74-70. - Recreational activities. 
    No person in a park shall: 
(1)  Swim, bathe or wade in any waters or waterways in any park, except in such waters and at such places as are provided therefor, and in compliance with such regulations as are set forth in this article. Nor shall any person frequent any waters or places customarily designated for the purpose of swimming or bathing, or congregate thereat when such activity is prohibited by the director upon a finding that such use of the water would be dangerous or otherwise inadvisable. 
(2)  Frequent any waters or places designated for the purpose of swimming or bathing, or congregate thereat, except between such hours of the day as shall be designated by the director for such purposes for each individual area. 
(3)  Erect, maintain, use or occupy on or in any beach or bathing area any tent, shelter or structure of any kind. 
(4)  Wear a bathing suit in such a manner as to constitute nudity under subsection 74-67(10). 
(5)  Dress or undress on any beach, or in any vehicle, toilet or other place, except in such bathing houses or structures as may be provided for that purpose. 
(6)  Bring into or operate any boat, raft or other watercraft, whether motor powered or not, upon any waters, except at places designated for boating by the director. Such activity shall be in accordance with applicable regulations. 
(7)  Fish in any waters, and whether by the use of hook-and-line, net, trap or other device, except in waters designated by the director for that use and under such regulations and restrictions as have been or may be prescribed by the director. 
(8)  Hunt, trap or pursue wildlife at any time. No person, other than personnel authorized by the director, shall use, carry or possess firearms of any description, or air rifles, spring guns, bow and arrows, slings or any other form of weapons potentially inimical to wildlife and dangerous to human safety, or any instrument that can be loaded with a fire blank cartridge, or any kind of trapping device. Shooting into park areas from beyond park boundaries is forbidden. 
(9)  Picnic or lunch in a place other than those designated for the purpose. Attendants shall have the authority to regulate the activities in such areas when necessary to prevent congestion and to secure the maximum use for the comfort and convenience of all. Visitors shall comply with any directions given to achieve this end. 
(10)  Violate the regulation that use of the individual fireplaces together with tables and benches follows generally the rule of first come, first served. 
(11)  Use any portion of the picnic areas or of any of the buildings or structures therein for the purpose of holding picnics to the exclusion of other persons, nor shall any person use such area and facilities for an unreasonable time if the facilities are crowded. 
(12)  Leave a picnic area before the fire is completely extinguished and before all trash in the nature of boxes, papers, cans, bottles, garbage and other refuse is placed in the disposal receptacles where provided. If no such trash receptacles are available, refuse and trash shall be carried away from the park area by the picnicker to be properly disposed of elsewhere. 
(13)  Take part in or abet the playing of any games involving thrown or otherwise propelled objects such as balls, stones, arrows, javelin or model airplanes except in areas set apart for such forms of recreation. The playing of rough or comparatively dangerous games such as football, baseball and quoits is prohibited except on the fields and courts or areas provided therefor. 
(14)  Ride a horse except on designated bridle trails. Where permitted, horses shall be thoroughly broken and properly restrained and ridden with due care, and shall not be allowed to graze or go unattended, nor shall they be hitched to any rock, tree or shrub. 
(15)  Ride a self-propelled bicycle in a manner contrary to the posted rules below. Biking of a recreational, casual nature is permissible. 
a.  Bikers must ride at a reasonable and safe speed. 
b.  Reckless riding or racing is prohibited. 
c.  Bikers must announce their approach and intentions to pedestrians, and pass to the left when safe to do so. 
d.  Pedestrians have the right-of-way. 
e.  Bikers must comply with C.G.S. § 14-286d(b) mandating safety helmets for riders age 12 and under. 
f.  There shall be only one rider per seat per bicycle. 
g.  Riding is permitted on formal trails and roadways only. 
h.  No riding after dark per subsection 74-67(12). 
(16)  Sled, toboggan or cross-country ski after dusk in any area other than those prescribed. 
(Code 1978, § 5-605) 
Sec. 74-71. - Merchandising, advertising and signs. 
(a)  No person in a park shall: 
(1)  Expose or offer for sale any article or thing, nor shall he station or place any stand, cart or vehicle for the transportation, sale or display of any such article or thing. 
(2)  Announce, advertise or call the public attention in any way to any article or service for sale or hire. 
(3)  Paste, glue, tack or otherwise post any sign, placard, advertisement, or indescription whatever, nor shall any person erect or cause to be erected any sign whatever on any public lands or highways or roads adjacent to a park. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the sale or offering for sale, placement of any stand, cart, tent, temporary structure or vehicle for the transportation, sale or display of any article or thing, the advertising of any article or service for sale or hire or the posting of any sign, placard or advertisement announcing the sale of any service or article, by any regularly licensed concessionaire acting by and under the authority and regulation of the director or by any sponsor of any special event being conducted pursuant to a temporary and conditional permit issued by the planning and zoning commission under the provisions of section 3.17.1 of the zoning regulations. 
(Code 1978, § 5-607) 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 18. 
Sec. 74-72. - Regulations. 
    The director of recreation for the town is authorized to establish reasonable regulations upon approval of the town council wholly consistent with this article to implement and effectuate the intent of this article. 
(Code 1978, § 5-608) 
Sec. 74-73. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this article shall be fined $35.00 for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 119, § 5-610, 6-22-87) 
Chapter 78 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Any ordinance adopting a preliminary plan or development plan saved from repeal, § 1-5(11); administration, ch. 2; planning and zoning commission, § 2-196 et seq.; capital region planning agency, § 2-271 et seq.; agricultural land preservation advisory commission, § 2-396 et seq.; inland-wetlands agency, § 2-421 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; floods, ch. 46; historical preservation, ch. 54; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86; utilities, ch. 98. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 78-1-78-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SUBDIVISION OPEN SPACE USE AND MAINTENANCE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the town saved from repeal, § 1-5(8); sidewalk construction in subdivisions, § 86-90. 

Sec. 78-31. - Purpose. 
    The Town of South Windsor recognizes that subdivision open space is a resource that is intended to benefit both the residents of a subdivision and, because of its status as publicly-owned land, all residents of the town. Town-owned subdivision open space (hereinafter "subdivision open space) generally serves a number of functions, including conservation of natural resources and environmentally sensitive land; screening and buffering of residents from other land uses/developments; preservation of scenic vistas and rural characteristics; and recreational areas. These functions are usually best accomplished through the preservation of subdivision open space in a natural state. The following article, rules and regulations are designed and intended to accomplish the purposes described herein. 
(Ord. No. 136, 4-18-96; Ord. No. 162, 12-6-99) 
Sec. 78-32. - Policy statement. 
(a)  Subdivision open space land shall be preserved in a natural state, and the use of such land shall be limited to appropriate conservation and passive recreational purposes except where otherwise approved by the planning and zoning commission during the subdivision approval process. 
(b)  Subdivision open space properties may only be modified upon approval by the town council following open space task force review and evaluation of a proposal for modification, and after a public hearing on the proposal. 
(c)  The rules and regulations given in this article shall govern use of subdivision open space. 
(Ord. No. 136, 4-18-96; Ord. No. 162, 12-6-99) 
Sec. 78-33. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accessway, public, means a strip of land under town ownership, 50 feet or less in width, which fronts on a public street, is located between side boundaries of two residential lots, and serves as a primary entrance onto a larger parcel of town-owned subdivision open space. 
    Natural state means land that is undisturbed by human intrusions, including but not limited to, construction; filling or excavation; removal or destruction of trees, shrubs or vegetation (live or dead); and activities detrimental to drainage, flood control, water conservation, erosion control, soil conservation or the preservation of wildlife. 
    Open space task force means a council-appointed task force composed of a member from the parks and recreation commission, planning and zoning commission, inland-wetlands agency/conservation commission, agricultural land preservation advisory committee, at least two members of the public, director of public works, superintendent of parks and grounds, director of planning, member of the South Windsor Land Trust, member of the South Windsor Chamber of Commerce, and any other members that the council may appoint. Duties are as assigned by the town council. 
    Recreation, active, means activities that require physical exertion by people and/or cause physical alterations to the land, such as but not limited to exercise walking, sledding, skiing, camping, running and organized group play. 
    Recreation, passive, means minimally intrusive activities that allow the land to remain essentially in its natural state, such as but not limited to nature walks, bird watching. 
    Subdivision open space means any parcel or area of land or water essentially unimproved except under circumstances noted within this article and set aside, dedicated, designated or reserved for public use or enjoyment, acquired through the planning and zoning subdivision process. 
(Ord. No. 136, 4-18-96; Ord. No. 162, 12-6-99) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 78-34. - Prohibited uses. 
(a)  Subdivision open space shall not be used for any of the following: 
(1)  Any action that creates a nuisance, poses a real or immediate threat, or results in damage to or destruction of open space resources or public property. 
(2)  Removal or intentional destruction of existing vegetation (including mowing) or the illegal harvesting or collection of native plant materials for personal use or sale. 
(3)  All forms of hunting, trapping or use of poisonous baits. 
(4)  Motorized vehicle use beyond the limits of established public access roads and designated parking areas. 
(5)  Unrestricted activities of pets such as dogs and/or exotic animals. 
(6)  Horseback riding. 
(7)  Possession/consumption of alcoholic beverages. 
(8)  Any other uses prohibited by municipal, state or federal rule, regulation, law, ordinance or statute. 
(9)  Any other uses similar to uses enumerated in this subsection. 
(b)  The following uses are also prohibited; however, enforcement will occur via the planning and zoning commission zoning regulations: 
(1)  Storage of equipment. 
(2)  Placement of structures, signs or sports/play equipment. 
(3)  Deposition of debris, including grass, leaves, brush, construction debris, refuse, etc. 
(4)  Excavation, filling or regrading. 
(5)  Planting of vegetation, for example, gardens, landscaping. 
(6)  Grazing of livestock. 
(7)  Any other uses similar to uses enumerated in this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 136, 4-18-96; Ord. No. 162, 12-6-99) 
Sec. 78-35. - Hours. 
    Subdivision open space may be used for permitted purposes from one-half hour before sunrise to one-half hour after sunset. 
(Ord. No. 136, 4-18-96; Ord. No. 162, 12-6-99) 
Sec. 78-36. - Enforcement. 
    The commission of any prohibited act as defined within the provisions of this article shall be considered a violation of a town ordinance and any person so violating this article may be subject to a fine of up to $100.00 for each such violation (each date that a violation occurs or continues to occur shall be deemed hereby as a separate violation for the purposes hereof) and the town may further issue a citation for any such violation after giving appropriate notice as provided for pursuant to C.G.S. Ch. 98 as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 136, 4-18-96; Ord. No. 162, 12-6-99) 
Sec. 78-37. - Exceptions. 
(a)  Subdivision open space may only be modified or the uses thereof expanded upon approval by the town council, following review and evaluation by the open space task force and town council public hearing. 
(b)  The following modifications/uses are the only modifications/uses that may be considered for approval: 
(1)  Access improvements, including mowing/maintenance of public accessways by adjoining property owners, subject to hold harmless provisions in section 78-38. 
(2)  Modification of existing/current town maintenance/cultural practices. 
(3)  Walking trails that allow observation of environmental aspects. 
(4)  Seasonal agricultural uses that are consistent with environmental concerns and good land management practices, and consistent with the goals and objectives of this article. This does not include personal, private gardens; see section 78-34(b)(5). 
(5)  Redesignation of open space use from passive to active or from active to passive. 
(Ord. No. 136, 4-18-96; Ord. No. 162, 12-6-99) 
Sec. 78-38. - Hold harmless provision. 
    Any property owner granted permission by the town council to maintain the public accessway portion or to perform limited mowing of any town-owned subdivision open space as provided in this article must sign and have recorded in the town clerk's office a hold harmless agreement in the form provided by the town. The agreement between the town and the property owner shall terminate upon the conveyance of title to the property owned by such property owner abutting the town-owned subdivision open space that is the subject of such hold harmless agreement. Any permission to use a subdivision open space or public accessway pursuant to the approval process described in this article shall expire upon the conveyance of title to the property that is the subject of the hold harmless agreement, requiring the new property owner to reapply for town council approval pursuant to section 78-37. 
(Ord. No. 136, 4-18-96; Ord. No. 162, 12-6-99) 
Secs. 78-39, 78-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ACQUISITION OF CONSERVATION EASEMENTS AND OPEN SPACE PROPERTIES 

Sec. 78-41. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to establish procedures for the acquisition, modification and release of conservation easements granted in the town's favor and procedures for the acceptance and sale or conveyance of open space properties by the Town of South Windsor. The purpose is also to establish a procedure for enforcing conservation easements and creating penalties for the violation of conservation easements. 
(Ord. No. 164, § 1, 7-16-01) 
Sec. 78-42. - Acceptance of conservation easement. 
(a)  All conservation easements granted on behalf of the Town of South Windsor shall be prepared on a form approved by the town attorney and the town agencies responsible for obtaining such easements, namely the town council, the inland wetlands agency (the "IWA") and the planning and zoning commission (the "PZC"). No conservation easement shall become effective unless it has been approved for form by the town attorney and further approved by the town agency responsible for obtaining the easement, whether that agency is the town council, the inland wetlands agency or the planning and zoning commission. 
(b)  After approval by the town agency responsible for obtaining the easement and by the town attorney, the conservation easement shall be executed and recorded on the South Windsor land records. Copies of the recorded conservation easement shall be provided to the town council, the IWA and the PZC as soon after recording as practicable. 
(c)  The IWA is empowered to approve and accept conservation easements on behalf of the town as part of the wetlands permit application process where said easements are related to the protection of on-site wetlands or watercourses pursuant to C.G.S. § 22a-42a(d)(1). 
(d)  The PZC is empowered to approve and accept conservation easements on behalf of the town as part of the approval process for open space subdivisions where said easements are related to the creation or preservation of open space pursuant to C.G.S. § 8-25(a). 
(e)  The town council is empowered to approve and accept all other conservation easements on behalf of the town pursuant to C.G.S. § 7-148(c)(3) and section 305 of the Town Charter. 
(Ord. No. 164, § 2, 7-16-01) 
Sec. 78-43. - Amendment to or modification of conservation easement. 
    The procedure for amending or modifying any conservation easement already in place shall be the same as outlined above in section 78-42 regarding the acceptance of conservation easements. 
(Ord. No. 164, § 3, 7-16-01) 
Sec. 78-44. - Release of conservation easement. 
    An existing conservation easement may be released in whole or in part only upon approval of the town agency initially responsible for obtaining the easement and only after following the procedures outlined in this section. 
(a)  Notice of a possible release of an existing conservation easement shall be given by the town agency which approved said easement (i.e., either the town council, PZC or IWA) to the other two agencies, at least 30 days prior to any actual release of the conservation easement. Said notice shall also be provided within said 30-day period to all owners of property which abuts the property that is subject to the conservation easement. The matter shall be scheduled for a public hearing within said 30-day period, to be conducted by the town agency responsible for obtaining the easement. The other town agencies shall provide input to the town agency conducting the public hearing either prior to or at the public hearing. Public input shall also be invited and received at the public hearing. 
(b)  After said public hearing, the town agency responsible for obtaining the conservation easement may vote to release the easement either in whole or in part and shall instruct the town attorney to prepare and record the necessary documentation for said release. 
(Ord. No. 164, § 4, 7-16-01) 
Sec. 78-45. - Enforcement of conservation easement. 
(a)  Notice of violations. 
(1)  Complaints may be submitted to the wetlands enforcement officer or zoning enforcement officer by members of the public, but such complaints must be in writing and signed on forms provided by the town. Any member of town staff or town board or commission may also initiate complaints. 
(2)  Whenever the wetlands enforcement officer or zoning enforcement officer determines that there has been a violation of any provision of a conservation easement in favor of the town, such officer shall give notice of such violation to the person responsible therefor, as hereinafter provided. Such notice shall: 
a.  Be in writing; 
b.  Set forth the violations of the conservation easement; 
c.  Specify a final date for the correction of any violation; 
d.  Be served upon the owner or the owner's agent, or the occupant as the case may require; provided, such notice shall be deemed to be properly served upon such owner or agent, or upon such occupant, if a copy thereof is posted in a conspicuous place in or about the dwelling affected by this notice; or if such person is served with such notice by any other method authorized or required under the laws of this state; 
e.  Contain an outline of remedial action which, if taken, will affect permanent compliance with the provisions of the conservation easement; and 
f.  State that the penalties and enforcement provisions of this article will become effective on the final date set for the correction of any violation. 
(3)  Any person notified in accordance with this section that fails to correct any violation by the date specified in said notice shall be in violation of this article and subject to its penalties and enforcement procedures. 
(b)  Appeals. Any person notified in accordance with subsection (a) above may appeal said notice of violation(s) to the town agency which accepted the conservation easement on behalf of the town, if either the IWA or PZC. If the conservation easement was accepted on behalf of the town by the town council, said appeal shall be to the conservation commission (the "CC"). Said appeal must be in writing and filed within ten days of the date of the notice of violation. If an appeal is taken as aforesaid, and the appeal is denied, the first day of violation shall be seven days after the decision of the IWA, PZC or CC denying the appeal or on such later date as established by the IWA, PZC or CC. 
(c)  Penalties and enforcement. 
(1)  Penalties: 
a.  Each violation of a conservation easement under this article shall be considered a separate municipal offense. 
b.  Each day any violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
c.  Each separate offense under this article shall be punishable by a fine of $99.00 payable to the Town of South Windsor. 
(2)  Enforcement: 
a.  The wetlands enforcement officer or zoning enforcement officer is authorized to issue a notice of violation for a violation of a conservation easement under this article. 
b.  In addition thereto, the town council, IWA/CC or PZC, as appropriate, are authorized to instruct the town attorney to initiate legal proceedings in the superior court for the immediate correction of any violation(s), collection of any penalties, and the recovery of all costs including costs of remedial action(s) authorized by the court and reasonable attorney's fees incurred by the Town of South Windsor to enforce this article. 
c.  All fines, court costs, costs of remedial action, and attorney's fees, as ordered by the court, shall constitute a lien on the subject premises, provided the owner of said premises has been notified of the violations as herein provided and was made a party to the enforcement proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 164, § 5, 7-16-01) 
Sec. 78-46. - Acceptance of open space properties. 
(a)  All deeds of open space properties conveyed to the Town of South Windsor shall be prepared on a form approved by the IWA, the PZC and the town attorney. No deed for open space shall be effective unless it has first been approved by the IWA or PZC, as appropriate, has been approved for form by the town attorney, and has then been accepted by the town council prior to recording. 
(b)  Prior to approving the conveyance of an open space parcel to the town, the IWA or PZC shall provide the town council with at least 30 days prior notice. If the open space is subdivision open space, then the procedures established in the subdivision regulations for council notification shall be followed. 
(c)  The town council shall notify the IWA or PZC of its concerns, objections or questions regarding the open space parcel within said 30-day period; or in the case of subdivision open space, prior to or at the PZC's public hearing on the subdivision application. 
(d)  The IWA or PZC shall take the input of the town council under advisement and either approve or reject the conveyance of the open space parcel. If the open space parcel is approved, it shall be forwarded to the town council for final approval prior to recording the deed. if approved by the town council, the deed shall be accepted and recorded on the South Windsor land records. If rejected by the town council, the deed shall not be accepted, nor shall it be recorded on the South Windsor land records. 
(Ord. No. 164, § 6, 7-16-01) 
Sec. 78-47. - Conveyance or sale of open space properties. 
    An open space parcel owned by the town may be conveyed or sold only if permitted by the laws and regulations of the United States, the State of Connecticut, and the Town of South Windsor, and only upon approval of the town council after following the procedures outlined in this section. 
(a)  By resolution of the town council, notice of a possible sale or conveyance of an open space parcel shall be given to the body or bodies which approved said open space parcel (i.e., either PZC or IWA), at least 30 days prior to the actual approval of the sale or conveyance by the town council. The matter shall also be scheduled for a public hearing to be conducted by the town council. Either the IWA or PZC shall provide input to the town council prior to or at the public hearing at which the sale or other conveyance is to be considered. 
(b)  At the public hearing, the town council shall receive public input as well as that from affected boards or commission. After said public hearing, the town council may vote to convey or sell an open space parcel if such conveyance or sale is allowed by law, and shall instruct the town attorney to prepare and record the necessary documentation for said sale or conveyance. 
(Ord. No. 164, § 7, 7-16-01) 
Chapter 82 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; floods, ch. 46; health and sanitation, ch. 50; litter, § 50-31 et seq.; sanitation in public parks, § 74-68; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86; utilities, ch. 98. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 82-1-82-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SOLID WASTE DISPOSAL FACILITY 

Sec. 82-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Facility means the solid waste disposal facility. 
    Processing means incinerating, composting, baling, shredding, salvaging, compacting and other processes whereby solid waste characteristics are modified or solid waste quantity is reduced. 
    Recycling means the processing of solid waste to reclaim material therefrom. 
    Resources recovery means the processing of solid wastes in such a way as to produce materials or energy that may be used in manufacturing, agriculture or other processes. 
    Solid waste means unwanted or discarded solid, liquid, semisolid or contained gaseous material, including but not limited to demolition debris, material burned or otherwise processed at a resources recovery facility or incinerator, material processed at a recycling facility and sludges or other residue from a water pollution abatement facility, water supply treatment plant or air pollution control facility. 
    Solid waste container means a receptacle used by any person to store solid waste during the interval between solid waste collections. 
    Solid waste disposal means the placement of material at a location with the intent to leave it at such location indefinitely, or to fail to remove material from a location within 45 days, but does not mean the placement of material required to be recycled under C.G.S. § 22a-241b in a location on the premises of a recycling facility, provided such facility is in compliance with all requirements of state or federal law and any permits required thereunder. 
    Solid waste disposal facility means the location utilized for solid waste disposal and may include a transfer station. 
    Solid waste management means the entire solid waste system of storage, collection, transportation, processing and disposal. 
    Storage means keeping, maintaining or storing solid waste from the time of its production until the time of its collection. 
    Transportation means the transporting of solid waste from the place of collection or processing to a solid waste processing facility or solid waste disposal area. 
(Code 1978, § 5-103; Ord. No. 112, 9-30-85) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 82-32. - Established. 
    The town shall designate one solid waste disposal facility within or without its territorial limits by resolution of the town council upon an affirmative vote of three-quarters of its members. The town council may also designate, by affirmative vote of three-quarters of its members, a transfer station in addition to or in lieu of such aforementioned solid waste disposal facility. 
(Code 1978, § 5-101; Ord. No. 112, 9-30-85) 
Sec. 82-33. - Administration and regulation. 
    Any refuse disposal facility established or maintained within the town shall be administered and controlled by the town manager, who shall promulgate rules and regulations governing the use of the facility so that it is operated and maintained in a safe, efficient and sanitary manner. The rules and regulations shall provide for the hours of operation of the facility, the type and amount of material to be accepted at the facility, the separation of various types of material where applicable, the types of vehicles that will be permitted at the facility, and the means of identifying persons transporting material to the facility and the source of the material. 
(Code 1978, § 5-103; Ord. No. 112, 9-30-85) 
Sec. 82-34. - Prohibited disposal practices. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Dispose of solid waste generated outside the corporate limits of the town at any location within the corporate limits of the town. 
(2)  Dispose of solid waste at any facility or location in the town that is not approved by the town council and the state department of environmental protection. 
(3)  Deposit solid waste in any solid waste container other than his own, without the written consent of the owner of such container. 
(Code 1978, § 5-104; Ord. No. 112, 9-30-85) 
Sec. 82-35. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating the terms of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-12. 
(Code 1978, § 5-105; Ord. No. 112, 9-30-85) 
Secs. 82-36-82-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - REFUSE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate, C.G.S. § 7-148(c)(4)(H). 

Sec. 82-66. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Refuse means trash, rubbish, garbage, industrial wastes, organic wastes, building debris or demolition debris. 
    Refuse collector means any person offering or providing the removal, transportation, collection or storage of refuse as a service to others. 
(Code 1978, § 5-201) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 82-67. - Rules and regulations. 
    The town manager is authorized to promulgate rules and regulations governing the collection, transportation, removal or storage of refuse within the town so that same will be carried out in a safe, efficient and sanitary manner. 
(Code 1978, § 5-206) 
Sec. 82-68. - Permits. 
(a)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any person to act as a refuse collector within the town without first having obtained a permit for each vehicle to be used within the town for the removal, transportation or collection of refuse. 
(b)  Application. Applications for permits shall be filed with the town manager or his designee, on forms approved by him, which forms shall include at least the following: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the applicant's business and the name and telephone number of a responsible person in charge. 
(2)  A brief description of the applicant's business providing enough information to enable the town manager or his designee to determine whether the applicant is qualified to perform the service of a refuse collector adequately and safely. 
(3)  Certificates of insurance showing coverage in force in at least the minimum amounts established by the town manager by regulation. 
(4)  A description of each vehicle to be licensed, including the make, color, registration number, type and size. 
(5)  A map showing the route of each vehicle to be licensed, the number of stops expected on each route, and the registration number of the primary vehicle assigned to each route. 
(c)  Fee. The applicant shall pay to the town a fee in the amount of $200.00 for each permit issued. 
(d)  Length of validity. Each permit shall be valid for a period of one year from the date of issuance. 
(e)  Display. Evidence of a permit shall be displayed conspicuously on the licensed vehicle in a manner prescribed by the town manager. 
(f)  Transferability. Permits issued under this section shall not be transferable except in the event of the permanent replacement of the licensed vehicle. Each refuse collector holding one or more permits from the town shall be entitled to obtain one transferable permit to be utilized on a spare vehicle in the event of loss, destruction, damage or breakdown of a licensed vehicle. The town manager or his designee shall be immediately notified of the intended use of the transferable permit, the reason for its use, the expected duration of its use, the route upon which it will be used, the description of the licensed vehicle being replaced, and the description of the vehicle that will bear the transferable permit. Use of the transferable permit shall be discontinued immediately upon the repair or replacement of the licensed vehicle. 
(g)  Revocation or suspension. In the event of a violation of any of the provisions of this article or any rules or regulations issued pursuant to this article, the town manager shall give written notice to the permittee of the violation, the steps to be taken to correct the violation, and the period of time within which the corrective action must be taken. If the violation is not corrected within the time prescribed, the town manager shall have authority to immediately suspend all permits held by the offending refuse collector. If the permittee thereafter fails to correct the violations, the town manager shall have authority to call and hold a public hearing upon due notice to the permittee and with full opportunity for him to be heard, to determine whether any and all permits should be permanently revoked. 
(Code 1978, §§ 5-202-5-205, 5-207) 
Sec. 82-69. - Violations; penalty. 
    Any person found guilty of violating any of the terms or provisions of this article, or any rules or regulations issued pursuant to this article shall, in addition to the other penalties provided for in this article, be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-12. 
(Code 1978, § 5-208) 
Secs. 82-70-82-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - RECYCLABLE MATERIALS PROGRAM 

Sec. 82-101. - Established. 
(a)  Generally. There is established within the town a program for the separate collection of recyclable materials from all occupants of residential property within an area whose solid waste is or will be collected by or on behalf of the town, including condominiums. This program shall not apply to any apartment complex, commercial or institutional establishments; however, occupants of business, industrial and apartment buildings, and private, public and governmental institutions and buildings shall also engage in recycling as provided in this article. 
(b)  Schedule. Collections of recyclable materials in accordance with this section shall be made in accordance with a schedule of dates to be publicly advertised by the town. 
(c)  Separation of recyclables. All occupants of residential property within the area serviced by the program shall source separate all designated recyclables and place them at the side of the road fronting their residence in the manner described in this article except in the case of condominiums in the manner set forth in regulations established by the town and on the date specified for collection by the schedule published by the town. 
(d)  Materials. Materials designated as recyclables for the program established in accordance with this section shall consist of the following: 
(1)  Newspaper. 
(2)  Glass food containers. 
(3)  Metal food containers. 
(4)  Cardboard. 
(5)  Scrap metal. 
(6)  Car batteries (storage battery). 
(7)  Waste motor oil. 
(8)  Leaves. 
(9)  Nickel-cadmium batteries (rechargeable batteries). 
(10)  Plastics (codes 1 and 2). 
(11)  Mixed paper-magazines, junk mail, office paper, phone books. 
(12)  Other recyclable material as designated by the town following a comment period of at least 30 days and 30 days after designation and publication of notice in a newspaper of general circulation in the area. 
(Ord. No. 125, § I, 9-17-90; Ord. No. 131, 6-14-93) 
Sec. 82-102. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cardboard means corrugated boxes and similar corrugated and craft paper materials that have a minimum of contamination by food, liquid or other material. 
    Commingled means source separated, nonputrescible recyclable materials that have been mixed at the source of generation (i.e., placed in the same container). 
    Designated recyclable materials means those recyclable materials designated by the town to be source separated. The term includes but is not limited to newspaper, glass and metal food containers, car batteries, cardboard, office paper, scrap metal, waste oil and leaves. 
    Glass food container means a glass bottle or jar of any size or shape used to package food or liquid products suitable for human or animal consumption. 
    Hazardous waste means all solvents, acids, pesticides, herbicides, oils, chemicals and other toxic or hazardous materials. 
    Intermediate processing center means a facility that can recycle an item and market or deliver for reuse the resulting material product. 
    Metal food container means an aluminum, bimetal, steel, tin-plated steel, or other metallic can, plate or tray of any size or shape used to package food or liquid products suitable for human or animal consumption. 
    Mixed papers means magazines, coupons, envelopes (with or without cellophane windows), color inserts, junk mail, sweepstakes forms, notebook paper, and phone books from households. 
    Newspaper means used or discarded black and white newsprint of the type distributed daily or weekly that has a minimum of contamination by food or other material. 
    Nickel-cadmium means consumer type (nonindustrial type) small, sealed nickel-cadmium rechargeable batteries from households. 
    Office paper means used or discarded high-grade white paper and manila paper, including but not limited to paper utilized for file folders, tab cards, writing, typing, printing, computer printing, and photocopying, that is suitable for recycling and has a minimum of contamination. 
    Plastics means PET (polyethylene terephthalate) - code 1 and HDPE (high-density polyethylene) - code 2. PET (code 1) is a plastic material lighter in grade than HDPE and is most commonly used to produce up to three-liter soft drink bottles; HDPE (code 2) is a heavier plastic material used in producing milk bottles and the base cups of plastic soft drink containers. 
    Recyclable material means a material that would otherwise become solid waste, which can be separated, collected and processed and returned to economic use in the form of raw materials or products, and shall include the items listed in section 82-103(a)-(c). 
    Recycling means any process by which materials that would otherwise become solid waste are separated, collected and processed, and returned to economic use in the form of raw materials or products. 
    Recycling container means a specifically marked plastic container provided by the town to each dwelling unit in the town that has its refuse collected on part of the townwide municipal refuse and recyclables collection. 
    Resident means any human being residing within the town on a temporary or permanent basis. 
    Scrap metal means used or discarded items made of ferrous metals, aluminum, brass, copper, lead, chromium, tin, nickel or alloys thereof, including but not limited to white goods and metal food containers. 
    Solid waste means all refuse normally placed in containers by occupants of residential, commercial and industrial disposal by the refuse collector of the town. 
    Source separate means to separate recyclable materials from the solid waste stream at the point of waste generation. 
    Storage battery means lead acid batteries or other batteries used in motor vehicles, such as but not limited to automobiles, airplanes, boats, recreational vehicles and tractors. 
    Waste oil means crankcase oil that has been utilized in internal combustion engines. 
    Yard waste means leaves, grass clippings, branches and other vegetative matter. 
(Ord. No. 125, § III, 9-17-90; Ord. No. 131, 6-14-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 82-103. - Separation of recyclable material. 
(a)  It shall be mandatory for all persons who are occupants of residential property, excluding condominiums and apartments, to separate cardboard, glass food containers, metal food containers, newspaper, scrap metal, storage batteries and leaves from all other solid waste generated by such residence for collection and ultimate recycling of that material. 
(b)  It shall be mandatory for all occupants of business and industrial property and of private, public and governmental institutions and buildings (in the case of other than individual occupants, the chief executive officer of the entity occupying the property, institution or building), apartments and condominiums to separate cardboard, glass food containers, metal food containers, newspaper, office paper, scrap metal and leaves from all other solid waste generated by such nonresidential establishments for collection and ultimate recycling of the material. It shall also be mandatory for the occupants or their agents to have the recyclable material collected and disposed of for recycling purposes; except in the case of condominiums, recyclable material shall be collected and disposed of for recycling purposes by the town or its agents as in the case of residential property other than condominiums and apartments provided the applicable condominium association complies with the town's requirements for requests for inclusion, permission to enter property, hold harmless agreements, necessary bylaw changes, and other reasonable requirements by the town. 
(c)  It shall be mandatory for all persons who are occupants of residential property, including condominiums and apartments, to separate nickel-cadmium batteries, plastics (codes 1 and 2), magazines, junk mail, office paper and telephone books from all other solid wastes generated by such residence for collection and ultimate recycling of such material. 
(d)  There shall be added to the list of recyclable materials described in subsections (a)-(c) of this section those items added to the list of recyclable materials contained in C.G.S. § 22a-207 et seq. and the regulations of the state department of environmental protection in accordance therewith. 
(Ord. No. 125, § II, 9-17-90; Ord. No. 131, 6-14-93) 
Sec. 82-104. - Rules and regulations. 
    The town manager or his designee, subject to the approval of the town council, shall establish and promulgate reasonable rules and regulations as to the manner, days and times and charges for the collection, sorting, transportation, sale and/or marketing of recyclable material in order to encourage the recovery of material resources while minimizing the cost of the recycling program. These rules and regulations shall be as mandatory as if set forth in this article, and violation of the rules and regulations shall be deemed a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 125, § IV, 9-17-90) 
Sec. 82-105. - Collection by unauthorized persons prohibited.
