(a)  Recyclable material shall become the property of the town once picked up by the town's authorized agents or employees, or once received at a town designated recycling center if not picked up by the town's authorized agents or employees. 
(b)  It shall be a violation of this article for any person unauthorized by the town to pick up or cause to be picked up recyclable material. Each such collection in violation of this subsection shall constitute a separate and distinct offense punishable as provided in section 82-108. 
(Ord. No. 125, § V, 9-17-90) 
Sec. 82-106. - Preparation of recyclables for collection. 
(a)  All recyclables placed by residents for collection pursuant to the program established in accordance with this article shall be prepared for collection as follows: 
(1)  Uncontaminated newspapers and cardboard shall be separated and placed into the recycling containers provided by the town. Charges for the containers shall be by regulation established by the town. 
(2)  Glass and metal food containers shall be separated from other refuse and placed in the same recycling container. These recyclables shall be rinsed free of food contaminants. The caps, tops and rings of glass food containers shall be removed. The labels shall be removed from the metal containers. 
(3)  Car batteries shall be placed beside the recycling container in a manner to contain any acid therefrom. 
(4)  Scrap metal shall be placed beside the recycling container on a quarterly basis as provided by the schedule published by the town. 
(5)  Waste oil shall be placed in a clean, leakproof capped plastic container beside the recycling container. 
(6)  If the recycling container is not large enough to hold all of the materials to be recycled, any excess shall be stored in standard nonplastic grocery shopping bags or corrugated containers and placed on top of or beside the recycling container. 
(7)  Leaves shall be picked up by the public works department during the fall pickup schedule and shall not be part of the scheduled recyclable pickup program. 
(8)  Nickel-cadmium batteries shall be placed in the recycling container. 
(9)  Plastics shall be placed in the recycling container or shall be stored in standard nonplastic grocery shopping bags or corrugated containers and placed on top of or beside the recycling container. PET plastic containers shall be washed clean and free from other materials (no caps) except paper labels; attached base cups are acceptable. HDPE plastic containers shall be washed clean and free from other materials (no caps) except paper labels. 
(10)  Mixed paper-magazines, junk mail, office paper, phone books-shall be commingled and placed in a standard nonplastic grocery shopping bag or corrugated container separated from all other recyclable materials; the container shall be placed beside the recycling container. 
(b)  All of the provisions of subsection (a) of this section may, from time to time, be modified by the town by a change in the rules and regulations mentioned in section 82-104. 
(Ord. No. 125, § VI, 9-17-90; Ord. No. 131, 6-14-93) 
Sec. 82-107. - Waste haulers. 
(a)  All waste haulers or collectors operating within the town shall notify the town's director of public works of those persons that have discarded recyclable material with other solid waste. 
(b)  No such hauler or collector shall knowingly mix recyclable material with other solid waste. 
(c)  Any waste hauler or collector who violates this section shall be subject to the penalties provided in this article as well as those penalties provided by the general statutes. 
(Ord. No. 125, § VII, 9-17-90) 
Sec. 82-108. - Unlawful acts; violations and penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to combine recyclable material or hazardous wastes with refuse. Refuse that has recyclable material commingled with it shall not be collected, and recyclable material that has refuse commingled with it shall not be collected. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of the resident to properly segregate the uncollected waste and either store or dispose of it. 
(c)  Allowing refuse to accumulate shall subject a resident to a citation for violation of the town sanitary code. 
(d)  Failure to recycle is a violation of this article. 
(e)  The recycling container shall be kept clean and stored in such a location as not to constitute a nuisance or otherwise be objectionable. 
(f)  No person having custody or control of residential premises from which recyclables are collected for disposal by the town shall permit or cause any recyclables within his custody or control to become a hazard to public travel, health or safety, or become a nuisance of any sort. 
(g)  No person shall separate, recover, collect, remove, store or dispose of recyclable material within the town except as specifically authorized by the town or the provisions of this article. 
(h)  No person other than the authorized agents of the town or employees of the town acting in the course of their employment shall collect or pick up or cause to be collected or picked up such recyclable material. Each such collection or pickup in violation of this section shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(i)  Any person found guilty of a violation of any provision of this article or any of the rules and regulations promulgated pursuant hereto shall be guilty of an infraction and shall be fined a sum that is the maximum allowed for an infraction as provided by the general statutes and the fines established pursuant thereto. This article and the regulations pursuant thereto may be enforced by police officers by citations. 
(j)  In addition to any other penalty provided in this article, occupants of business and industrial property that are considered a commercial establishment under the provisions of C.G.S. §§ 22a-220a and 22-241i shall, for violation of this article, be subject to a penalty not to exceed $500.00 for each violation as provided in such statutes. 
(Ord. No. 125, § VIII, 9-17-90) 
Secs. 82-109-82-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CENTRAL CONNECTICUT SOLID WASTE AUTHORITY 

Sec. 82-136. - Statement of purpose. 
    Pursuant to C.G.S. § 7-273aa, which provides that any two or more Connecticut municipalities may, by concurrent ordinances of their legislative bodies, create a regional solid waste authority under the provisions of C.G.S. §§ 7-273aa-7-273oo, inclusive ("C.G.S. ch. 103b"), to jointly manage solid waste and recycling services on behalf of its members, the purpose of this article is to create such a regional authority to be known as the Central Connecticut Solid Waste Authority ("CCSWA"). Upon adoption of this article by two or more municipalities, CCSWA shall be created. 
(Ord. No. 189, 6-21-10) 
Sec. 82-137. - Creation of the regional solid waste authority. 
    CCSWA is hereby created as a regional authority under the provisions of C.G.S. ch. 103b and shall have all the rights, powers, duties and obligations of a regional authority pursuant to C.G.S. ch. 103b and C.G.S. chs. 446d and 446e. 
(Ord. No. 189, 6-21-10) 
Sec. 82-138. - Designation of regional solid waste authority. 
    The Town of South Windsor hereby designates CCSWA as its regional solid waste authority, including its regional resource recovery authority, and adopts the provisions of C.G.S. ch. 103b in connection with this election to become a member of CCSWA; provided, however, that this designation and membership election shall not constitute a commitment of the municipality's solid waste or recycling streams, and provided further that the municipality agrees that it shall take no action, now or in the future, contrary to its currently existing legal obligations and commitments, including without limitation, making any pledge of its municipal solid waste or recycling streams to a disposal or recycling option chosen through CCSWA which has an effective date commencing prior to the expiration date of any currently existing waste stream commitment to another disposal or recycling arrangement. By adopting this article, the municipality shall not be obligated now or in the future to make any such commitment of its solid waste or recycling streams, or to commit any funding toward CCSWA, without further express authorization by its legislative body. 
(Ord. No. 189, 6-21-10) 
Sec. 82-139. - Purpose of the authority. 
    The purpose of CCSWA shall be to solicit and jointly manage solid waste and recycling services on behalf of its members. 
(Ord. No. 189, 6-21-10) 
Sec. 82-140. - Principal address of the authority. 
    The principal address of CCSWA shall be 241 Main Street, Hartford, Connecticut 06106, the Capitol Region Council of Governments. 
(Ord. No. 189, 6-21-10) 
Sec. 82-141. - Members of the authority. 
    The members of CCSWA shall be the municipalities, including the municipality, which adopt this article. Each member municipality shall be assigned to one of four sub-regions of CCSWA: (1) the Northwest Sub-Region, (2) the Naugatuck Valley Sub-Region, (3) the Greater Capitol Sub-Region or (4) the Shoreline Sub-Region. 
(Ord. No. 189, 6-21-10) 
Sec. 82-142. - Voting system for meetings of the authority's full membership. 
    The number of votes to be cast by each municipal member of CCSWA at any meeting of the authority's full membership shall be determined in accordance with the following five-tiered voting system based on the individual population of each municipal member compared to the total population of all CCSWA municipal members (all such population figures to from the most recent annual at published by the Connecticut Department of Public Health): 
(1)  Each municipal member whose individual population is less than one percent of the total population of all CCSWA municipal members shall have one vote; 
(2)  Each municipal member whose individual population is equal to or greater than one percent, but less than two percent, of the total population of all CCSWA municipal members shall have two votes; 
(3)  Each municipal member whose individual population is equal to or greater than two percent, but less than five percent, of the total population of all CCSWA municipal members shall have three votes; 
(4)  Each municipal member whose individual population is equal to or greater than five percent, but less than ten percent, of the total population of all CCSWA municipal members shall have four votes; and 
(5  Each municipal member whose individual population is equal to or greater than ten percent of the total population of all CCSWA municipal members shall have five votes. 
(Ord. No. 189, 6-21-10) 
Sec. 82-143. - Appointment, removal and term of office of a municipal member representative. 
    Each municipal member shall appoint one representative to CCSWA, which shall be the current chief elected official of the municipality or that official's designee, and that representative shall exercise the voting powers established for that municipal member as set forth in this article. As long as the method of appointment and removal and the term of office of each municipal member representative shall be consistent with the first sentence of this section, the details of such appointment, removal and term of office shall be as determined by the appointing municipality; provided, however, that not more than half of the terms of all such municipal representatives shall expire within any one fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 189, 6-21-10) 
Sec. 82-144. - Annual meeting and bylaws of the authority. 
    There shall be at least one annual meeting of all municipal members of CCSWA, to elect the members of the executive committee and enact such other business as shall be deemed advisable at such meeting, all as provided in the bylaws of CCSWA to be adopted after its formation. It shall require the affirmative vote of a majority of all CCSWA municipal members to enact the authority bylaws or adopt any amendments thereto, such vote to take place at a duly-called meeting of the full membership of CCSWA, with proxy voting to be permitted at such meeting. 
(Ord. No. 189, 6-21-10) 
Sec. 82-145. - Prohibition against member monetary compensation other than host community compensation. 
    The members and member representatives of CCSWA shall receive no monetary compensation solely for their service as members and member representatives of CCSWA; provided, however, that the ability of CCSWA, if it chooses to do so in its sole discretion, to pay host community compensation to municipal members which agree to host facilities owned or used by CCSWA within their municipal borders shall not be affected by this prohibition. 
(Ord. No. 189, 6-21-10) 
Sec. 82-146. - Executive committee of the authority. 
    The full membership of CCSWA shall elect an executive committee to manage the operations of CCSWA; provided, however, that the specific division of responsibilities for such management between the executive committee, the full membership of CCSWA and any other body or officer of CCSWA shall be consistent with the bylaws of CCSWA to be adopted after its formation. No member of CCSWA shall have more than one representative on the executive committee, and each member of the executive committee shall have one vote, without regard to the voting system established by section 82-142 of this article for meetings of the authority's full membership. The members of such executive committee shall constitute an odd number, shall include at least one representative of each of the five voting tiers established pursuant to section 82-142 of this article for meetings of the authority's full membership, and shall also be determined by considerations of geographical representation based on the four sub-regions established under section 82-141 of this article, all such matters and the terms of office and appointment of such executive committee members and other matters pertaining thereto to be specifically determined in a manner consistent with the bylaws of CCSWA to be adopted after its formation. 
(Ord. No. 189, 6-21-10) 
Secs. 82-147-82-170. - Reserved. 
Chapter 83 - SPECIAL SERVICES DISTRICTS 
ARTICLE I. - GENERAL 

Sec. 83-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, as used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    "Assessor" means the assessor appointed by the town manager of the town pursuant to section 407 of the Charter. 
    "Board of commissioners" or "board" means the board of commissioners of a special services district established pursuant to this chapter. 
    "Code of Ordinances" means the Code of Ordinances, South Windsor, Connecticut, as amended from time to time. 
    "Commissioner" means a member of a board of commissioners of a special services district. 
    "Connecticut General Statutes" means the General Statutes of Connecticut, Revision of 1958, as amended from time to time. 
    "Fiscal year" means, with respect to a special services district, the same fiscal year as the town as set forth in section 701 of the Town Charter. 
    "Property" means real property within a special services district which is identified in the tax records of the town as a parcel of land and/or building, including an individual condominium unit, planned community unit or separately identified taxable interest in real property. 
    "Property owner" means the individual, corporation, partnership, limited partnership, limited liability partnership, limited liability company, trust, unincorporated association, or other legal entity, or any combination thereof, in whose name(s) title to a taxable interest in real property within a special services district is listed on the land records of the town. 
    "Special services district" means a special services district established by the town pursuant to the SSD Act and this chapter, constituting a body politic and corporate. 
    "SSD Act" means Chapter 105a, Municipal Special Services Districts, §§ 7-339m to 7-339t, inclusive, of the Connecticut General Statutes. 
    "State" means the State of Connecticut. 
    "Taxable interest(s) in real property" means one or more interest in property constituting real estate for purposes of the compilation of the grand list of the town as set out in C.G.S. § 12-64, which is not exempt from property taxes levied by the town pursuant to the provisions of the Connecticut General Statutes, and is located within the boundaries of a special services district established pursuant to this chapter, as those boundaries may be amended from time to time. 
    "Town" means the Town of South Windsor, Connecticut, a political subdivision of the state. 
    "Town Charter" means the Charter of the Town of South Windsor, Connecticut. 
(Ord. No. 191, 4-19-11) 
Sec. 83-2. - Purpose. 
    The town may establish by ordinance of the town council, within its confines, special services districts pursuant to the SSD Act to promote the economic and general welfare of the town's citizens and property owners through the preservation, enhancement, protection and development of the economic health of the town. 
(Ord. No. 191, 4-19-11) 
Sec. 83-3. - Powers. 
    Special services districts established pursuant to this chapter shall have the powers enumerated pursuant to C.G.S. §§ 7-339n and 7-339o of the SSD Act, as amended from time to time, unless otherwise limited by the ordinance establishing the special services district. These powers, as of the date hereof, are as follows: 
(1)  To sue and be sued; 
(2)  To acquire, hold and convey any estate, real or personal; 
(3)  To contract; 
(4)  To borrow money, provided any obligation incurred for this purpose shall be discharged in accordance with the provisions of the ordinance establishing such special services district not more than seven years after it was incurred, and such special services district may pledge any revenues to be received pursuant to section 7-339r of the SSD Act against any such obligation; 
(5)  To recommend to the town council the imposition of a levy upon the taxable interests in real property within such special services district, the revenues from which may be used in carrying out any of the powers of such special services district; 
(6)  To construct, own, operate and maintain public or common improvements; 
(7)  To provide, within such special services district, some or all of the other services which the town is authorized to provide therein (except for elementary or secondary public education services or services then being provided by any multi-town body or authority); 
(8)  To construct, acquire, or obtain leasehold interests in motor vehicle parking facilities, within or without the special services district; 
(9)  To operate a motor vehicle parking facility within or without the special services district; 
(10)  To lease or sublease to other parties motor vehicle parking facilities; and 
(11)  To enter into, fund and perform agreements which reduce the cost of motor vehicle parking to residents of such special services district and to employees of, and those doing business with, businesses located within such special services district. 
(Ord. No. 191, 4-19-11) 
Secs. 83-4-83-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONNECTICUT STUDIOS PROJECT SPECIAL SERVICES DISTRICT 

Sec. 83-11. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, as used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    "Administrator" means the designee of the town for purposes of providing those services to be provided by the administrator herein, in the rate and method of apportionment, or any other document related to the bonds. 
    "Assessed value" means, for each fiscal year, the assessed value of the applicable real property shown on the grand list of the town effective October 1 of the prior fiscal year. 
    "Bond resolution" means the resolution entitled: "A Resolution Appropriating $15,000,000.00 for the Financing of the Connecticut Studios Project and Authorizing the Issuance and Sale of Not Exceeding $15,000,000.00 Special Obligation Revenue Bonds of the Town of South Windsor, Connecticut to Meet Said Appropriation", adopted by the town council on December 6, 2010. 
    "Bonds" means any bonds, including the Series 2011 Bonds, refunding bonds or other debt, whether in one or more series, issued or incurred by the town and secured by the CSP capital facilities special taxes to fund the CSP public infrastructure improvements. 
    "Building square footage" shall have the meaning set forth in the rate and method of apportionment. 
    "Collector of revenue" means the collector of revenue appointed by the town manager of the town pursuant to section 608 of the Town Charter. 
    "Connecticut Studios Project" means: (a) the CSP public infrastructure improvements; (b) the funding of capitalized interest on the Series 2011 Bonds; (c) the funding of a debt service reserve fund for the Series 2011 Bonds; and (d) the payment of certain costs of issuance, administrative expenses and credit enhancement fees, if any, with respect to the Series 2011 Bonds. 
    "CSP capital facilities special tax" means the CSP capital facilities special tax calculated in accordance with the rate and method of apportionment of CSP capital facilities special taxes. 
    "CSP capital facilities special tax levy" means the levy of CSP capital facilities special taxes. 
    "CSP public infrastructure improvements" means roads, public easements, outdoor parking lots, sewers, water lines, utilities, and other supporting infrastructure within the CSP Special Services District, and engineering, management and construction costs related thereto, to be constructed by the town pursuant to the development agreement, and are to be owned by the town or subject to an easement for use by the town, and available to the public for public purposes. 
    "CSP Special Services District" means, for purposes of this article, the Connecticut Studios Project Special Services District established pursuant to the SSD Act and section 83-12 of this article. 
    "CSP special services special tax" means the CSP special services special tax calculated in accordance with the rate and method of apportionment of CSP special services special taxes. 
    "CSP special services special tax levy" means the levy of CSP special services special taxes. 
    "CSP SSD tax levy" means the aggregate of the CSP capital facilities special tax levy and the CSP special services special tax levy. 
    "CSP SSD tax revenue", as used in this article, shall mean the aggregate amount collected from the CSP SSD tax levy. 
    "Date of classification" means the date each year determined by the CSP Special Services District to classify property for purposes of determining the CSP capital facilities special tax for each property. 
    "Developed property" means parcels of taxable property for which a building permit has been issued as of the date of classification that allows the construction of a structure intended for occupancy. Developed property shall be divided into five subcategories: subcategory D-1, subcategory D-2, subcategory D-3, subcategory D-4, and subcategory D-5. 
    "Developer's project" means the development of a motion picture studio, including the acquisition, construction and improvement of all or a portion of the following components: (a) the CSP public infrastructure improvements; (b) four buildings containing nine sound stages totaling approximately 161,600 square feet of space; (c) approximately 103,200 square feet of full-service finished production offices; (d) approximately 73,500 square feet of mill and storage facilities for set and sound stage creation and storage, including 13,575 square feet of television sound stage and 3,750 square feet of commissary space; (e) a 100-150 room business class hotel; (f) four full-service restaurants; and (g) approximately 16,000 square feet of retail space and other facilities. 
    "Development agency" means the South Windsor Development Agency established pursuant to a resolution of the town council adopted September 15, 1997. 
    "Development agreement" means the development agreement, by and between the town and the developer, to provide for the construction of the CSP public infrastructure improvements. 
    "Land use category" means, as the context indicates, one or more of the categories of land use consisting of municipal property, undeveloped property, and developed property (including subcategories thereof). 
    "Municipal property" means any property owned by the town or the CSP Special Services District, or subject to an easement for use by the town or the CSP Special Services District, or that portion of any property which is categorized by the assessor, for property tax purposes, as municipal property exempt from taxation pursuant to C.G.S. § 12-81(4). 
    "Net land area" shall have the meaning set forth in the rate and method of apportionment of CSP capital facilities special taxes. 
    "Rate and method of apportionment of CSP capital facilities special taxes" means the rate and method of apportionment of CSP capital facilities special taxes and the CSP capital facilities special tax report, set forth in Schedule C attached to Ordinance No. 191. 
    "Rate and method of apportionment of CSP special services special taxes" means the rate and method of apportionment of CSP special services special taxes and the CSP special services special tax report, set forth in Schedule D attached to Ordinance No. 191. 
    "Series 2011 Bonds" means the not exceeding $15,000,000.00 aggregate principal amount of bonds designated "Town of South Windsor, Connecticut (acting by and through the South Windsor Development Agency) Special Obligation Revenue Bonds (Connecticut Studios Project), Series 2011", or such other designation as shall be determined for such bonds, to finance the Connecticut Studios Project pursuant to the bond resolution. 
    "Subcategories" means the following subcategories of developed property: subcategory D-1, subcategory D-2, subcategory D-3, subcategory D-4 and subcategory D-5. 
    "Subcategory D-l" means developed property primarily used or intended for use as filming and television sound stage facilities, including complementary office property and any ancillary space thereto. 
    "Subcategory D-2" means developed property primarily used or intended for use as millwork and storage facilities and any ancillary space thereto. 
    "Subcategory D-3" means developed property not classified as subcategory D-l, subcategory D2, subcategory D-4, or subcategory D-5. 
    "Subcategory D-4" means developed property primarily used as restaurants and any ancillary space thereto. 
    "Subcategory D-5" means developed property primarily used or intended for use as hotel facilities and any ancillary space thereto. 
    "Town manager" means the town manager appointed by the town council pursuant to section 402 of the Town Charter. 
    "Undeveloped property" means parcels of taxable property not classified as developed property. 
(Ord. No. 191, 4-19-11) 
Sec. 83-12. - Establishment of Connecticut Studios Project Special Services District. 
(a)  Pursuant to the SSD Act and this chapter, there is hereby established a special services district to be known as the "Connecticut Studios Project Special Services District" (herein, the "CSP Special Services District"). 
(b)  The boundaries of the CSP Special Services District are the same as the Connecticut Studios Project District established pursuant to the bond resolution, as more particularly described in Schedule A attached to Ordinance No. 191. A map of the CSP Special Services District is set forth in Schedule B attached to Ordinance No. 191 and shall be filed in the town offices and shall be recorded upon the land records of the town. Should any question arise as to the precise location of the boundaries of the district, the principles set forth in chapter 86, article V of the Code of Ordinances shall be applied to aid in making such determination. 
(c)  In order to provide that different land use categories and subcategories within the CSP Special Services District share equitably in the costs of the CSP Special Services District in proportion to the different benefits to be derived therefrom, there are hereby established within the CSP Special Services District the following land use categories and subcategories: developed property (including subcategory D-l, subcategory D-2, subcategory D-3, subcategory D-4 and subcategory D-5), municipal property and undeveloped property. All real estate within the CSP Special Services District shall be classified within one of these land use categories or subcategories, if applicable, in accordance with the definitions of those classifications set forth in section 83-11 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 191, 4-19-11) 
Sec. 83-13. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the CSP Special Services District shall be to promote the economic and general welfare of the town's citizens and property owners through the preservation, enhancement, protection and development of the economic health of the town by constructing, operating and maintaining the CSP public infrastructure improvements to support the developer's project. The CSP public infrastructure improvements shall be owned by the town or subject to an easement for use by the town, and available to the public for public purposes. 
(Ord. No. 191, 4-19-11) 
Sec. 83-14. - Powers. 
    The CSP Special Services District shall have all of the powers set forth in section 83-3 of this chapter, except that the CSP public infrastructure improvements shall be owned by the town or subject to an easement for use by the town, and available to the public for public purposes. 
(Ord. No. 191, 4-19-11) 
Sec. 83-15. - Referendum to approve the CSP Special Services District. 
(a)  A referendum shall be held among all property owners in the CSP Special Services District on the question of whether this article shall take effect. The town clerk shall determine the identity of such property owners in the town land records and shall give notice of the referendum to such property owners. 
(b)  The referendum question shall appear on a ballot created by the town clerk. Each ballot shall be accompanied by a copy of the ordinance from which this article is derived and a letter explaining how the ballot is to be cast and identifying the date and time by which the completed ballot must be received by the town clerk. Each ballot shall be signed by the property owner or the duly authorized representative of said owner. The signature of any person signing a ballot in his/her capacity as the duly authorized representative of any property owner shall also attest to his/her authority to sign said ballot under penalties of false statement. 
(c)  In addition to the referendum question, the ballot shall contain an identification of each property owned by the property owner within the CSP Special Services District, the assessed value of said property as shown in the town's grand list as of the first day of October last preceding preparation of the ballot, and the allocation of such assessed value to each of the land use categories and subcategories, if applicable. The town clerk shall prepare and shall post in the town clerk's office, prior to the mailing of said ballots, a list of the property owners within the CSP Special Services District, the assessed value of each property located within the CSP Special Services District, and the allocation of such assessed value to each of the land use categories and subcategories, if applicable. 
(d)  The ballot shall be mailed by certified mail to the address used by the town's assessor for tax purposes by the town clerk not later than 60 days following adoption of this article by the town council. The ballots shall be returned to the town clerk not later than ten days following the mailing of the ballots. 
(e)  Each property owner shall be entitled to cast one ballot for each property which they own within the CSP Special Services District, which will be so counted in determining whether the necessary majority of property owners have voted in favor of the creation of the CSP Special Services District. For the purposes of this section: 
(1)  A tenant in common of any freehold interest in property shall cast a vote equal to his/her fractional ownership interest therein, each of whom shall execute the ballot and note on the ballot such fractional interest owned; 
(2)  A joint tenant of any freehold interest in property shall cast a vote representing an equal fractional ownership interest therein, each of whom shall execute the ballot and note on the ballot such equal fractional interest owned; 
(3)  A corporation shall cast its vote by its chief executive officer of such corporation or his/her authorized agent whose authority to vote shall be noted on the ballot executed on behalf of the entity in question; 
(4)  A partnership, limited partnership, limited liability partnership, limited liability company, trust or other legal entity which is authorized at law to take legal action in its own name, shall cast its vote by its chief executive officer or his/her authorized agent whose authority to vote shall be noted on the ballot executed on behalf of the entity in question; 
(5)  No property owner shall have more than one vote for each property owned; and 
(6)  Any property owner may use an authorized agent to vote on its behalf by executing a notarized affidavit evidencing such authorization. A copy of any such affidavit shall be appended to the ballot which is executed by the authorized agent and delivered to the town clerk. 
(f)  The town clerk shall supervise the referendum and shall certify the results of the referendum. The referendum shall comply, to the extent applicable and practicable, with C.G.S. ch. 145 (Absentee Voting) and ch. 152 (Referenda), except as the SSD Act and the terms of this article may otherwise permit or direct. 
(g)  The referendum shall be approved if: (1) a majority of the property owners within each of the land use categories and subcategories shall respond affirmatively; and (2) property owners within each of the land use categories and subcategories the assessed value of which shall constitute more than one-half of the total of assessed value for all taxable interests in real property within each of the land use categories and subcategories shall respond affirmatively, in accordance with the SSD Act. Fractional interests, if any are noted on the ballots, shall be taken into account in the calculation of the number of property owners within each of the land use categories and subcategories in clause (1) of this paragraph and the assessed value within each of the land use categories and subcategories in clause (2) of this paragraph. 
(h)  No ordinance amending or repealing the provisions of this article shall be effective unless approved in the same manner as the referendum establishing the CSP Special Services District V described in this section. 
(Ord. No. 191, 4-19-11) 
Sec. 83-16. - Addition of land to CSP Special Services District. 
(a)  Any property owner whose real property has at least one boundary adjoining one of the boundaries of the CSP Special Services District (notwithstanding the intervention of a street) as of the date of the request, may request that such real property be incorporated into the CSP Special Services District. Such property owner shall make such request to the board of commissioners. This request must be signed by the property owner or owners, or an authorized agent of such property owner(s), as determined in subsection 83-15(e) of this article. If approved by the board of commissioners, which approval shall be in the board's sole discretion, the board shall prepare an ordinance for approval by the town council amending the ordinance from which this article is derived to add such property to the CSP Special Services District. Upon approval of such ordinance, the town clerk shall conduct a referendum in accordance with section 83-15 of this article requesting the property owners to vote in favor of or against the addition of such property to the CSP Special Services District. 
(b)  The town clerk shall notify the board of commissioners and the assessor of the results of the referendum regarding the addition of property to the CSP Special Services District and record a copy of the written notification and results of the referendum in the land records of the town. The levy imposed on a property incorporated into the CSP Special Services District after its inception shall be at the same rate as that imposed upon all other property in the CSP Special Services District of the same land use category or subcategory, as applicable, but shall be prorated to cover the period from the date upon which such request is granted to the end of the fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 191, 4-19-11) 
Sec. 83-17. - Board of commissioners. 
(a)  There shall be established a board of commissioners of seven members, consisting of six members from the town ("town board members") and one member from the property owners ("property owner board member"). The property owner board member shall have a non-voting alternate member. In addition, the town manager and the director of finance of the town shall sit as ex officio non-voting members of the board. 
(b)  Town board members. The five members appointed to the board of the development agency shall serve as five of the town board members and the mayor shall serve as the sixth town board member of the board of commissioners for the CSP Special Services District, each for terms which shall be coterminous with their terms as members of the development agency and as mayor. The sitting members of the development agency and the mayor as of the effective date of this article shall serve as the initial town board members of the board of commissioners for the remainder of their current appointed and elected terms, respectively. 
(c)  Property owner board member. Individuals who are property owners, or persons entitled to cast a vote on behalf of a property owner pursuant to subsection 83-15(e) of this article, other than authorized agents, may serve as the property owner board member. Ralph A. Palumbo shall serve as the initial property owner board member on the effective date of this article representing the property owners. Anthony Delvicario shall serve as an alternate member representing the property owners. 
(1)  At the annual meeting of each odd numbered year, the property owner board member of the board of commissioners of the CSP Special Services District and one alternate member shall be elected by a plurality vote of property owners present and voting at such annual meeting. Nominations for the property owner board member shall be made at the annual meeting of each odd numbered year. Each property owner (including owners of fractional interests) shall be entitled to nominate a candidate (including themselves) for the property owner board member. Each property owner shall be entitled to cast one ballot for each property which they own within the CSP Special Services District, which will be counted in accordance with the rules provided in subsection 83-15(e) of this article. The candidate receiving the highest vote count shall be elected as the property owner board member. The candidate receiving the second highest vote count shall be elected as the alternate member for the property owner board member, or, if there is no such candidate elected, then the property owner board member shall promptly appoint an alternate member from among the other property owners willing to serve. 
(2)  The term of the property owner board member and alternate member elected to represent the property owners shall commence on the day after the election. The property owner board member and alternate member shall continue to serve respectively as the property owner board member and alternate member until a successor is elected or until such office is terminated in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(3)  If the property owner board member shall for any reason (including, without limitation, such property owner board member ceasing to be a property owner) cease to be able to serve as a property owner board member prior to the end of such commissioner's current term, the alternate member shall become a commissioner for the remainder of such term. If any alternate member shall for any reason cease to be able to serve as an alternate member prior to the end of such alternate member's current term (including, but not limited to, such alternate member filling the property owner board member vacancy or ceasing to be a property owner), the property owner board member shall appoint a new alternate member from among property owners willing to serve for the remainder of such term. If a vacancy occurs among the town board members, such commissioner shall be replaced by the individual appointed or elected to fill such vacancy on the board of the development agency or the office of mayor, as applicable. 
(d)  Within 20 days following the referendum creating the CSP Special Services District, the town clerk shall call the initial meeting of the board to elect officers, establish a schedule for subsequent meetings, and adopt bylaws for the CSP Special Services District, said bylaws to be adopted within 60 days of the first meeting of the board. Officers of the board shall consist of a chairman, a vice-chairman, a treasurer and a secretary and the duties of such officers shall be incorporated into the bylaws when written. 
(e)  The board of commissioners shall be the executive body governing the day-to-day operations of the CSP Special Services District. A quorum of the board shall consist of four voting members, and actions of the board shall be taken by a majority vote of those present and voting at any meeting where a quorum is present. The board shall make administrative decisions and establish or interpret policies of the CSP Special Services District which are consistent with the purpose, intent and powers of the CSP Special Services District. The board may designate such agents, including a district manager and a district clerk, as it deems necessary and advisable to act on its behalf in the conduct of the business of the board. 
(f)  The board of commissioners may hire such staff or consultants considered necessary to perform the duties and carry out the obligations of the CSP Special Services District as approved in the annual budget and may contract with the town to provide such services as it deems advisable. 
(g)  No commissioner shall receive any compensation for service as such, but shall be reimbursed for reasonable expenses incurred on behalf of the CSP Special Services District as determined and approved by the board. 
(h)  Meetings. 
(1)  The board of commissioners shall establish a regular schedule of meetings and provide notice of its regular meetings to the property owners, including dates, times, and places for said meetings, in accordance with the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act, chapter 14 of the Connecticut General Statutes ("FOIA"). 
(2)  The board of commissioners may call special meetings from time to time as necessary to conduct the business of the CSP Special Services District. The board of commissioners shall provide notice of special meetings to property owners setting forth the date, time, place and subject matter of the meeting in accordance with FOIA. 
(3)  There shall be at least one annual meeting of property owners to review the activities of the CSP Special Services District and elect the property owner board member and alternate member (at the annual meeting of each odd numbered year). Said meeting shall be held on any day from January 8th to January 15th of each year, as determined by the board of commissioners. The town clerk shall warn the annual meeting of property owners by publishing a notice thereof in a newspaper having a general circulation in the town not less than five days prior to the date of said meeting. Said meeting shall be conducted in conformance with the provisions of Robert's Rules of Order. 
(Ord. No. 191, 4-19-11) 
Sec. 83-18. - Annual budget. 
(a)  The fiscal year of the CSP Special Services District shall begin on the first day of July and shall end on the last day of June of each calendar year. The first fiscal year of the CSP Special Services District shall commence on the first July 1st following the effective date of this article. 
(b)  The board of commissioners shall prepare and adopt a first budget for the CSP Special Services District as soon as practicable following the effective date of this article for the period beginning on the effective date to June 30, and annually thereafter. Budgets shall include proposed expenditures, revenues and recommended tax levies for the CSP Special Services District. The procedures set forth in subsection (c) of this section shall not apply to the adoption of the first budget, but said procedures shall serve to guide the board of commissioners in the process which it establishes for the adoption of the first budget. 
(c)  Budget procedures. 
(1)  Not later than February 1, the board shall compile, or request the town to have the administrator compile, a report detailing the building square footage for each taxable interest in real property within subcategory D-l, subcategory D-2, subcategory D-3 and subcategory D-4 of developed property, the number of rooms for rent for each taxable interest in real property within subcategory D-5 of developed property, the net land area of each taxable interest in real property of undeveloped property, the assessed value for each taxable interest in real property within each land use category and subcategory, and such other information necessary or desirable to calculate the CSP capital facilities special tax and the CSP special services special tax. 
(2)  Not later than March 1, the board shall compile, or request the town to have the administrator compile, and shall file with the town clerk and mail to each property owner a proposed annual budget, including detailed estimates of the expenditures to be made by the CSP Special Services District, the estimated revenue (other than CSP SSD tax revenue) to be collected by the CSP Special Services District in the ensuing fiscal year, and the estimated CSP capital facilities special tax levy for each land use category and subcategory, if applicable, thereof and the CSP special services special tax levy for each property recommended by the board. 
(3)  The board of commissioners shall schedule and hold one or more public hearings, the first of which shall take place not later than April 1, on the proposed annual budget for the CSP Special Services District for the ensuing fiscal year. The town clerk shall publish notice thereof in a newspaper having a general circulation in the town not less than five days prior to the date of the first of said hearings. At said hearings any property owner shall have an opportunity to be heard regarding appropriations for the ensuing fiscal year. 
(4)  Not later than May 1, the board of commissioners shall, by resolution, adopt a budget for the ensuing fiscal year, including its recommended CSP capital facilities special tax levy for each land use category and subcategory within the CSP Special Services District and its recommended CSP special services special tax levy for each property, as necessary to support the CSP Special Services District's budget, and file the same with the town clerk and the collector of revenue not later than May 15. 
(5)  Under no circumstances shall the budgeted expenditures of the CSP Special Services District for any fiscal year be permitted to exceed budgeted revenues. Any excess of revenues over expenses for a fiscal year may be retained by the CSP Special Services District as a reserve and the board may appropriate such reserve to pay expenses in a subsequent fiscal year. 
(d)  Expenditures in any fiscal year shall be made in accordance with the budget so adopted, or as amended by the board of commissioners from time to time. Should the board of commissioners fail to adopt a budget as set forth above, the most recently adopted budget shall remain in effect for the ensuing fiscal year(s) until a budget is adopted for such fiscal year by the board of commissioners pursuant to the procedures set forth in this section for the adoption of an annual budget. 
(Ord. No. 191, 4-19-11) 
Sec. 83-19. - CSP SSD taxation. 
(a)  The CSP capital facilities special tax levy imposed upon each taxable interest in real property in the CSP Special Services District shall be determined in accordance with the rate and method of apportionment of CSP capital facilities special taxes. The CSP special services special tax levy imposed upon each taxable interest in real property in the CSP Special Services District shall be determined in accordance with the rate and method of apportionment of CSP special services special taxes. 
(b)  The CSP capital facilities special tax levy and the CSP special services special tax levy imposed upon each taxable interest in real property in the CSP Special Services District shall be subject to adjustment if the CSP Special Services District is expanded in accordance with the terms of section 83-16 of this article. 
(c)  Municipal property and other land uses exempt from property taxation pursuant to any applicable provision of law shall not be subject to the CSP capital facilities special tax levy or the CSP special services special tax levy imposed by this article. 
(d)  Any common area within a building which serves more than one subcategory shall be classified as belonging to that subcategory which otherwise occupies the greatest portion of the floor area on the floor upon which said common area is located, as determined by the board of commissioners in their sole discretion. 
(e)  The CSP capital facilities special tax levy and the CSP special services special tax levy shall be due and payable in two equal installments, due on or before July 1 and January 1 in the same manner as property tax bills of the town. Each year the collector of revenue of the town shall, accordingly, provide property owners with statements detailing the amount of their CSP capital facilities special tax levy and CSP special services special tax levy and the semiannual installment amounts. Said statements may be provided with or incorporated into the property tax bills of the town. Delinquent charges shall be assessed on late CSP capital facilities special tax levy and the CSP special services special tax levy payments and shall be computed in the same manner used for establishing delinquent charges on property tax bills of the town. The board, with the approval of the town manager, may also provide for a different manner and different time of collection for the CSP capital facilities special tax levy or the CSP special services special tax levy. In the event of a projected shortfall of revenues to pay expenses, the board may impose an additional CSP capital facilities special tax levy and/or CSP special services special tax levy to make up such shortfall, which shall be due and payable on such date or dates as may be established by the board. 
(f)  It shall be an obligation of the town to impose the CSP capital facilities special tax levy and the CSP special services special tax levy recommended by the board as municipal levies, in addition to the regular town levy, and to collect the revenues accruing therefrom pursuant to the SSD Act. All moneys, including but not limited to, levies or any income, proceeds or fees issuing from the provision of services by the CSP Special Services District or other business conducted by the CSP Special Services District, received by the board or by the town on behalf of the CSP Special Services District shall be paid into the general fund of the town. 
    The town shall create and maintain two funds for the receipt of all moneys for the benefit of the CSP Special Services District: the "CSP capital facilities special tax fund" and the "CSP special services special tax fund". All receipts from the CSP capital facilities special tax levy shall be immediately deposited in the CSP capital facilities special tax fund. All receipts from the CSP special services special tax levy and all other receipts, moneys, income and other revenues from any other source shall be immediately deposited in the CSP special services special tax fund. The treasurer of the town shall disburse such moneys in accordance with an annual budget for the CSP Special Services District adopted by the board. The treasurer of the town shall disburse moneys from such accounts to the CSP Special Services District (or to the town for amounts payable to the town from such funds) upon written request of a duly authorized representative of the CSP Special Services District, and only upon such request in accordance with the then current approved budget of the board of commissioners of the CSP Special Services District. The CSP Special Services District shall set forth in its bylaws the procedures for approving disbursement of funds and requesting disbursement from the town treasurer. 
(g)  For purposes of the CSP capital facilities special tax levy to be implemented pursuant to this article, all areas within a building and which constitute a subcategory of developed property shall be deemed a taxable interest in real property within such respective subcategory based upon the intended use of such area upon issuance of the building permit by the building official of the town covering such area of the building. Thereafter, all such areas shall remain taxable interests in real property within such respective subcategory regardless of occupancy until a building permit for use as a different subcategory for such area is issued. All property which constitutes an undeveloped property shall be deemed a taxable interest in real property. 
(Ord. No. 191, 4-19-11) 
Sec. 83-20. - Expenditures and financial reporting. 
(a)  All orders or contracts for expenditures by the board of commissioners or its agents on behalf of the CSP Special Services District which are greater than $5,000.00 shall be awarded to the lowest responsible qualified bidder only after a public invitation to bid, which shall be advertised in a newspaper having circulation in the CSP Special Services District. 
(b)  The board of commissioners shall have an independent financial audit of the CSP Special Services District's financial affairs conducted by a certified public accountant before March 1 following the end of each fiscal year. Said audit shall be performed in accordance with the provisions of C.G.S. ch. 111, (Municipal Auditing Act). A copy of the audit shall be forwarded to the town manager and the town clerk and upon request, any property owner. Said audit may be conducted in conjunction with an independent audit of the town's financial affairs. 
(Ord. No. 191, 4-19-11) 
Sec. 83-21. - Municipal service agreements. 
    The town may enter into contracts with the CSP Special Services District in accordance with section 7-339t of the SSD Act in which the town is excused from providing to the CSP Special Services District some or all of the services which the CSP Special Services District is authorized to provide pursuant to this article and in which the CSP Special Services District agrees to provide all such services from which the town has been excused. The town and the CSP Special Services District may also enter into contracts in accordance with section 7-339t of the SSD Act in which the CSP Special Services District may obtain from the town some or all of the services for which the CSP Special Services District has become responsible. Any contracts executed pursuant to this section shall not be subject to the requirements of subsection 83-20(a) of this article. 
(Ord. No. 191, 4-19-11) 
Sec. 83-22. - Dissolution of CSP Special Services District. 
(a)  The CSP Special Services District may be dissolved by an ordinance repealing this article or after a referendum is conducted by the board of commissioners among all property owners within the CSP Special Services District on the question of whether the CSP Special Services District shall be dissolved, in which event, such referendum shall be conducted, and the outcome determined, in the same manner as the referendum establishing the CSP Special Services District described in section 83-15 of this article. 
(b)  In the event the CSP Special Services District is dissolved, the board of commissioners shall proceed to wind up the affairs of the CSP Special Services District as of the end of the current fiscal year. If, after dissolution of the CSP Special Services District, there are outstanding liabilities or obligations, whether fixed or contingent, the town council may continue to impose, in addition to the regular municipal levy, the CSP capital facilities special tax levy, the CSP special services special tax levy, or another levy on the taxable interests in real property within such CSP Special Services District pursuant to section 7-339s of the SSD Act for as many years as such liabilities remain outstanding. For purposes of this section, the obligations of the CSP Special Services District pursuant to any municipal service agreements, contracts or other agreements between the CSP Special Services District and the town shall be deemed to be outstanding liabilities or obligations and the town council may impose such an additional levy as is necessary to fulfill the obligations of the CSP Special Services District to the town pursuant to any such agreements for the remainder of their original term(s). Any levy imposed by the town council pursuant to this section shall be calculated to produce sufficient revenues to satisfy and release all liabilities and/or obligations of the CSP Special Services District as they become due but shall otherwise be subject to any limitations set forth in this article. The revenues collected shall be deposited into the general fund of the town and disbursed solely for the purposes stated herein. If, after dissolution of the CSP Special Services District, there are assets which remain following the winding up of the affairs of the CSP Special Services District, such assets shall be transferred to the town. 
(Ord. No. 191, 4-19-11) 
Sec. 83-23. - Property of the CSP Special Services District. 
    All taxable interests in real property and all personal property owned by the CSP Special Services District shall not be subject to any property tax levied by the town. 
(Ord. No. 191, 4-19-11) 
Sec. 83-24. - Effective date. 
    The provisions of this article shall take effect upon the issuance of the Series 2011 Bonds by the town (as such issuance date may be extended by amendment of the bond resolution) following the approval of the establishment of the CSP Special Services District at a referendum held in accordance with the provisions of section 83-15 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 191, 4-19-11) 
Secs. 83-25-83-50. - Reserved. 
Chapter 86 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance accepting, dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening or vacating any street or public way in the town saved from repeal, § 1-5(5); any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades of any street in the town saved from repeal, § 1-5(6); any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor saved from repeal, § 1-5(7); public building commission, § 2-171 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; peddlers, § 18-31 et seq.; cemeteries, ch. 22; floods, ch. 46; health and sanitation, ch. 50; natural gas waste and oil waste, ch. 50, art. XII; library, ch. 66; parks and recreation, ch. 74; planning, ch. 78; solid waste, ch. 82; traffic and vehicles, ch. 94; utilities, ch. 98. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 86-1. - Fires within public highways. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to build or attempt to build a fire within the limits of any public highway, road or way. 
(b)  Any person who violates this section shall be fined not more than $35.00 for each such offense. 
(Code 1978, § 6-600) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 42. 
Secs. 86-2-86-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OBSTRUCTIONS, EXCAVATIONS AND DRIVEWAYS 

Sec. 86-31. - Scope and purpose. 
    It is the purpose of this article to regulate the making of openings or placing of obstructions within the limits of public highways, including openings in curbs and sidewalks and the installation of driveways, and to establish responsibility for such excavations and obstructions until they are restored or removed. 
(Code 1978, § 6-101; Ord. No. 132, 7-25-94; Ord. No. 217, 8-7-17) 
Sec. 86-32. - Permit required. 
    Except as otherwise provided, no persons, public utility or public agency other than the town or its agent shall excavate any part of any street or highway under the control of or maintained by the town, or dig below the surface thereof, or place any obstruction thereon, or construct a driveway entrance from any street, without first obtaining a permit therefor from the director of public works or his authorized representative. For emergency utility repairs, see section 86-45(b). 
(Code 1978, § 6-102; Ord. No. 132, 7-25-94; Ord. No. 217, 8-7-17) 
Sec. 86-33. - Application for permit. 
    No permit required by section 86-32 shall be issued until after receipt of an application, to be made in writing on forms provided by the director of public works and signed by the applicant or his authorized representative. 
(Code 1978, § 6-103; Ord. No. 132, 7-25-94; Ord. No. 217, 8-7-17) 
Sec. 86-34. - Surety bond. 
    No permit required by section 86-32 shall be issued until after the applicant has deposited with the town a surety bond guaranteeing that any excavation made under such permit will be restored without cost to the town. Such bond shall be in an amount and for a period of time determined to be appropriate by the director of public works and shall be issued by a surety company licensed to do business in and having a place of business in the state. The director of public works shall prepare reasonable rules governing the application of this section, and in the case of any governmental agency or public service company as defined in the general statutes, such rules may provide for the acceptance of any legally binding agreement in lieu of a surety bond as aforesaid. 
(Code 1978, § 6-104; Ord. No. 132, 7-25-94; Ord. No. 217, 8-7-17) 
Sec. 86-35. - Liability insurance. 
    No permit required by section 86-32 shall be issued until after the applicant has filed with the town a certificate of insurance showing limits of liability equal to or exceeding the coverage carried by the town conditioned substantially that the applicant shall indemnify and save harmless the town, its officers and employees and the director of public works and his agents, from all suits and actions of every name and description brought against the town, or any officer or employee of the town for or on account of any injuries or damages received or sustained by any person in consequence of or resulting from any work performed by the applicant, his servants or agents, or of or from any act or omission of the applicant, his servants or agents. 
(Code 1978, § 6-105; Ord. No. 132, 7-25-94; Ord. No. 217, 8-7-17) 
Sec. 86-36. - Fee for permit. 
    Every permittee shall pay a fee for permits issued under the provisions of this article. Fee schedule shall be set by the town council. 
(Code 1978, § 6-106; Ord. No. 132, 7-25-94; Ord. No. 217, 8-7-17) 
Sec. 86-37. - Fee for permanent patching. 
    The fee for the permanent patching of the roadway shall be collected prior to issuance of a permit. This fee shall be based upon the estimated size of the patch and upon the estimated costs developed by the director of public works or his agents. A minimum fee shall be established by the director for uses in situations where a per-square-foot charge does not reflect actual costs. These costs shall be updated periodically at least once a year. 
(Code 1978, § 6-106a; Ord. No. 132, 7-25-94; Ord. No. 217, 8-7-17) 
Sec. 86-38. - Additional fee. 
    If after the permittee has completed the work of permanent patching and it is determined that the size of the patch is larger than that estimated, an additional fee shall be collected from the permittee. If the actual cost of the permanent patch exceeds the fee collected from the permittee, the permittee will be billed the difference in costs. If the actual cost is less than that collected from the permittee, the permittee will be reimbursed the difference in costs. 
(Code 1978, § 6-106c; Ord. No. 132, 7-25-94; Ord. No. 217, 8-7-17) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 217, adopted Aug. 7, 2017, repealed § 86-38, which pertained to exemption from fee and derived from the Code of 1978, § 6-106b; Ord. No. 132, adopted July 25, 1994, and renumbered Secs. 86-39-86-48 as Secs. 86-38-86-47. 
Sec. 86-39. - Issuance of permit. 
    Upon the filing of an application, payment of permanent patch deposit, and payment of the required application fee, the director of public works shall cause to be issued, on forms provided by him, a permit specifying the nature and location of the work to be done; the terms and conditions of such work, which terms and conditions shall be based upon the requirements of the public welfare and safety; and the time within which the work is to be completed, which shall not be longer than one year from the date of the permit. Notwithstanding such other conditions as may be imposed, or any provision contained herein to the contrary, it shall be a condition of each permit issued under this article that the permittee shall for a period of one year from the date of completion of work of such permit, unless sooner released from this condition over the written signature of the director of public works or his authorized representative or until the town constructs or causes to be constructed the permanent roadway patch, save harmless the town from all claims for penalties and damages arising from or in consequence of any work performed by or any act or omission of the applicant under such permit. 
(Code 1978, § 6-107; Ord. No. 132, 7-25-94; Ord. No. 217, 8-7-17) 
Sec. 86-40. - Expiration of permit. 
    Permits issued under the provisions of this article shall expire in accordance with the following conditions: 
(1)  Upon completion of all work specified on the permit, including the restoration of any excavation, the removal of any obstruction and temporary roadway patch, the permittee may present his permit to the director of public works or his authorized representative, who shall cause such work to be inspected and, if the work has been completed to his satisfaction, and in accordance with the terms and conditions of the permit, shall certify thereon as to the completion of the work and the expiration of the permit. 
(2)  Expiration of the permit shall not be deemed to imply that the permittee is released of the obligation to maintain the work. The permittee is responsible to maintain the temporary roadway patch until a permanent patch is in place. 
(3)  The installation of the permanent roadway patch shall not relieve the permittee of his obligation if after the permanent roadway patch is installed it fails and it is proven that failure was a result of the work done by the permittee. 
(Code 1978, § 6-108; Ord. No. 132, 7-25-94; Ord. No. 217, 8-7-17) 
Sec. 86-41. - Inspection by director. 
(a)  The director of public works or his authorized representative is empowered to inspect, or cause to have inspected, at any time any or all work being performed under a permit issued under the provisions of this article. 
(b)  If in the opinion of the director the public safety and welfare so warrant, or if the work is not satisfactory or not in accordance with town standards, he may direct the permittee to restore any excavation or remove any obstruction within 12 hours of such notice; and, if such excavation is not restored or such obstruction removed within that period, he may cause such work to be done, and the permittee shall be responsible for the full expense of such work. 
(Code 1978, § 6-109; Ord. No. 132, 7-25-94; Ord. No. 217, 8-7-17) 
Sec. 86-42. - Requirements for pavement patching. 
    The minimum requirements for temporary and permanent patching shall be as specified in the street cut permit manual, which shall be provided with the street cut application form. 
(Code 1978, § 6-109a; Ord. No. 132, 7-25-94; Ord. No. 217, 8-7-17) 
Sec. 86-43. - Other requirements. 
(a)  The permittee shall be responsible to repair or replace any damage caused by the permittee or his assigns to existing sidewalks, curbs, yards, mailboxes and any other such existing aperture or property. These shall be replaced or repaired in as good a condition as they were before being disturbed. 
(b)  The permittee shall be responsible for following additional technical and detailed requirements as enumerated in the street cut permit manual, which shall be provided with the street cut application form. 
(Code 1978, § 6-109b; Ord. No. 132, 7-25-94; Ord. No. 217, 8-7-17) 
Sec. 86-44. - Exceptions. 
(a)  None of the other provisions of this article shall apply to any work performed in connection with the installation, maintenance, repair, replacement or relocation of utility poles owned by any public service company, nor to the erection of any temporary protection warning signs or devices. 
(b)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to prevent or unduly delay the making of any necessary excavation of the performance of any work related thereto by any public service company in the event of any emergency; and in such cases such public service company may proceed with such work without regard for the provisions of this article provided that within a reasonable period of time after the cessation of such emergency, and not longer than five days, all provisions of this article shall become effective with respect to such work. 
(Code 1978, § 6-110; Ord. No. 132, 7-25-94; Ord. No. 217, 8-7-17) 
Sec. 86-45. - Conflicts. 
    The permit required by section 86-32 shall not be construed as giving permission to perform any work that conflicts with or is expressly forbidden by any planning and zoning, inland-wetlands agency/conservation commission or water pollution control authority approvals. All such approvals shall govern. 
(Code 1978, § 6-110a; Ord. No. 132, 7-25-94; Ord. No. 217, 8-7-17) 
Sec. 86-46. - Legal obligations. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to relieve any permittee from any obligations or liabilities of the town or to any other parties that may be imposed upon him by law. 
(Code 1978, § 6-111; Ord. No. 132, 7-25-94; Ord. No. 217, 8-7-17) 
Sec. 86-47. - Penalty. 
(a)  Violation of this article shall be an infraction as provided for in C.G.S. §§ 51-164m and 51-164n, as the same may be modified from time to time. 
(b)  A fine of $250.00 per day shall be assessed for each violation, and each day such violation continues shall be deemed to be a separate offense. 
(Code 1978, § 6-112; Ord. No. 132, 7-25-94; Ord. No. 217, 8-7-17) 
Secs. 86-48-86-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 86-81. - Existing sidewalks-Inspection. 
    Annually, or at more frequent intervals, the town manager may cause all existing sidewalks fronting on town roads to be inspected to determine whether any such sidewalk or any part thereof is in need of repair or replacement in order to make it safe for public travel. 
(Code 1978, § 6-401; Ord. No. 115, 3-2-87; Ord. No. 197, 10-15-12) 
Sec. 86-82. - Notice to abutting landowners. 
    Whenever an abutting landowner or occupant, or agent thereof, directly or indirectly, willfully or negligently, causes damage to a public sidewalk and the town manager determines it is in need of repair or replacement, he shall notify the owner of the land abutting thereon by letter sent to his last known address to repair or replace the same within 20 days of the date of the sending of the letter. Such repairs shall be made with materials of a type, style and dimension as may be prescribed by the town manager for the purpose, so far as possible, of restoring the sidewalk to its original condition. For good cause shown, the town manager may extend the period allowed to repair or replace a sidewalk. 
(Code 1978, § 6-402; Ord. No. 115, 3-2-87; Ord. No. 197, 10-15-12) 
Sec. 86-83. - Refusal to repair; bill of costs. 
    If the owner of any premises abutting on any town road refuses or neglects to repair or replace a sidewalk or any part thereof as ordered by the town manager within 20 days of the mailing of an order to him, or within any extension period granted to him for such work, it shall be the duty of the town manager to have the same repaired or replaced at the expense of the owner; and the town manager may engage an independent contractor to do the work. A bill for all costs incurred by the town to repair or replace a sidewalk pursuant to this section shall be presented to the property owner in the manner described in subsection 86-86(b) and must be paid in full within 60 days thereof unless extended for good cause by the town manager. 
(Code 1978, § 6-403; Ord. No. 115, 3-2-87; Ord. No. 197, 10-15-12) 
Sec. 86-84. - Lien. 
    The town manager shall deliver to the collector of revenue any unpaid and overdue bill for the costs of any repair or replacement of any sidewalk or part thereof performed in accordance with section 86-83. This cost plus interest at the interest rate charged for overdue personal property taxes from the date of the repairs or replacement shall be assessed against and remain a lien in favor of the town upon the premises abutting the sidewalk so repaired or replaced until paid, provided that the town manager also lodges with the town clerk for record, within 60 days from the date that payment was due, a certificate signed by him describing the premises, the amount assessed, and the repair or replacement work performed. Notice of the lien shall be given to the property owner within the same 60 days in the manner described in subsection 86-86(b). This lien may be foreclosed in the manner provided by law for foreclosure of tax liens. 
(Code 1978, § 6-404; Ord. No. 115, 3-2-87; Ord. No. 197, 10-15-12) 
Sec. 86-85. - New sidewalks-Construction. 
    The town council may, upon finding after hearing before it that it will serve public necessity and convenience, authorize the town manager to install along all or part of any street or highway in the town sidewalks in accordance with the town's standard sidewalk specifications as set forth by the town engineering department. The town manager is authorized to acquire such slope rights, easements and/or rights-of-way, by eminent domain proceedings if necessary, as shall be necessary to accomplish such sidewalk installation. 
(Code 1978, § 6-405; Ord. No. 115, 3-2-87; Ord. No. 197, 10-15-12) 
Sec. 86-86. - Hearing. 
(a)  At least 15 days before making such an authorization for installation, the town council shall cause notice of the time and place of a hearing relating to the same to be given the owner of property abutting the proposed sidewalks prior to the date of such hearing, by mailing a copy of the notice of the hearing by certified mail to the owner of abutting property or by causing a copy of the notice to be placed in their hands. 
(b)  Notice that such authorization has been made shall be given to the owner of the land abutting the proposed sidewalks promptly after the same has been made by mailing a copy of the authorization by certified mail to the last known address of such owner, or causing a copy of the authorization to be placed in the hands of such owner or left at his usual place of abode. 
(Code 1978, §§ 6-406, 6-407; Ord. No. 115, 3-2-87; Ord. No. 197, 10-15-12) 
Sec. 86-87. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 197, adopted Oct. 15, 2012, repealed § 86-87, entitled "Assessment", which derived from: Code 1978, § 6-408; and Ord. No. 115, adopted Mar. 2, 1987. 
Sec. 86-88. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 197, adopted Oct. 15, 2012, repealed § 86-88, entitled "Lien", which derived from: Code 1978, § 6-409; and Ord. No. 115, adopted Mar. 2, 1987. 
Sec. 86-89. - Appeal. 
    Any owner aggrieved by any assessment or fine made or given pursuant to this article III may appeal thereupon to the Superior Court of the Judicial District of Hartford within 20 days of any notice described in this article. 
(Code 1978, § 6-410; Ord. No. 115, 3-2-87; Ord. No. 197, 10-15-12) 
Sec. 86-90. - Sidewalk construction in subdivisions. 
    The provisions of this article referring to the construction of sidewalks shall not be construed to apply to, abrogate or in any way amend or change regulations, rules or ordinances that control the construction of sidewalks in residential subdivisions to be built. 
(Code 1978, § 6-411; Ord. No. 115, 3-2-87; Ord. No. 197, 10-15-12) 
Cross reference- Subdivision open space use and maintenance, § 78-31 et seq. 
Sec. 86-91. - Removal of snow and ice from sidewalks and liability therefor. 
(a)  Obligations of property owner or occupant. The owner, agent of the owner, or occupant of premises bordering on any street or public place within the town where there is an established sidewalk shall cause to be removed therefrom any and all snow and ice within 24 hours after same shall have fallen or formed, or within 24 hours after sunrise when the same shall have fallen or formed in the 14 hours preceding sunrise. When it is impracticable to remove ice or snow, the sidewalk shall be made safe and convenient for travel by covering with sand or some other suitable substance. This section shall not apply to any sidewalk that abuts the rear lot line of property unless such sidewalk is contiguous to a sidewalk on the side and/or front of the property. For the purposes of this section, such sidewalk to which this section shall not apply shall be the responsibility of the town. Sidewalks that are the responsibility of the town shall be cleared within a reasonable time after the completion of emergency highway and street snow removal. The owner, agent of the owner, or occupant, and in the case of a corporation, the officers thereof, who shall violate the provisions of this subsection shall be fined $35.00 for each offense, or an amount to be determined by the centralized infraction bureau pursuant to public law as amended, which latter amount shall be determined. 
(b)  Statute adopted. The provisions of C.G.S. § 7-163a are hereby adopted by the town. 
(c)  Removal of snow or sleet onto public street or thru-way.
