ARTICLE II. - WATER POLLUTION CONTROL AUTHORITY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions, committees, agencies, authorities and councils, § 2-121 et seq. 

Sec. 98-31. - Established; membership. 
(a)  There shall be a water pollution control authority in the town to consist of seven electors and two alternates. The seven electors shall be appointed by the town council for terms of four years. The town council shall appoint three electors to serve on the authority for terms of four years, commencing November 30, 2015. The town council shall appoint one elector to serve on the authority for a term of four years, commencing November 30, 2016. The town council shall appoint three electors to serve on the authority for terms of four years, commencing November 30, 2017. Any vacancy on the authority shall be filled for the unexpired portion of the term by the town council. In appointing electors to the authority, the town council shall not appoint more than a bare majority of any political party. 
(b)  The town council shall appoint two alternates to the authority for a term of two years, commencing November 30, 2015. Any vacancy in the alternates to the authority shall be filled for the unexpired portion of the term by the town council. In appointing alternates to the authority, the town council shall not appoint more than one alternate from any political party. 
(c)  The town council shall appoint the current authority membership to serve for transition terms as follows: three electors to the authority shall be appointed to serve until November 30, 2015; one elector to the authority shall be appointed to serve until November 30, 2016; three electors to the authority shall be appointed to serve until November 30, 2017; two alternates to the authority shall be appointed to serve until November 30, 2015. During the transition terms, the council shall not appoint more than a bare majority of any political party to the authority. 
(d)  The town council may, after a public hearing and by a two-thirds vote of its entire membership, remove any member of the authority for cause. 
(Code 1978, § 2-1201; Ord. No. 103, 5-3-82; Ord. No. 150, § 2-1201, 6-15-98; Ord. No. 205, 12-2-14, eff. 12-12-14) 
Sec. 98-32. - Compensation and expenses. 
    The members of the water pollution control authority shall serve without compensation, but the necessary expenses of the authority shall be paid by the town through proper appropriation procedure. 
(Code 1978, § 2-1202; Ord. No. 103, 5-3-82; Ord. No. 150, § 2-1202, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 98-33. - Chairman. 
    The members of the water pollution control authority shall choose a chairman from its members by ballot to serve for a term of two years or until his successor is duly elected. The authority may provide a method of removing an officer as a provision of its bylaws, which will include a vote of not less than five. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 2-1203, 5-3-82; Ord. No. 150, § 2-1203, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 98-34. - Powers and duties. 
    The water pollution control authority shall have all the powers provided under C.G.S. § 7-245 et seq. and Special Act 2-260 of 1969. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 2-1204, 5-3-82; Ord. No. 150, § 2-1204, 6-15-98) 
Sec. 98-35. - Successor to sewer commission. 
    The water pollution control authority is the successor to the sewer commission and shall assume all of its obligations and duties and be vested with all its rights and authority. 
(Ord. No. 103, § 2-1205, 5-3-82; Ord. No. 150, § 2-1205, 6-15-98) 
Secs. 98-36-98-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- This article consists of those portions of the town water pollution control authority's rules and regulations, as revised June 26, 1996, which are normally found in the standard sewer use ordinance. Such portions have been codified herein at the direction of the town. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 98-66. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Acquire a sewerage system means to obtain title to all or any part of a sewerage system or any interest therein by purchase, condemnation, grant, gift, lease, rental or otherwise. 
    Act or the act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 USC 1251 et seq. 
    Approved means accepted or acceptable under applicable specifications or requirements stated or cited in this article or accepted as suitable for the proposed area. 
    Authority means the town water pollution control authority. 
    BOD (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    Building means any structure served or capable of being served by the sewerage system. 
    Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to a point not less than five feet outside the inner face of the building wall, at which point it shall connect to the building sewer. 
    Building sewer means the extension of the building drain from the building drain to a point on the property line where it shall connect to the sewer lateral. 
    Categorical standards means national categorical pretreatment standards, also known as pretreatment standards. 
    Commercial establishment means any building or area used for business, industrial or professional purposes and providing facilities for the use of employees or customers. 
    Community sewerage system means any sewerage system serving one or more residences in separate structures which is not connected to a municipal sewerage system or which is connected to a municipal sewerage system as a distinct and separately managed district or segment of such system. 
    Compatible pollutant means BOD, suspended solids, pH and fecal coliform bacteria; plus any additional pollutants identified in the water pollution control facility's NPDES permit, where the water pollution control facility is designed to treat such pollutants and, in fact, does treat such pollutants to the degree required by the NPDES permit. 
    Construct a sewerage system means to acquire land, easements, rights-of-way or any other real or personal property or any interest therein, plan, construct, reconstruct, equip, extend and enlarge all or any part of a sewerage system. 
    Cooling water includes clean wastewater from air conditioning, industrial cooling, condensing and similar apparatus and from hydraulically powered equipment. In general, cooling water will include only water that is sufficiently clean and unpolluted to admit of being discharged without treatment or purification into any natural open stream or watercourse without offense. 
    DEP means the state department of environmental protection. 
    Director of health means that person duly appointed by the town manager to carry out prescribed duties of the director of health. 
    Disposal area means the entire area of an individual sanitary sewage disposal system used for underground dispersion of the liquid portion of sewage. It may consist of a disposal field, disposal bed, seepage pit or a combination thereof. 
    Drainlayer or licensed drainlayer means an individual whom the state shall have issued a license to install and repair building drains, building sewers, public sewer laterals, public sewers and individual sanitary sewage disposal systems during the period when such license is valid. The term drainlayer may also be applied to town employees designated by the town manager and also to state highway department's employees and employees of public utilities when they are engaged in installing, altering and repairing sewers, drains or connections and appurtenance thereto under permit from the town manager. 
    Dwelling unit means one or more rooms providing complete living facilities for one or more individuals, including equipment for cooking or provisions for the same, including rooms for living, sleeping, eating, bathing and sanitary facilities. 
    Emergency repair means any occurrence that will have an adverse effect on the health and welfare of the property owner as determined by the assistant director of public works/pollution control superintendent. 
    Floatable oil means oil, fat or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from sewage by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. 
    Garbage means wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
    gpd means gallons per day (24 hours). 
    Grab sample means a sample taken from a waste stream on a one-time basis with no regard to the flow in the waste stream and without consideration of time. 
    Grade means the slope of fall of a pipeline or the ground surface. It may be expressed as fall or drop per foot, per 100 feet, or in percent. 
    Hazardous waste means any explosive, flammable, corrosive radioactive, toxic, pathological or other waste or substances defined as hazardous under the applicable laws and rules and regulations of the United States Environmental Protection Agency and/or the state department of environmental protection, including but not limited to the Toxic Substances Control Act, the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, and the Comprehensive Environmental Response Cooperation and Liability Act, as amended. 
    Hearing board means that board appointed according to the provisions of this article. 
    Individual sanitary sewage disposal system means subsurface sewage disposal system designed and constructed to treat sewage in a manner that will retain most of the settleable solids in a watertight tank and to discharge the liquid portion to an adequate disposal area. 
    Industrial user means all users which discharge industrial process wastes (including cooling water) into the sewer system and perform activities identified under division D of the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, Bureau of the Budget. 
    Industrial wastes means the liquid wastes from industrial manufacturing processes, trades or businesses as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
    Inflow means any water other than wastewater that enters the public sewer system, including sewer service connections from sources, such as but not limited to roof leaders, cellar drains, yard drains, area drains, drains from wetland areas, manhole covers, cooling towers, stormwater surface runoff or drainage. Inflow does not include and is distinguished from infiltration. 
    Invert means the floor, bottom or lowest portion of a flow channel in a structure or pipe. 
    Major industries means users of 93,000 gallons or more of water annually. 
    Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
    NPDES means the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System. 
    Operate a sewerage system means own, use, equip, reequip, repair, maintain, supervise, manage, operate and perform any act pertinent to the collection, transportation and disposal of sewage. 
    Owner means the current owner of record of any lot or parcel of land as recorded in the land records of the town. 
    pH means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution. 
    Pollution control facility means a building or group of buildings, with appurtenances, used for treating sewage. 
    ppm expresses concentrations in parts per million by weight or volume. 
    Pretreatment or treatment means the reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater to a less harmful state prior to or in lieu of discharging or otherwise introducing such pollutants into a water pollution control facility. The reduction or alteration can be obtained by physical, chemical or biological processes, except as prohibited by 40 CFR 403.6(d). 
    Professional engineer means a person licensed to practice professional engineering in the state. 
    Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that has been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1.24 centimeters) in any dimension. 
    Public sewer lateral means a pipe laid incidental to the original construction of a main sewer from that sewer to some point at the side of the street, highway or similar location. 
    Public sewerage system means that portion of the sewerage line and system owned and controlled by the town. 
    Rule means each statement of general applicability by the authority that prescribes law or policy or describes the organization, procedure or practice requirements of the authority. 
    Sanitary equivalents means a normal strength of wastewater as measured in terms of suspended solids and BOD concentration. 
    Sanitary sewer means a sewer that carries sewage and to which stormwaters, surface waters and groundwaters are not intentionally admitted. 
    Septage means the liquids and solids removed from a tank used to treat domestic sewage. 
    Sewage means any substance, liquid or solid that may contaminate or pollute or affect the cleanliness or purity of any water. 
    Sewer means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
    Sewer lateral means a pipe laid incidental to the original construction of a main sewer to some point at the side of the street, highway or similar location. 
    Sewerage system means any device, equipment, appurtenance, facility and method for collecting, transporting, receiving, treating, disposing of or discharging sewage. 
    Sludge means the solid, semisolid and liquid residue that results from the treatment of wastewater, including the ash remaining after the incineration of residue. 
    Slug means any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste that, in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow, exceeds for any period of duration longer than 15 minutes more than five times the average 24-hour concentration or flow during normal operation. 
    Small industries means users of 93,000 gallons or less of water annually. 
    Soluble oil means oil that is of either mineral or vegetable origin and disperses in water or sewage at temperatures between zero degrees Celsius and 65 degrees Celsius. For the purposes of this article, emulsified oil shall be considered as soluble oil. 
    Storm drain means a pipe or conduit that collects and conveys stormwater or groundwater. 
    Superintendent means the superintendent of the pollution control department of the town. 
    Suspended solids means solids that either float on the surface of or are in suspension in water, sewage or other liquids, and are removable by laboratory filtering. 
    Toxic pollutant means pollutants or a combination of pollutants listed as toxic in regulations promulgated by the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency under the provisions of section 307(a) of the act or other acts. 
    User means any person who contributes, causes or permits the contribution of sewage into the sewerage system. 
    Wastewater means the combined sewage, septic and industrial wastes and normal inflow and infiltration. 
    Water pollution control authority (WPCA) means the duly appointed authority of the town. 
    Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 98-67. - Use of public sewers required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the town, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the town, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectional waste; however, agricultural fertilization with animal excrement shall be lawful and permissible, subject to the provisions of other state and town regulations. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet or stream within the town, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the town, any sewage or other polluted waters. 
(c)  Except as otherwise provided, it shall be unlawful to construct any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. Further, it shall be unlawful, in any area having available to it a public sanitary sewer, to repair, replace or extend any portion of a seepage field of an individual sanitary sewage disposal system. 
(d)  The owner of each house, building or other structure situated within the town on a parcel of land that has available to it a public sanitary sewer shall, at his expense, connect to such public sewer before occupying such premises unless special approval from the authority is given for any reason involving gross financial hardship, practical application or that on-site disposal is impossible. Each house, building or other structure used for human occupancy, employment or recreation that employs an individual sanitary sewage disposal system that is inadequate based upon established standards of town and state health departments, and having available to it a public sewer, shall, at the owner's expense, be connected to the public sanitary sewer in accordance with the provisions of this section within 30 days from the mailing of written notice by the director of health to the owner at his last known address; however, this period may be extended to a maximum of 60 days by the director of health if the property owner provides sufficient reason for such extension, based on financial hardship, weather or soil conditions, or other suitable reason. 
(e)  Except as otherwise provided, whenever a house, building or other structure that has employed an individual sanitary sewage disposal system shall connect to a public sanitary sewer, the individual sanitary sewer shall be promptly abandoned and the septic tank, if it is metal, after cleaning, filled with a suitable material. Any individual sanitary sewer employing a concrete tank with a concrete top shall be cleaned and abandoned for sanitary sewer purposes after the house, building or other structure is connected to the public sanitary sewer, but the tank need not be crushed but should be filled with a suitable medium to coarse sand. 
(f)  Any house, building or other structure that requires the use of an ejector pump to obtain public sanitary sewer service and has employed an individual sanitary sewer system utilizing a concrete tank with a concrete top need not abandon the individual sanitary sewerage system but may maintain the use of the system as a backup sewage disposal system. 
Sec. 98-68. - Protection from damage. 
    No person shall negligently, maliciously or willfully damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment that is part of the sewerage system. 
Sec. 98-69. - Powers and authority of inspectors. 
(a)  The superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the town, bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter all properties with the owner's consent for the purpose of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing in accordance with the provisions of this article. The superintendent or his representative shall have no authority to inquire into any processes, including metallurgical, chemical, oil, refining, ceramic, paper or other industries, beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers or facilities for wastewater treatment. If the superintendent or his duly appointed representative cannot procure the consent of the premises' owner to conduct an inspection, the superintendent is empowered to seek an administrative warrant in order to satisfy the inspection requirements of this article. 
(b)  The superintendent and duly authorized agents, bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter all private properties through which the town holds a duly negotiated easement for the purposes of but not limited to inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair and maintenance of any portion of the sewerage works lying within the easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on the easement shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved. 
Sec. 98-70. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person found to be violating any provision of this article, except section 98-68, shall be served by the authority with written notice stating the nature of the violation and proving a reasonable time limit for satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, by the expiration of the time limit stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. 
(b)  Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit provided for in subsection (a) of this section or any person who shall commit any violation of section 98-68 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be fined $99.00 for each violation. Each day in which any such violation shall continue shall be deemed a separate offense. 
Sec. 98-71. - Expenses. 
    In addition to all penalties specified in this article and in addition to any penalties provided by the general statutes, any person who shall cause injury or damage to the sewerage system or to any of its appurtenances, through violation of any of the provisions of this article, shall be liable to the town for all such injury or damage so caused, together with a reasonable attorney's fee and all court costs that may be incurred by the town in connection with recovery of compensation for such injury or damage. 
Secs. 98-72-98-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - INDIVIDUAL SANITARY SEWAGE DISPOSAL 

Sec. 98-96. - When authorized. 
    Where a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of section 98-67(d), the building sewer shall be connected to an individual sanitary sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this division. 
Sec. 98-97. - Permit required. 
(a)  Before commencement of construction, repair, alteration or enlargement of any individual sanitary sewage disposal system, the appropriately licensed installer shall first obtain a written permit signed by the town sanitarian. Such permits shall be available in the sanitarian's office. The applicant shall supplement the permit with any plans, specifications and other information as deemed necessary by the town sanitarian. A permit and inspection fee shall be paid to the town at the time the application is filed. The permit shall become void 60 days after issue if construction is not started. 
(b)  A final permit for an individual sanitary sewage disposal system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the sanitarian. 
Sec. 98-98. - Compliance with state health code. 
(a)  The type, capacities, location and layout of an individual sanitary sewage disposal system shall comply with the requirement of the state public health code regulations and technical standards for subsurface sewage disposal systems. 
(b)  The owner or occupant shall operate and maintain the individual sanitary sewage disposal system in a sanitary manner at all times in compliance with the state public health code regulations and technical standards for subsurface sewage disposal systems at no expense to the town. 
Sec. 98-99. - Responsibility of town. 
    The town or any of its agents shall not be held responsible for the inadequate operation of any disposal system installed under this division. 
Sec. 98-100. - Determination of adequacy by sanitarian. 
    When in the opinion of the town sanitarian the requirements of this division do not appear sufficient to provide adequate waste disposal at a specific location, the sanitarian may require such facilities or measures as he shall deem necessary. 
Secs. 98-101-98-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 98-121. - Approval required. 
(a)  No person shall make any excavation for or construct, install, lay, alter, abandon or remove any sewer, lateral or cross country line in a public street or on private lands within the town, which sewer discharges directly or indirectly to or into the sewerage system, without first obtaining written approval from the authority. 
(b)  Approval for emergency repairs to any sewer line must be obtained from the assistant director of public works or his designee, who will then oversee and approve the subject repair and who will then notify the authority of the repair at their next scheduled meeting. 
(c)  Any person proposing a new discharge into the public sewer system or a substantial change in the volume or character of pollutants that are being discharged into the public sewer system shall obtain written approval therefor from the authority before such new discharge or change in volume or character of pollution is made. 
(d)  Written approval from the authority is not needed for an individual whose building lot or residence existed at the time of the town installation of public sewer, to connect his private sewer to public sewer that has already been approved by the authority. However, the individual must obtain the appropriate permits from the town and fulfill any other applicable obligations stated in section 98-131. 
Sec. 98-122. - Type of connection. 
    When a connection to the public sewer is to be made, each building shall have a direct connection to the public sewer serving it; however, for commercial, industrial or multifamily residential buildings on the same lot or parcel of land, the authority may permit an external connection of several separate building sewers to one main on-site sewer or lateral, which shall have a direct connection to the public sewer. However, written approval must be obtained from the authority prior to connection to the public sewer. 
Sec. 98-123. - Payment of costs, expenses. 
    All costs and expenses incident to the installation, connection and maintenance of a sewer, lateral or cross country line on public or private lands shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the town from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by such installation. 
Sec. 98-124. - Use of old building sewers. 
    Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the engineering department, to meet all the technical requirements of this division and any other requirements that may need the approval of the authority. 
Sec. 98-125. - Construction requirements. 
    The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing and backfilling the trench shall all conform with the requirements as specified in the current public improvement specifications of the town. 
Sec. 98-126. - Elevation of building sewer. 
    Whenever practical, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such a building drain shall be lifted by a means approved by the authority and discharged to the building sewer. 
Sec. 98-127. - Prohibited connection. 
    No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer that in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
Sec. 98-128. - Conformity of connections with specifications. 
    The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the public improvement specifications of the town. 
Sec. 98-129. - Protection from hazards. 
    All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the town. 
Sec. 98-130. - Issuance of permits. 
(a)  Once approval is given for an installation, new or revised, of a sewer, lateral or cross country line by the authority, the issuing of required permits shall be under the direction of the public works department, engineering division. 
(b)  Permits to connect to the public sewer may be revoked and annulled by the engineering division for just cause, which shall include but not be limited to action or inaction that may damage the town's sewer system, including failure to follow plans or properly construct and failure to use proper materials. 
Sec. 98-131. - Classes of permits; application; fee; approval. 
(a)  There shall be two classes of connection permits: for residential and commercial service and for service producing other than industrial wastes, and for service to establishments producing industrial wastes. In either case, the owner or his agent shall make application for a permit on the form furnished by the town. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the superintendent or his duly authorized agent. 
(b)  Permit applications shall be available in the town engineer's office, and applications and plans shall be returned to the engineering division for review. 
(c)  A permit and inspection fee for a residential or commercial building sewer permit shall be paid to the town at the time the application is filed, such permit to become void 60 days after issue if construction is not started. 
(d)  Prior to discharge or permission to discharge into the town's public sewers, the applicant industry shall obtain written approval from the state department of environmental protection in the form of a permit, allowing the proposed discharge. There will be no town approval until state department of environmental protection approval is obtained where required. 
(e)  If the premises change ownership before the work is completed, or if another contractor is chosen to perform or finish the work, the original permit becomes void and a new permit must be obtained by the new parties in interest. 
Sec. 98-132. - Building permit endorsement. 
    Any person wishing to obtain a building permit and/or certificate of occupancy shall be required to have the building certificate of occupancy endorsed by the engineering representative. Such an endorsement by the engineering division representative shall be that he has knowledge of the construction, where connection to the sanitary sewers is anticipated, plans have been submitted and approved, and that connection to the sewage system has been completed at a proper location. 
Sec. 98-133. - Proximity of building sewer to well. 
    No building sewer shall be constructed within 75 feet of a water supply well; except that if a building sewer is constructed within 75 feet of a water supply well, it shall be constructed in accordance with all applicable guidelines and regulations as prescribed within the state public health code regulations and technical standards for subsurface sewage disposal systems. 
Sec. 98-134. - Installation by licensed drainlayer. 
    All building sewers shall be installed by a drainlayer who possesses a valid license issued under C.G.S. § 20-330 et seq. 
Secs. 98-135-98-155. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - DISCHARGE RESTRICTIONS 

Sec. 98-156. - Generally. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewers. Further, no person shall open the cover of, enter or alter any manhole or similar appurtenance of any public sewer, or deposit any wood, sticks, unshredded garbage or other material, the sewer, drain, manhole or appurtenance thereto was not intended to receive. 
Sec. 98-157. - Prohibited discharges. 
(a)  No user shall contribute or cause to be contributed, directly or indirectly, any pollutant or wastewater which will interfere with the operation or performance of the sewerage system. These general prohibitions apply to all such users of the town sewerage system whether or not the user is subject to categorical pretreatment standards or any other federal or state pretreatment standards or requirements. A user shall not contribute the following substance to any sewerage systems: 
(1)  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas. 
(2)  Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process or constitute a hazard in the receiving waters or the sewage treatment plant, including but not limited to cyanides in excess of 0.1 ppm as CN in the wastes as discharged to the public sewer. At no time shall two successive readings on an explosion hazard meter at the point of discharge into the system; be more than five percent nor any single reading over ten percent of the lower explosive limit (LEL) of the combustible gas. 
(3)  Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or having other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment and personnel of the sewerage system. 
(4)  Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of causing obstruction to the flow of sewers or other interference with the proper operation of the sewerage system, such as but not limited to ashes, cinders, sand, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, whole blood, hair and fleshings, entrails, paper dishes, cups, milk containers, grease or garbage with particles greater than one-half inch in any dimension. 
(b)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following described substances, materials, waters or wastes, which can harm either the sewers or sewage treatment process or equipment; have an adverse effect on the receiving stream; otherwise endanger life, limb or public property; or constitute a nuisance. A pollutant shall include but not be limited to any pollutant identified pursuant to section 307(a) of the Water Pollution Control Act. 
(1)  Any substances that may cause the water pollution control facility's (WPCF) effluent or any other product of the WPCF such as residues, sludges or scums to be unsuitable for reclamation process where the WPCF is pursuing a resource recovery program. In no case shall a substance discharged to the WPCF cause the facility to be in noncompliance with its NPDES permit guidelines, or regulations developed under section 405 and section 503 of the act or any other criteria guidelines, or regulations affecting sludge use or disposal developed pursuant to the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, Clean Air Act, the Toxic Substance Control Act, or state criteria applicable to the sludge management method being used. 
(2)  Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than 150 degrees Fahrenheit (65 degrees Celsius). 
(3)  Any water or waste containing fat, wax, grease, petroleum or mineral oil, whether emulsified or not, in excess of 100 mg/l or containing substances that may solidify or become viscous at temperatures between 32 and 150 degrees Fahrenheit (zero and 65 degrees Celsius). 
(4)  Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. 
(5)  Any waters or wastes containing iron pickling wastes or concentrated plating solutions. 
(6)  Any quantity of waste from an industrial or commercial process or processes containing greater concentrations than the minimum indicated by weight or by volume. For any of the following: 
Pollutant Concentration 
(ppm) Arsenic as As ..... 0.05 Barium as Ba ..... 5.0 Boron as B ..... 5.0 Cyanides as CN (amendable) ..... 0.1 Fluoride as F ..... 20.0 Chromium (total) ..... 1.0 Iron as Fe ..... 5.0 Magnesium as Mg ..... 100.0 Manganese as Mn ..... 5.0 Copper as Cu ..... 1.0 Zinc as Zn ..... 1.0 Cadmium as Cd ..... 0.1 Lead as Pb ..... 0.1 Tin as Sn ..... 2.0 Silver as Ag ..... 0.1 Mercury as Ni ..... 0.01 Nickel as Ni ..... 1.0 Hydrogen Sulfide H 2 S (or any halogen) ..... 10.0 Sulfur Dioxide as SO 2 ..... 10.0 Nitrous Oxide as N 2 O 4 ..... 10.0  
All metals are to be measured as total metals. 
(7)  Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentration as may exceed limits established by the superintendent in compliance with applicable state or federal regulations. 
(8)  Any water or wastes having a pH in excess of 9.5. 
(9)  Materials that exert or cause: 
a.  Unusual concentration of inert suspended solids (such as but not limited to fuller's earth, lime slurries and lime residues) or of dissolved solids (such as but not limited to sodium chloride and sodium sulfate). 
b.  Excessive discoloration (such as but not limited to dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions) as determined by the state department of environmental protection. 
c.  A five-day BOD greater than 212 mg/l by weight or suspended solids greater than 238 mg/l by weight or a chlorine demand greater than 15 mg/l by weight such as to constitute a significant load on the sewage treatment works. 
d.  An unusual volume of flow or concentration of wastes constituting slugs. 
(10)  Water having an average daily flow greater than five percent of the average daily sewage flow of the town. 
(11)  Water or wastes containing substances which are amenable to treatment only to such degrees that the sewage treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters. 
Sec. 98-158. - Action by superintendent. 
(a)  If any waters or wastes are discharged or proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in section 98-157(b) and which may have a deleterious effect upon the sewerage works, processes, equipment or receiving waters or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the superintendent may: 
(1)  Disapprove the waste discharge and take action to prohibit it; 
(2)  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewer; 
(3)  Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or 
(4)  Require payment to cover the added cost of handling and treating the wastes as provided in division 5 of this article. 
(b)  If the superintendent permits the pretreatment or neutralization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plans and equipment in regard thereto shall be prepared by a registered professional engineer by the state at the owner's sole cost and expense, and shall be subject to the review and approval of the superintendent and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes, ordinances and laws. 
Sec. 98-159. - Interceptors required. 
    Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the superintendent, they are necessary for proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts or any flammable wastes, sand or other harmful ingredients. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the superintendent and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. 
Sec. 98-160. - Maintenance of facilities by owner. 
    Where preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at his expense. 
Sec. 98-161. - Installation of control manhole. 
(a)  When required by the superintendent, the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessible and safely located, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the superintendent. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(b)  All industries discharging into a public sewer shall perform such monitoring of their discharge in accordance with requirements of state law. This includes installation, use and maintenance of monitoring equipment, keeping records and reporting the results of such monitoring to the superintendent. Such records shall be made available upon request by the superintendent to other agencies having jurisdiction over discharges to the receiving waters. 
Sec. 98-162. - Measurements to be in accordance with Standard Methods. 
    All measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this division shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" published by the American Public Works Association and shall be determined at the control manhole. If no special manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewerage works and to determine the existence of hazards to life, limb and property. 
Sec. 98-163. - Special agreements authorized. 
    No statement contained in this division shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the authority and any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or character may be accepted by the authority for treatment subject to payment therefor by the industrial concern provided that such agreements do not contravene any requirements of existing state and federal laws. 
Sec. 98-164. - Discharge of septage; fee. 
(a)  Septic tank cleaning contractors may discharge septage collected from town properties only into the sewage treatment plant. 
(b)  A tipping fee shall be set annually and shall be based upon the treatment costs for suspended solids and BOD removal using those formulas as described in section 98-192. The fee shall be based upon an average suspended solids and BOD concentration of 6,830 ppm and 2,490 ppm respectively, per 1,500 gallons of septage. Septage may be disposed of at the treatment plant provided: 
(1)  Such contents consist only of domestic or commercial wastes excluding any industrial wastes or substances prohibited from public sewers by this article. 
(2)  Such contents are transported in sanitary, watertight vehicles, equipped with a suitable valve outlet and meeting such requirements as may be stipulated by local or state health agencies. 
(3)  Delivery of such contents is made to the treatment plant site on days and hours as established by the superintendent. 
Sec. 98-165. - Permit for wastewater discharges. 
    A permit from the state commissioner of environmental protection is required prior to the initiation of discharge of any of the following wastewaters to a public sewer: 
(1)  Industrial wastewater of any quantity. 
(2)  Domestic sewage in excess of 5,000 gpd through any individual building to a public sewer. 
Sec. 98-166. - Protection from accidental discharges; report; emergency notification procedure. 
(a)  Each user shall provide protection from accidental discharge of prohibited materials or other substances as indicated in this division. Facilities to prevent accidental discharge of prohibited materials shall be provided and maintained at the owner's or user's own expense. 
(b)  Within five days following an accidental discharge, the user shall submit to the superintendent and the commissioner of environmental protection a detailed written report describing the cause of the discharge and the measures to be taken by the user to prevent similar future occurrences. Such notification shall not relieve the user of any expense, loss, damage or other liability that may be incurred as a result of damage to the sewerage works, fish kills, aquatic plants, or any other damage to persons or property; nor shall such notification relieve the user from any fines, civil penalties or other liability that may be imposed by this division or other applicable laws. Failure to take adequate measures to prevent a similar future occurrence shall be grounds for revocation of any permit granted by the town and action to prohibit discharge by such user. 
(c)  A notice shall be permanently posted on the user's bulletin board or other prominent place advising employees whom to call in the event of a discharge of prohibited wastes. Employers shall ensure that all employees are advised of the emergency notification procedure. 
Secs. 98-167-98-190. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - RATES AND CHARGES 

Sec. 98-191. - Connection charges. 
(a)  Required. Whenever a sanitary sewer has been laid out and constructed by the authority, connections from real estate to the sewer shall not be permitted until a sewer connection charge has been paid by or for the owners of the real estate to be served by the connection. 
(b)  Application. Any owner desiring to make a connection to a sanitary sewer as provided in this division shall make application to the director of public works, submitting such plans and specifications as may be required by the director. These plans and specifications shall contain information as to the amount of property to be utilized by the proposed buildings and improvements for which such connection is sought, and giving the type and extent of use contemplated of the sewer system. 
(c)  Approval; payment. 
(1)  A copy of such application and the accompanying information shall be submitted to the authority; and such authority shall, upon making a determination that the planned connection and the necessary pipes, pumping facilities if such are required, and other necessary improvements are in accordance with applicable statutes, regulations and ordinances, approve the applications and forthwith levy a connection charge. 
(2)  Payment of such connection charges shall be made prior to issuance of a permit to connect to the sewer system. 
(3)  When a property owner is prepared to connect his property to the lateral, a connection charge will be levied. A schedule of connection charges will be kept on file in the office of pollution control. 
(4)  To determine the amount of connection charge: 
a.  A dwelling unit shall be considered one single-family living quarters, one church building or one school building. 
b.  Determine the area of developed land, including streets, parking area, and open spaces; a fractional acre additional to at least one acre shall be prorated, but in no event shall the developed area consist of less than the minimum required by the town zoning regulations. 
(d)  Determination of charges. The connection charges provided for under subsection (c) of this section shall be determined by the appropriate action of the authority. 
(e)  Payment. When under the provisions of subsection (c) of this section a connection charge is due and payable, it shall be paid to the collector of revenue for the town. 
Sec. 98-192. - Sewer use charges. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to establish fair and reasonable charges for use of the sewerage system and in connection therewith giving consideration to appropriate factors relating to the kind, quality or extent of use of any property connected to or to be connected to the sewage system. This section is further intended to establish an equitable basis of cost recovery of the industrial share of the local capital and debt service charges. 
(b)  Method of calculating rates. An annual sewer use charge shall be imposed on each building connected into the sewer system and discharging sewage of any quality, character or quantity into the sewerage system. The following methods for calculating rates are prescribed: 
(1)  Sewer use charges shall fund 100 percent of the costs for pollution control operation and maintenance (O & M) and shall be prorated among the several user categories (residential, commercial, small industrial and major industrial) based upon the quantity of equivalent sanitary wastewater discharged. A user charge shall be computed according to the following general formula: 
User Charge = (C t ;minus; C r ) × Q

Where: 
C t is the total annual cost for O & M; 
C r is the cost for removal of excess solids and BOD; 
Q t is the sum of the individual user outflows (mgy); and 
Q is the quantity of an individual user outflow (mgy).

(2)  Industries shall be assessed a surcharge when suspended solids (SS) and BOD concentrations exceed 238 mg/l and 212 mg/l, respectively. A separate surcharge shall be computed for both SS and BOD. In the computation of SS and BOD surcharge rates, the annual allocated cost for SS and BOD removal shall be divided by the annual quantity of each parameter removed in the treatment process.

(c)  Small industries. 
(1)  The owner of a small industry is required to submit a sworn statement of water use or discharge into the sewer system from January 1 through December 31, such statement to be supported by any available records or evidence of water use or discharge to which the applicable rate shall be applied; or 
(2)  In the case of disagreement, the owner is required to install and maintain, at his own expense, a meter measuring sewage outflow, such measurements to be used in arriving at the sewer use charge. The meter to be installed in a place easily accessible to the authority or its duly authorized agent for recording purposes. 
(d)  Major industries. 
(1)  The owner of a major industry shall install and maintain, at his own expense, a meter measuring waste outflow, such measurements to be used in arriving at sewer use charge and the meter to be installed in a place easily accessible to the authority or its duly authorized agent for recording purposes; and 
(2)  A suitable sampling manhole shall be provided at the owner's expense in a place easily accessible to the authority or its duly authorized agent for monitoring BOD and SS. 
Location of flow measuring equipment and the sampling manhole may be combined upon approval of the authority. 
(e)  Billing cycle. 
(1)  Residential. The user fee per calendar year (annual charge) for each single-family living quarters shall be due and payable on October 1. 
(2)  Commercial and industrial. The user fee per calendar year (annual charge) for each commercial and industrial building connected into the sewer system shall be due and payable on April 1. 
(f)  Special charges. The authority shall establish special charges when water use is not related to sewer use, or when water is obtained from an unmetered source. 
Secs. 98-193-98-225. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WATER SERVICE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 98-226. - Water service for dwellings. 
(a)  No building or structure shall be erected for use as living quarters for one or more families unless it is supplied with drinking water from a well servicing no other structure used as living quarters or unless water for use by the structure is supplied by a water company specially chartered by the general assembly and approved by the public utilities commission. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to residential developments and subdivisions that had received preliminary approval by the town planning and zoning commission as of February 20, 1963. 
(Code 1978, § 11-200) 
Secs. 98-227-98-250. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WATER LIENS 

Sec. 98-251. - Route 5 and Sullivan Avenue. 
    Whenever a property owner makes or permits a connection to be made with the following described water main, for the purpose of supplying his property with water, a lien for the following described connection charge in favor of the town shall be immediately attached to all the real property of such owner forming part of or contiguous to the real property so supplied with water. The water main referred to in this section is the one installed on Route No. 5 from the northerly terminus of the Metropolitan District pipeline to the East Windsor town line and the water main installed on Sullivan Avenue from Route No. 5 to the intersection of Ayers Road and that water main installed on Ayers Road from the intersection of Ayers Road proceeding easterly for a distance of 200 feet. The connection charge referred to in this section shall become payable at once to the tax collector of the town and shall bear interest at the rate of six percent per annum until paid and shall be in addition to any service charge payable to the Connecticut Water Company for such connection. Such charge shall be determined by multiplying $4.44 by 150, and the amount thus computed shall be considered as applying to the maximum frontage to be supplied by one service pipe; except that in case the frontage of the property desiring water service is less than 150 feet or is located in an area zoned or designated commercial or industrial and the actual frontage is on record in the land records of the town, the connection charge shall be $4.44 for each foot of frontage of record. In no event shall the lien or connection charge be less than $444.00. Buildings occupied as residences in an industrial or commercial zone shall be charged at the same rate as those residences in a residential zone. 
(Code 1978, § 3-101(a)) 
Sec. 98-252. - Foster Street. 
(a)  Whenever a property owner makes or permits a connection to be made to the following described water main, for the purpose of supplying his property with water, an assessment in favor of the town shall immediately be levied against all real property of such owner forming part of or being contiguous to the property so supplied with water. The assessment shall become payable at once to the tax collector of the town, except as otherwise provided in this section, and shall be in addition to any service charge payable to the Connecticut Water Company, or its assigns or successors. This assessment shall be in the same proportion of the cost of installation of the water main that the frontage of the property bears to the total amount of frontage of property for which the main is available. 
(b)  The water main referred to in this section is that one installed in Foster Street from Bayberry Trail, southerly to the elderly housing complex known as Flax Hill. 
(c)  Any assessment levied under this section shall be due and payable on the date the connection is made to the water line. Any such assessment or portion thereof not paid within 30 days of its due date shall bear interest at the rate set by the general statutes as provided in reference to taxes from such due date. Each addition of interest shall be collectible as part of such assessment, and any unpaid assessment or portion thereof shall constitute a lien upon the real estate against which such assessment was levied from the date it became delinquent. Each such lien may be continued, released and recorded in the manner provided by statute for continuing, recording and releasing property tax liens. 
(d)  Any property owner who shall notify the collector of revenue in writing within 30 days of such due date may elect to pay the assessment in ten equal installments, the first installment of which shall be due on the due date and the remaining installments shall be payable annually thereafter on the anniversary of the due date. All such installments shall bear interest at the rate of six percent on the unpaid balance. 
(Code 1978, § 3-101(b); Ord. No. 123, 6-21-89) 
Sec. 98-253. - Graham Road. 
    Whenever a property owner makes or permits a connection to be made with the following described water main, for the purpose of supplying his property with water, a lien for the connection charge described in section 98-251 in favor of the town shall immediately attach to all the real property of such owner forming part of or contiguous to the real property so supplied with water. The water main referred to herein is that one installed in Graham Road from Hayes Road northerly to the Eli Terry School. The connection charge shall become payable at once to the tax collector of the town, shall bear interest at the rate of six percent per annum until paid, and shall be in addition to any service charge payable to the Connecticut Water Company, its assigns or successors, for such connection. This charge shall be determined in accordance with the provisions of section 98-251. 
(Code 1978, § 3-201(c)) 
Sec. 98-254. - Elm Street. 
    Whenever a property owner makes or permits a connection to be made with the following described water main, for the purpose of supplying his property with water, a lien for the connection charge described in section 98-251 in favor of the town shall immediately attach to all the real property of such owner forming part of or contiguous to the real property so supplied with water. The water main referred to herein is that one installed in Elm Street from Kelly Road northerly to the terminus of Elm Street. The connection charge shall become payable at once to the tax collector of the town, shall bear interest at the rate of six percent per annum until paid, and shall be in addition to any service charge payable to the Connecticut Water Company, its assigns or successors, for such connection. This charge shall be determined in accordance with the provisions of section 98-251. 
(Code 1978, § 3-201(d)) 
Sec. 98-255. - Main Street and Sullivan Avenue Water Main Assessment. 
(a)  Whenever a property owner makes or permits a connection to be made to the water main described in this section, for the purpose of supplying his property with water, an assessment in favor of the town shall immediately be levied against all the real property of such owner forming part of or being contiguous to the property so supplied with water. This assessment shall become payable at once to the tax collector of the town and shall be in addition to any service charge payable to the Connecticut Water Company, its assigns or successors. This assessment shall be computed by multiplying the frontage of the property by $6.50. In no event shall the assessment be less than $650.00. 
(b)  In the case of land zoned for other than commercial or industrial purposes or classified, pursuant to C.G.S. § 12-107(a)-(e), as farm land, forest land or open space land that has in excess of 350 feet of frontage, assessment of such excess frontage shall be deferred until such land is developed and connected to the water line. Buildings occupied as residences in an industrial or commercial zone shall be assessed on the same basis as those in a residential zone. 
(c)  The water main referred to in this section is that one installed in Main Street from Ellsworth Elementary School proceeding northerly to the intersection of Sullivan Avenue and thence proceeding easterly to the intersection of Route 5. 
(d)  Any assessment levied under this section shall be due and payable on the date the connection is made to the water line. Any such assessment or portion thereof not paid within 30 days of its due date shall bear interest at the rate of six percent per annum from the due date. Each addition of interest shall be collectible as part of such assessment, and any unpaid assessment or portion thereof shall constitute a lien upon the real estate against which such assessment was levied from the date it became delinquent. Each such lien may be continued, released and recorded in the manner provided by the general statutes for continuing, recording and releasing property tax liens. 
(e)  Any property owner who shall notify the collector of revenue in writing within 30 days of such due date may elect to pay such assessment in ten equal installments, the first installment of which shall be due on the due date and the remaining installments shall be payable annually thereafter on the anniversary of the due date. All such installments shall bear interest at the rate of six percent on the unpaid balance. 
(Code 1978, § 3-201(e)) 
Sec. 98-256. - Brian Road, Birch Road, Laurel Street. 
(a)  Whenever any of the water mains described in this section becomes available for use by a property owner in the front of his property for the purpose of supplying his property with water, an assessment in favor of the town shall immediately be levied against all the real property of such owner forming part of or being contiguous to the property so supplied with water. This assessment shall become payable at once to the tax collector of the town, except as otherwise provided in this section, and shall be in addition to any service charge payable to the Connecticut Water Company, its assigns or successors. This assessment shall be the same proportion of the cost of installation of the water main that the frontage of the property bears to the total amount of frontage of property for which the main is available. 
(b)  The water mains referred to in this section are the mains to be installed: 
(1)  The entire length of Brian Road. 
(2)  The entire length of Birch Road. 
(3)  Laurel Street from and including No. 54 Laurel Street through and including No. 91 Laurel Street. 
(c)  Any assessment levied under this section shall be due and payable on the date the installation of such main is completed and is available for connection by the property owner for supply of water. Any such assessment or portion thereof which is not paid within 30 days of its due date shall bear interest at the rate of six percent per annum from the due date. Each addition of interest shall be collectible as part of such assessment and any unpaid assessment or portion thereof shall constitute a lien upon the real estate against which such assessment was levied from the date it became delinquent. Each such lien may be continued, released and recorded in the manner provided by the general statutes for continuing, recording and releasing property tax liens. 
(d)  Any property owner who shall notify the collector of revenue in writing within 30 days of such due date may elect to pay said assessment in ten equal installments, the first installment of which shall be due on the due date and the remaining installments shall be payable annually thereafter on the anniversary of the due date. All such installments shall bear interest at the rate of six percent on the unpaid balance. 
(Code 1978, § 3-202)

ARTICLE 1  INTRODUCTION/DISTRICTS
Page 1-1
ARTICLE 1 INTRODUCTION/DISTRICTS
Section 1.1 Districts
For the purpose of these regulations, the Town of South Windsor is divided into zoning districts
regulating the use of the land and buildings, the height and bulk of buildings, and the areas of lots, yards,
courts and open spaces as follows and as provided hereafter:
Zoning District
Designation
Principal Use
Residential Zones
